relationships.additional_info: CMSC majors will not receive credit for this course towards their upper level concentration in their CMSC major.  Smith School of Business.  All BMGT majors, including students who are a double major in CMSC, must complete BMGT301 for their BMGT degree.Restricted to Information Systems majors with 45 credits completed and other BMGT majors with 53 credits completed.

BMGT301F.name: Introduction to Information Systems
BMGT301F.description: Comprehensive overview of information systems (IS), which explores the strategic and tactical nature of IS. The basic concepts in analyzing and designing information systems for business applications will be presented. Aspects of data management such as databases, data warehousing, data analysis, and data mining will be analyzed, and the basics of web page and web site design will be outlined. Students will also be introduced to modern information systems infrastructure such as telecommunications, networks, and information systems security. Knowledge of Excel or a similar spreadsheet tool.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major in BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: CMSC majors will not receive credit for this course towards their upper level concentration in their CMSC major.  Smith School of Business.  All BMGT majors, including students who are a double major in CMSC, must complete BMGT301 for their BMGT degree.Restricted to second year students in the Smith School's Smith Start program (FPFF).

BMGT302.name: Essential Programming Skills for Business Analytics
BMGT302.description: The course introduces structured and object-oriented programming and its applications in business functions and analytics. Students will apply problem-solving skills to create software solutions using programming logic and data structures. The course especially emphasizes learning by doing exercises using a modern, high-level programming language and industry standard software.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT301; or permission of BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major in BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business.  Smith School of Business; and must not be in the Computer Science major.Restricted to Information Systems majors with 45 credits completed and other BMGT majors and Business Analytics minors with 53 credits completed. Not open to Computer Science.

BMGT302F.name: Essential Programming Skills for Business Analytics
BMGT302F.description: The course introduces structured and object-oriented programming and its applications in business functions and analytics. Students will apply problem-solving skills to create software solutions using programming logic and data structures. The course especially emphasizes learning by doing exercises using a modern, high-level programming language and industry standard software.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT301; or permission of BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major in BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business.  Smith School of Business; and must not be in the Computer Science major.Restricted to students in the Smith School's iTBT Fellows program. The specific programming language used in the course is subject to change as we tailor the course content to industry standards.

BMGT310.name: Intermediate Accounting I
BMGT310.description: Comprehensive analysis of financial accounting topics related to financial statement preparation and external reporting.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT221.
BMGT310.
relationships.additional_info: Accounting majors with 60 credit hours completed.

BMGT313.name: Financial Statement Analysis
BMGT313.description: Provides students with the tools to conduct a financial statement analysis, which is part of an overall business analysis. Involves understanding and using the information that financial statements are communicating to users.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT221.
relationships.additional_info: Accounting and Finance majors with 53 credits completed.

BMGT313F.name: Financial Statement Analysis
BMGT313F.description: Provides students with the tools to conduct a financial statement analysis, which is part of an overall business analysis. Involves understanding and using the information that financial statements are communicating to users.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT221.
relationships.additional_info: Emerging CFOs (FPEC).

BMGT321.name: Managerial Accounting
BMGT321.description: A study of the basic concepts of product costing and cost analysis for management planning and control. Emphasis is placed on the role of the accountant in organizational management, analysis of cost behavior, standard cost budgeting, responsibility accounting and relevant costs for decision-making.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT221.

BMGT323.name: Taxation of Individuals
BMGT323.description: Federal taxation of individuals focusing on income, exclusions, deductions, depreciation, credits and capital transactions. Property coverage includes the tax consequences of sales and dispositions of investment and business assets. Both tax planning and compliance issues are covered.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT221.
relationships.additional_info: Accounting majors with 53 credit hours completed.

BMGT326.name: Accounting Systems
BMGT326.description: A study of accounting systems and computer and communications technology.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT221; and (BMGT201 or BMGT301).
relationships.additional_info: Accounting majors with 60 credit hours completed.

BMGT332.name: Quantitative Models for Management Decisions
BMGT332.description: The aim of this course is to introduce management science techniques for informed decision-making that can be applied in spreadsheet models to assist in the decision-analysis process. Models include Linear Programming, Transportation and Assignment problems, network flow models, Integer and non-linear programming, Simulation and Decision Trees.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT231 or BMGT230; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.
relationships.additional_info: BMGT majors and Business Analytics minors with 53 credit hours completed.

BMGT340.name: Business Finance
BMGT340.description: Topics include: the principles and practices involved in the organization, financing and rehabilitation of business enterprises; the various types of securities and their use in raising funds, apportioning income, risk and control; intercorporate relations; and new developments. Emphasis on solution of problems of financial policy faced by management.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT220; and (BMGT231 or BMGT230).

BMGT340F.name: Business Finance
BMGT340F.description: Topics include: the principles and practices involved in the organization, financing and rehabilitation of business enterprises; the various types of securities and their use in raising funds, apportioning income, risk and control; intercorporate relations; and new developments. Emphasis on solution of problems of financial policy faced by management.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT220; and (BMGT231 or BMGT230).
relationships.additional_info: students in the Smith School's Sophomore Finance Fellows Program.

BMGT340N.name: Business Finance
BMGT340N.description: Topics include: the principles and practices involved in the organization, financing and rehabilitation of business enterprises; the various types of securities and their use in raising funds, apportioning income, risk and control; intercorporate relations; and new developments. Emphasis on solution of problems of financial policy faced by management.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT220; and (BMGT231 or BMGT230).
relationships.additional_info: agricultural and resource economics majors (0111C) with 53 credit hours completed.

BMGT341.name: Financial Markets
BMGT341.description: Shows the interconnectedness of the markets. The role of the Central bank and monetary policy is included in this context. Students develop an understanding of: (i) the determination of interest rates; (ii) financial instruments, markets and institutions; (iii) the impact of monetary policy on institutions; and (iv) how financial innovations create markets.

relationships.prereqs: Must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in BMGT340.
relationships.additional_info: Finance majors with 60 credit hours completed.

BMGT342F.name: Wall Street Finance
BMGT342F.description: Using concepts and tools of finance, students will examine a wide range of business problems and explore possible solutions.  The course is designed to improve a student's problem solving capabilities, business writing and communication skills, teamwork, and planning skills. Students will also gain experience in analyzing issues frequently faced by financial decision-makers.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT340.
relationships.additional_info: students in the Smith School's Wall Street Fellows Program.

BMGT343.name: Investments
BMGT343.description: An introduction to financial investments. Topics include: securities and securities markets; investment risks, returns and constraints; portfolio policies; and institutional investment policies.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT340.
relationships.additional_info: This course cannot be used to fulfill any requirements for majors in Economics.     Finance majors with 60 credit hours completed.

BMGT345.name: Foundations of Financial Management for Non Business Majors
BMGT345.description: Provides students an overview of financial management.  Students will understand how a business allocates financial resources in an uncertain environment to maximize shareholder value.  In addition students will learn the following: how to apply accounting principles to corporate finance; how to value assets, projects, companies and investment securities; understand the relationship between risk and return and how it impacts investment and corporate decisions; how to calculate a company's cost of capital, and develop an intuitive comprehension of financial concepts and analysis.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT210 or BMGT220.
relationships.restrictions: Must not have completed BMGT340; and must not be a major in the R.
relationships.additional_info: Course does not apply to a Smith School degree.   H. Smith School of Business.    BMGT340 may substitute for BMGT345.Open to all non-BMGT majors.

BMGT350.name: Marketing Principles and Organization
BMGT350.description: An introduction to the concepts and principles of marketing including the marketing of service and nonprofit organizations. Provides an overview of all the concepts in marketing including relationship marketing, product development, pricing, promotion, marketing research, consumer behavior, international marketing, distribution and internal marketing to employees.

relationships.additional_info: Recommended: ECON200.

BMGT350N.name: Marketing Principles and Organization
BMGT350N.description: An introduction to the concepts and principles of marketing including the marketing of service and nonprofit organizations. Provides an overview of all the concepts in marketing including relationship marketing, product development, pricing, promotion, marketing research, consumer behavior, international marketing, distribution and internal marketing to employees.

relationships.additional_info: Recommended: ECON200. agricultural and resource economics (0111C) and horticulture (0107C) majors with 53 credit hours completed.

BMGT351.name: Marketing Research Methods
BMGT351.description: Focuses on aiding marketing decision-making through exploratory, descriptive and causal research. Develops student skills in designing market research studies, including selection of data collection method, development of data collection instrument, sample design, collection and statistical analysis of data and reporting the results, including data visualization.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT230; and must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in BMGT350.
relationships.additional_info: Marketing majors with 53 credit hours completed

BMGT354.name: Consumer Analysis
BMGT354.description: Identifying buyer behavior concepts relevant to a specific marketing problem so that appropriate marketing decisions can be made. Conceptual frameworks are drawn from psychology, sociology, economics, and other social sciences to aid in understanding the behavior of ultimate and industrial buyers.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT350.
relationships.additional_info: Marketing majors with 68 credit hours completed.

BMGT355.name: Foundations of Marketing for Non Business Majors
BMGT355.description: Introduces the concepts and principles of marketing.  Provides an overview of all the concepts in marketing including relationship marketing, product development, pricing, promotion, marketing research, consumer behavior, international marketing, distribution and internal marketing to employees.

relationships.restrictions: Must not have completed BMGT350; and must not be a major in the R.
relationships.additional_info: Course does not apply to a Smith School degree. H. Smith School of Business.      BMGT350 may substitute for BMGT355.Open to all non-BMGT majors.

BMGT360.name: Strategic Management of Human Capital
BMGT360.description: Provides students with the basic knowledge needed to help organizations attract, select, develop, engage, evaluate, and retain talent. Topics covered may include strategic HRM, the role of globalization, legal issues in HRM, work analysis, HR planning, recruitment, personnel selection, performance management and appraisal, training and development, career development, compensation systems, motivating and rewarding performance, labor relations, and employee health and safety.

relationships.additional_info: all students with 53 credit hours completed.

BMGT362.name: Negotiations
BMGT362.description: By using a variety of assessment tools, feedback sources, skill-building exercises, and exercise debriefings, this experiential course is designed to enhance students' negotiating self-confidence and improve students' analytical skills, interpersonal skills, creativity and persuasive abilities.

relationships.restrictions: Must not have completed COMM425.

BMGT363.name: Leadership and Teamwork in Organizations
BMGT363.description: Provides a comprehensive understanding of fundamental leadership concepts, theories, and skills in organizations and applies to assessing and developing effective leadership practices in organizations.

relationships.additional_info: Course restricted to Management majors (0503G & 0503E) with 53 credits.

BMGT364.name: Managing People and Organizations
BMGT364.description: An introduction to selected aspects of human behavior in organizations generally known as organizational behavior (OB). This course is designed to help students develop systematic and fundamental understanding of people and their behaviors in organizations, as well as useful abilities and skills required to effectively and ethically manage various individual, interpersonal, group, and organization-level processes.

BMGT364N.name: Managing People and Organizations
BMGT364N.description: An introduction to selected aspects of human behavior in organizations generally known as organizational behavior (OB). This course is designed to help students develop systematic and fundamental understanding of people and their behaviors in organizations, as well as useful abilities and skills required to effectively and ethically manage various individual, interpersonal, group, and organization-level processes.

relationships.additional_info: agricultural and resource economics (0111C) and dietetics (1307D) majors with 53 credit hours completed.

BMGT365.name: Entrepreneurial Finance and Private Equity
BMGT365.description: Studies venture capital and private equity using a combination of cases, lectures and guest speakers. Addresses how venture capitalists provide capital to start-up firms in growing industries and how private equity markets provide capital to help established medium-sized firms (often family businesses) grow and restructure. Focuses on how financial, legal, and economic issues are dealt with in the financial contracts between venture capitalists and their limited partners and between capitalists (or other private equity investors) and the firms in which they invest.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT461 or BMGT361.
relationships.restrictions: Junior standing or higher.
relationships.additional_info: Restricted to BMGT majors with 72 credit hours completed and Innovation and Entrepreneurship (#BU03) minors.

BMGT366.name: Growth Strategies for Emerging Companies
BMGT366.description: Offers practical management tools that are needed to build a new venture into a significant enterprise. The competencies, strategies and structures of successful high performance businesses are studied through cases, videos and guest lecturers. Topics include leadership, internal growth strategies, merger, acquisition and franchising.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT461 or BMGT361.
relationships.restrictions: Junior standing or higher.
relationships.additional_info: Restricted to Innovation and Entrepreneurship (#BU03) minors and Management (0503G) majors.

BMGT367.name: Career Search Strategies in Business
BMGT367.description: An overview and opportunity to practice job search skills critical to obtaining internships and full-time positions. Course will cover strategies for exploring career options, preparing job search materials, development of job search skills such as interviewing and networking. Students are encouraged to take this course in the sophomore or junior year.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major in BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business.

BMGT370.name: Introduction to Transportation
BMGT370.description: An overview of the transportation field with an emphasis on freight movements from the perspective of both providers of capacity and users of freight services. Examines the characteristics of the freight modes and the role of each mode as a major component of logistics and supply chain management. Explores the economics, energy use, and finances of each mode as well as the impact of government policies on each mode's future. Discussion of infrastructure and capacity needs of the transportation system and its ability to support the economy.

relationships.additional_info: BMGT majors with 53 credit hours completed.

BMGT372.name: Introduction to Logistics and Supply Chain Management
BMGT372.description: Supply chain management involves the coordination of suppliers, manufacturers, distributors, and retailers to ensure that products and services are available to the final consumer in a timely and cost-effective fashion. Logistics management is the subset of supply chain management dealing with the physical flows of product and includes such activities as transportation management, warehousing, materials handling, inventory management, and order fulfillment. Attention is paid to the logistics cost trade-offs within the firm and between members of the supply chain.

relationships.additional_info: BMGT majors with 53 credit hours completed.

BMGT375.name: Supply Chain Management for Non Business Majors
BMGT375.description: Examines management decision-making in the design, implementation and coordination of a firm's supply chain activities. Topics include transportation management, warehousing, materials handling, inventory management, and order fulfillment.

relationships.restrictions: Must not have completed BMGT372; and must not be a major in the Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business. Open to all non-BMGT majors.

BMGT380.name: Business Law I
BMGT380.description: Legal aspects of business relationships. Examination of torts and business crimes, contracts and agency. The law of personal property and bailment relationships. Survey of public policy issues.

BMGT380N.name: Business Law I
BMGT380N.description: Legal aspects of business relationships. Examination of torts and business crimes, contracts and agency. The law of personal property and bailment relationships. Survey of public policy issues.

relationships.additional_info: agricultural and resource economics majors (0111C) with 53 credit hours completed.

BMGT382.name: Marketing and Innovation for Entrepreneurs
BMGT382.description: Marketing and Innovation are two critically important activities that determine success in any business venture. This course will focus on understanding the fundamentals of marketing and innovation from the perspective of an entrepreneur. At a broad level, we will apply proven marketing frameworks (STP and 4Ps) to effectively deliver innovation in an entrepreneurial context.

relationships.restrictions: Must not have completed BMGT352.

BMGT385.name: Operations Management
BMGT385.description: Studies the design, management and improvement of a firm's processes and systems for creation and delivery of products and services. Includes strategic and operational views of supply chain, product development, and capacity analysis, highlighting the competitive advantages that operations management can provide the firm.

relationships.additional_info: BMGT majors and Business Analytics minors with 53 credit hours completed.

BMGT390H.name: Designing Innovative Systems
BMGT390H.description: QUEST students develop an understanding of complex systems that incorporate elements of business and technical design and analyze how these systems evolve over time and may be shaped by technology disruptions, internal decisions, and external forces. Students apply these concepts to real-world complex systems in a team environment.

relationships.prereqs: ENES190 or BMGT190.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in the QUEST program.
relationships.additional_info: Cross-listed with: ENES390. Restricted to QUEST program students. Cross-listed with ENES390H.

BMGT392.name: Introduction to International Business Management
BMGT392.description: A study of the domestic and foreign environmental factors affecting the international operations of U.S. business firms. The course also covers the administrative aspects of international marketing, finance and management.

relationships.prereqs: ECON200.
relationships.additional_info: BMGT majors with 53 credit hours completed.

BMGT395.name: Principles of Management for Non Business Majors
BMGT395.description: Introduces concepts related to organization behavior. Topics include leadership, team decision making and management, conflict resolution and negotiations, organizational culture, and organization change. Students will learn how to apply those concepts and theories to understanding and critically analyzing various individual, interpersonal, group, and organizational management processes.

relationships.restrictions: Must not have completed BMGT364; and must not be a major in the Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business. Open to all non-BMGT majors.

BMGT397.name: Mentoring Multidisciplinary Teams
BMGT397.description: QUEST students practice essential skills for mentoring and coaching multidisciplinary teams. These include effective communications, facilitation, conflict resolution, and the ability to motivate. Students will practice these skills as mentors for student teams from BMGT/ENES 190H. In the process, they will strengthen their knowledge of design and quality techniques.

relationships.restrictions: Restricted to QUEST Program (TQMP) students.
relationships.additional_info: Cross-listed with: ENES397. Restricted to QUEST program students. Cross-listed with ENES397.

BMGT398.name: Individual Study in Business and Management

BMGT398A.name: Individual Study in Business and Management; Internship
BMGT398A.description: Smith School of Business students. Interested students should contact Erin Fields Saddler (esaddler@rhsmith.umd.edu) for details and permission. Click here for further information

BMGT398C.name: Individual Study in Business and Management; Undergraduate Teaching Scholars Training

BMGT398I.name: Individual Study in Business and Management; Information Technology and Business Tranformation (iTBT) Fellows
BMGT398I.description: Information Technology and Business Transformation Fellows.

BMGT402.name: Database Systems
BMGT402.description: The fundamentals of database management systems (DBMS), data models, query processing, and data warehouses, and their application in the development of business information systems will be covered. An important goal of this course is to understand the value of information resources and information management challenges within an organization.

relationships.additional_info: Recommended: BMGT302.   Information Systems majors with 60 credits completed and other BMGT majors and Business Analytics minors with 72 credits completed.

BMGT403.name: Systems Analysis and Design
BMGT403.description: Techniques and tools applicable to the analysis and design of computer-based information systems. System life cycle, requirements analysis, logical design of databases and performance evaluation. Emphasis on case studies. Project required that involves the design, analysis and implementation of an information system.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT301; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.
relationships.additional_info: Recommended: BMGT302. Information System students with 72 credits completed.

BMGT406.name: Developing Applications for the Web and Social Media
BMGT406.description: The design and development of Web applications and the underlying platforms and standards for Web application development will be covered. It will examine the phenomenon of social media, social networking and crowdsourcing and understand their use within organizations.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT402 and BMGT302.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major in BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business.  Restricted to Information Systems majors with 60 credits completed and other BMGT majors with 72 credits completed.

BMGT407.name: Information Systems Projects
BMGT407.description: Senior capstone course for the decision and information sciences major. Collected knowledge from the DIS courses and application to significant problems of size and complexity. State-of-the-art research ideas and current business and industrial practices in information systems.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT402 and BMGT403.
relationships.restrictions: Senior standing.
relationships.additional_info: Permission to register for the course is granted to Information Systems majors with 86 credit hours completed who will have completed BMGT407's prerequisites by the start of the Fall semester.

BMGT408C.name: Emerging Topics in Information Systems; Quality Web Development in Business

BMGT408E.name: Emerging Topics in Information Systems; Big Data and AI using Cloud Computing
BMGT408E.description: Information Systems majors with 60 credit hours completed and other BMGT majors and Business Analytics minors with 72 credit hours completed.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT302.

BMGT411.name: Ethics and Professionalism in Accounting
BMGT411.description: Analysis and discussion of issues relating to ethics and professionalism in accounting.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT311.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Accounting program.
relationships.additional_info: Restricted to Accounting majors with 86 credit hours completed.

BMGT417.name: Taxation of Corporations, Partnerships and Estates
BMGT417.description: Federal taxation of corporations using the life-cycle approach-formation, operation, assessment, merger, reorganization and liquidation. Overviews of pass-through entities - partnerships and s-corporations -using the life-cycle approach, and the tax consequences of wealth transfers by individuals - gift and estate taxation. Both tax planning and compliance issues are addressed.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT221.
relationships.additional_info: Accounting majors with 84 credit hours completed.

BMGT422.name: Auditing Theory and Practice
BMGT422.description: A study of the independent accountant's attest function, generally accepted auditing standards, compliance and substantive tests and report forms and opinions.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT310; and must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in BMGT311.

BMGT428J.name: Special Topics in Accounting; Accounting Advisory for Closely Held Businesses
BMGT428J.description: Prerequisites: BMGT220 and BMGT340.  Accounting and Finance majors.

BMGT430.name: Data Modeling in Business
BMGT430.description: Explores the role of statistical models in business analytics to drive managerial decision-making and improve performance through the use of relevant data-motivated examples.  Topics include regression models (both simple and multiple regression, as well as logistic regression for binary data), model validation, variable transformation, variable selection, discriminant analysis, and forecasting.  These topics are modeled using state-of-the-art data analytics software.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT231 or BMGT230; or permission of BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business. BMGT majors with 72 credit hours completed or Business Analytics minors.

BMGT431.name: Data Analytics
BMGT431.description: An introduction to the tools and techniques that are central to the analysis of abundant data that is being collected in many forms including web traffic, social network data, and reviews and comments on websites.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT430.
relationships.additional_info: Business Analytics minors or OM majors.

BMGT434.name: Analytics Consulting: Cases and Projects
BMGT434.description: This course assumes that students have already been introduced to the concepts and techniques of operations research/business analytics (OR/BA). Published papers, short cases, and projects in OR/BA will be analyzed and discussed in a thoughtful way, taking into account the soft (people-related) issues and the hard (mathematical/optimization) issues.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT332 and BMGT385.
relationships.additional_info: BMGT majors, QUEST students, and Business Analytics minors with 72 credit hours completed.

BMGT435.name: Business Process Simulation
BMGT435.description: Covers the methods for computer simulation modeling and analysis of complex systems. Students are assumed to have been introduced to the basic techniques and applications in the field of operations management and business analytics. Course emphasis is on modeling of real-world systems (for example, inventory or queueing systems), implementing simulations in special purpose software, and analyzing simulation results.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT332 and BMGT385.
relationships.additional_info: BMGT majors or Business Analytics minors with 60 credits completed.

BMGT438A.name: Special Topics in Operations Management; Applied Quantitative Analysis
BMGT438A.description: Course restricted to QUEST students. Cross-listed with ENES489A.

BMGT438T.name: Special Topics in Operations Management; Cross-Cultural Perspectives on Quality

BMGT440.name: Advanced Financial Management
BMGT440.description: Analysis and discussion of cases and readings relating to financial decisions of the firm. The application of finance concepts to the solution of financial problems is emphasized.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT340.
relationships.additional_info: BMGT majors with 68 credit hours completed.

BMGT441.name: Fixed Income
BMGT441.description: Describes important financial instruments which have market values that are sensitive to interest rate movements. Develops tools to analyze interest rate sensitivity and value fixed income securities. Defines and explains the vocabulary of the bond management business.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT340.
relationships.additional_info: Finance majors with 72 credit hours completed.

BMGT443.name: Applied Equity Analysis and Portfolio Management
BMGT443.description: Study and application of the concepts, methods, models, and empirical findings to the analysis, valuation and selection of securities, especially common stock.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT343.
relationships.additional_info: BMGT majors with 84 credit hours completed.

BMGT444.name: Futures and Options Contracts
BMGT444.description: The institutional features and economic rationale underlying markets in futures and options. Hedging, speculation, structure of futures prices, interest rate futures, efficiency in futures markets and stock and commodity options.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT343.
relationships.additional_info: Finance majors with 84 credit hours completed.

BMGT445.name: Banking and Financial Institutions
BMGT445.description: Analysis and discussion of cases and readings in commercial bank management. The loan function is emphasized; also the management of liquidity reserves, investments for income and source of funds. Bank objectives, functions, policies, organization, structure, services and regulation are considered.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT340.
relationships.additional_info: Recommended: ECON330 or BMGT341. Finance majors with 84 credit hours completed.

BMGT446.name: International Finance
BMGT446.description: Financial management from the perspective of the multinational corporation. Topics covered include the organization and functions of foreign exchange and international capital markets, international capital budgeting, financing foreign trade and designing a global financing strategy. Emphasis of the course is on how to manage exchange and political risks while maximizing benefits from global opportunity sets faced by the firm.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT340.
relationships.additional_info: Finance and International Business majors with 72 credit hours completed.

BMGT448L.name: Special Topics in Finance; Hedge Fund Management
BMGT448L.description: Finance majors with 72 credit hours completed.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT340.

BMGT448X.name: Special Topics in Finance; Private Equity Strategy & Execution
BMGT448X.description: Finance majors with 60 or more credits completed.Students will need access to a Windows computer, Microsoft Excel and Microsoft PowerPoint.  Visit this link  for additional course information.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT340.

BMGT448Y.name: Special Topics in Finance; Behavioral Finance

BMGT449F.name: Investment Fund Management: Lemma Senbet Fund

BMGT450.name: Integrated Marketing Communications
BMGT450.description: In-depth study of coordinated marketing activities including advertising, sales promotion, Internet marketing, direct marketing and personal selling. Emphasizes strategic planning to effectively use these  promotional tools to communicate with customers and meet marketing goals. Blends theory and current practice to provide managerial orientation.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT350.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major in BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business.    Restricted to BMGT-Shady Grove Seniors majoring in Marketing. Other students may request enrollment on a space available basis. UMCP undergraduate BMGT students are not eligible to enroll at Shady Grove.

BMGT453.name: Retail Management
BMGT453.description: Planning and implementing retail marketing strategy. Application to store and non-store (catalog, internet) retailing. Evaluation of how environmental trends in the consumer market, competition, the economy and technology affect retail strategy in the U.S. and global market.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT220 and BMGT350.
relationships.additional_info: BMGT majors with 60 credit hours completed.

BMGT454.name: Global Marketing
BMGT454.description: Marketing functions from the global executive's viewpoint, including coverage of global marketing policies relating to product adaptation, data collection and analysis, channels of distribution, pricing, communications and cost analysis. Consideration is given to the cultural, legal, financial and organizational aspects of global marketing.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT350.
relationships.additional_info: BMGT majors with 72 credit hours completed.

BMGT456.name: Customer-Centric Innovation
BMGT456.description: Addresses the management of new products and services with a focus on the innovation process, specifically the development and launching of new products or services: Opportunity Identification, Concept Generation, Design, Testing and Launch.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT350.
relationships.additional_info: BMGT majors and QUEST students with 60 credits.

BMGT457.name: Marketing Policies and Strategies
BMGT457.description: This capstone course ties together various marketing concepts using the fundamentals of strategic market planning as the framework. Application of these principles is accomplished by analyzing and discussing cases and by playing a marketing strategy computer simulation game. Analysis of current business articles to understand the link between theory and real-world problem solving.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT350.
relationships.additional_info: Marketing majors with 100 credit hours completed.

BMGT458A.name: Special Topics in Marketing; Design and Innovation in Marketing

BMGT458B.name: Special Topics in Marketing; Design Applications in Marketing and Branding

BMGT458Q.name: Special Topics in Marketing; Computer Graphics Workshop

BMGT458R.name: Special Topics in Marketing; Advanced Computer Graphics Workshop
BMGT458R.description: students in the Strategic Design and Innovation Fellows program.

BMGT461.name: Entrepreneurship
BMGT461.description: Process of creating new ventures, including evaluating the entrepreneurial team, the opportunity and the financing requirements. Skills, concepts, mental attitudes and knowledge relevant for starting a new business.

relationships.restrictions: Must not have completed BMGT361.
relationships.credit_granted_for: BMGT261, BMGT361, BMGT461, ENES460, SMLP470 or HLMN470.

BMGT461M.name: Entrepreneurship
BMGT461M.description: Process of creating new ventures, including evaluating the entrepreneurial team, the opportunity and the financing requirements. Skills, concepts, mental attitudes and knowledge relevant for starting a new business.

relationships.restrictions: Must not have completed BMGT361.
relationships.additional_info: Restricted to Innovation & Entrepreneurship Minors (#BU03).
relationships.credit_granted_for: BMGT261, BMGT361, BMGT461, ENES460, SMLP470 or HLMN470.

BMGT461N.name: Entrepreneurship
BMGT461N.description: Process of creating new ventures, including evaluating the entrepreneurial team, the opportunity and the financing requirements. Skills, concepts, mental attitudes and knowledge relevant for starting a new business.

relationships.restrictions: Must not have completed BMGT361.
relationships.additional_info: Restricted to non-BMGT majors with 72 credits. Not open to innovation and Entrepreneurship minors.
relationships.credit_granted_for: BMGT261, BMGT361, BMGT461, ENES460, SMLP470 or HLMN470.

BMGT463.name: Cross-cultural Challenges in Business
BMGT463.description: Examines in depth the nature of international cultural value-differences and their behavioral-related effects in the workplace. Topics include decision-making and leadership styles and reactions to various work assignments and reward structures.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major in BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business.

BMGT466.name: Global Business Strategy
BMGT466.description: Focuses on the strategic challenges that directly result from and are associated with the globalization of industries and companies. Topics include drivers of industry globalization, difference between global and multi-domestic industry, global expansion strategies, sources of competitive advantage in a global context, and coordination of a company across a global network.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major in BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business.Restricted to International Business majors and Management majors with 72 credit hours completed.

BMGT468A.name: Special Topics in Management and Organization; Casual Inference and Data Analytics for Managers

BMGT468G.name: Special Topics in Management and Organization; The Value Creation Challenge
BMGT468G.description: Visit this link for more information.

BMGT468R.name: Special Topics in Management and Organization; Fearless Founders: New Venture Practicum
BMGT468R.description: Click here  for more information and to seek permission to register for this course.

BMGT468V.name: Special Topics in Management and Organization; Business Models and Methods to Affect Social Change

BMGT468X.name: Special Topics in Management and Organization; The Value Creation Challenge
BMGT468X.description: Visit this link for more information.

BMGT468Y.name: Special Topics in Management and Organization; Entrepreneurial Capitalism Around the World

BMGT468Z.name: Special Topics in Management and Organization; Create the Future through Systems Thinking and Design
BMGT468Z.description: A Fearless Ideas Course from the Academy for Innovation & Entrepreneurship (AIE)  Click here for more information on the Fearless Ideas Courses.

BMGT472.name: Purchasing and Inbound Logistics
BMGT472.description: Analysis of the resupply activities of logistics management, including purchasing policies, transportation planning, and inventory control. Attention is directed toward total cost minimization and the establishment of a sustainable competitive advantage based on procurement.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT372.
relationships.additional_info: Supply Chain Management majors only.

BMGT475.name: Supply Chain Strategy and Network Design
BMGT475.description: Analysis of the strategic aspects of supply chain management. Emphasis on the creation of end-user value through supply chain cost reductions, service improvements or both. Attention is directed toward the enabling role of technology in support of strategy evaluation and implementation.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT372.
relationships.additional_info: Supply Chain Management majors (0503T).

BMGT476.name: Technology Applications in Supply Chain Management
BMGT476.description: An understanding of the role of technology in managing the supply chain. Provides students with hands-on experience in advanced software systems that build on top of enterprise resource planning systems. Major emphasis is placed on demonstrating that these systems result in supply chain cost reductions and service improvements.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT372.
relationships.additional_info: Supply Chain Management and Information Systems majors.

BMGT477.name: International Supply Chain Management
BMGT477.description: The study of the importance of the supply chain management within a global context. Topics covered include: the structure, service, pricing and competitive relationships among international carriers and transport intermediaries as well as documentation, location decisions, international sourcing/distribution and management of inventory throughout the international supply chain.

relationships.additional_info: Supply Chain Management and International Business majors.

BMGT478G.name: Special Topics in Supply Chain Management; Supply Chain Consulting

relationships.prereqs: Must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in BMGT372.
relationships.restrictions: Must be a student with SCM majors (0503T).

BMGT484.name: Digital Marketing
BMGT484.description: Examines the process of developing, implementing, and analyzing strategies for successfully marketing a variety of existing and potential products and services through digital means, including the web, social media, and mobile apps. Both the development and analysis of digital media for marketing will be discussed.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT350.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major in BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business.Restricted to BMGT majors with 60 credit hours completed.

BMGT485.name: Project Management
BMGT485.description: Modern project management techniques that are used by modern practicing professionals will be covered. Particular attention is given to the management of technology based systems and projects in a business enterprise. The topics covered include: defining project scope, alignment of projects with enterprise strategy, managing project cost, time and risks using tools such as CPM/PERT, and measuring project performance.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT231 or BMGT230; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major in BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business. Restricted to Information Systems majors with 60 credit hours completed and BMGT majors & Quest students with 72 credit hours completed.
relationships.credit_granted_for: BMGT485, ENCE320, ENCE325, INST408O or INST453.

BMGT490H.name: QUEST Capstone Professional Practicum
BMGT490H.description: The capstone course for the QUEST Honors Program provides students with an opportunity to learn in multidisciplinary teams of business, engineering, and science students in a real-world setting. Companies engage teams of QUEST students with real organizational challenges and dedicate resources to help students address these problems. Student teams must enhance their skills in quality management, process improvement, and systems design and will apply these to add value to a client. In the process, students will improve their teamwork skills.

relationships.prereqs: ENES390 or BMGT390.
relationships.additional_info: Cross-listed with: ENES490.  Quest Program students.

BMGT491.name: Scoping Experiential Learning Projects
BMGT491.description: QUEST students cultivate relationships with new and current corporate partners and prepare project scopes for QUEST's introductory course, BMGT/ENES 190H, and capstone course, BMGT/ENES 490H. Requires independent work communicating with clients and class visits to a variety of potential project sites.

relationships.prereqs: BMGT190 or ENES190.
relationships.restrictions: Restricted to QUEST Program (TQMP) students.
relationships.additional_info: Cross-listed with: ENES491. Prerequiste: BMGT190H or ENES190H. Restricted to Quest. Cross-listed with ENES491.

BMGT495.name: Strategic Management
BMGT495.description: A case-based course where students learn to play the role of the "strategic manager" who defines the scope of its business operations and, within the chosen scope, how the firm will compete against rivals.  This course focuses on how a firm can both formulate effective business-level and corporate-level strategies to achieve competitive advantage and earn above average profits.

relationships.additional_info: BMGT students with 60 credit hours completed.

BMGT600.name: Leadership and Teamwork
BMGT600.description: Course examines concepts of team-building and leadership which are critical to managerial success. Topics include leadership, decision making, communication and conflict, work motivation, building effective teams, and organizational change and culture.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business; or must be in Business and Management (Master's) program.

BMGT602.name: Introduction to Financial Accounting
BMGT602.description: Overview of financial accounting, periodic financial statements and the financial reporting process. Importance of financial statements as information source for creditors and investors and as a means by which managers can communicate information about their firms.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Business and Management (Master's) program; or permission of BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business.

BMGT606.name: Data Driven Decision Making
BMGT606.description: Analytical modeling of business decisions; uncertainty, risk and expected utility; regression modeling to infer relationships among variables.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in one of the following programs (Business and Management (Master's); Business and Management (Master's)) ; or permission of BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business.

BMGT610.name: Financial Management
BMGT610.description: Focuses on the valuation of the real assets of firms as well as the valuation of stocks and bonds, the primary financial assets in an economy. While details vary, the conceptual foundations of valuation boil down to three themes: time value of money, no-arbitrage, and systematic risk.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business; or must be in Business and Management (Master's) program.

BMGT612.name: Marketing Management
BMGT612.description: Analysis of marketing problems and evaluation of specific marketing efforts regarding the organization's products and services, pricing activities, channel selection, and promotion strategies in both domestic and international markets.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business; or must be in Business and Management (Master's) program.

BMGT758I.name: Special Topics in Business and Management; Purposeful Leadership

BMGT758N.name: Special Topics in Business and Management; Negotiation and Conflict Management

BMGT758X.name: Special Topics in Business and Management; Experiential Learning I

BMGT808R.name: Special Topics in Information Systems; Research Seminar in Decision, Operations and Information Technologies

BMGT818A.name: Special Topics in Accounting and Information Assurance; Behavioral Research in Accounting

BMGT818R.name: Special Topics in Accounting and Information Assurance; Workshop in Accounting Research

BMGT828.name: Independent Study in Business and Management

BMGT830.name: Operations Research:  Linear Programming
BMGT830.description: Concepts and applications of linear programming models, theoretical development of the simplex algorithm, and primal-dual problems and theory.

relationships.prereqs: MATH240; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department; or permission of BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business.

BMGT834.name: Operations Research: Probabilistic Models
BMGT834.description: Theoretical foundations for the construction, optimization, and applications of probabilistic models. Queueing theory, inventory theory, Markov processes, renewal theory, and stochastic linear programming.

relationships.prereqs: MATH241; and (STAT400; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department).
relationships.additional_info: Or permission of BMGT-Robert H. Smith School of Business.

BMSO600.name: Data, Models and Decisions
BMSO600.description: The field of data analytics is a very vibrant and broad field. The amount of data available and computing power have exploded in recent years. There is an increasing demand for business analysts who can select and apply the appropriate methods and interpret the results within the context of the problem. The goal of this course is to learn methods for exploring data and building models with the purpose of supporting data-driven decision making. The content of the course can be grouped as follows: Data Exploration, Probability, Confidence Interval Estimation, Hypothesis Testing and Regression Analysis. The focus will be on exploring realistic business scenarios, analyzing datasets using the appropriate analytical techniques, interpreting the analytic output within the context of the business scenario and translating the statistical results into actionable insights.

relationships.prereqs: Permission of BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in an online Business Master of Science program; or permission of BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business.  Smith School of Business.

BMSO601.name: Database Management Systems
BMSO601.description: The fundamentals of managing data and information within an organization, including enterprise level platforms and tools for data driven analytics.  Includes processes for acquiring and cleaning data, storing data, making it available for analytics, visualizing output, and archiving the data for long term use. Involves computational thinking, covers significant theoretical material on data models and queries, and teaches several different analytics and programming tools.

BSCI126.name: Pollinators in Crisis
BSCI126.description: We will dissect the pollinator crisis, and in the process learn about insects, about the interaction of organisms in complex ecosystems, and about the human-nature interface. Students will work in groups that specialize in an aspect of pollinator biology and their challenges. Instruction will target methods for collecting information, interpretation of scientific information and the professional presentation of findings.

relationships.additional_info: (Sponsoring Dept.: ENTM). Not acceptable for credit for any Biological Sciences major.

BSCI135.name: Amazing Green: Plants that Transformed the World
BSCI135.description: An interactive way to learn about plants and science, focusing on how plants have changed human history, the biology of their growth, and the science behind their use.

relationships.additional_info: (Sponsoring Dept.: CBMG). Students must pay a $40.00 laboratory materials fee. Not acceptable for credit for any Biological Sciences major.

BSCI151.name: Beyond Race: Human Biological Diversity
BSCI151.description: Do racial labels have any practical use in understanding human biological diversity?  Such categorizations are inextricably linked to racism, including a history of misuse in science going back hundreds of years, yet modern biological research and medicine often include the use of race.  At its core, addressing this question requires understanding the balance between genetic and non-genetic factors underlying human diversity.  The course will help students make an informed critique of the biological basis of race through the study of topics such as: basic biology, data analysis and experimental design, human evolution and genetics, and biomedical research and health outcomes.

relationships.additional_info: (Sponsoring Dept.: BIOL).

BSCI160.name: Principles of Ecology and Evolution
BSCI160.description: Basic principles of biology with special emphasis on  ecological and evolutionary biology.

BSCI201.description: Anatomy and physiology of the skeletal, muscular, neural, endocrine, and sensory systems. Course not acceptable toward major requirements in Biological Sciences, Chemistry or Biochemistry.

BSCI222.name: Principles of Genetics
BSCI222.description: Principles and mechanisms of heredity and gene expression. Considers plant, animal, and microbial organisms.

relationships.additional_info: Or must have completed BSCI105 or (BSCI170 and BSCI171); and two semesters of chemistry.(Sponsoring Dept.: BSCI).

BSCI223.description: Fundamental concepts in morphology, physiology, genetics, immunology, ecology, and pathogenic microbiology. Applications of microbiology to medicine, the food industry and biotechnology.

relationships.additional_info: (Sponsoring Dept.: CBMG). Students must pay a $40.00 laboratory materials fee.

BSCI279W.name: Supplemental Study; Problem Solving for Molecular Courses
BSCI279W.description: "A Feeling for the Molecule and how biologists can approach and appreciate molecular thinking. This is a supplemental study course for introductory organic chemistry to support biology majors; we will develop strategies for problem-solving that will be useful for other upper-level biological science courses.

BSCI283.name: Principles of Microbiology
BSCI283.description: Introduction to microorganisms designed for science majors. Genetic principles underlying microbial abilities; microbial structure-function relationships; metabolism, physiology, and ecology of microorganisms; interactions between microorganisms (including pathogens) and their hosts.

relationships.prereqs: BSCI222.

BSCI289.description: (Sponsoring Dept.: BSCI). Provides credit for off-campus research internships. This credit counts as elective toward graduation, but does not satisfy any Biological Sciences degree requirements (For information about research credit that does count toward Biological Sciences contact the Biological Sciences Program, room 1322 Symons Hall). The off-campus internship credit requires that a contract form be filed with the Assistant Dean for Science Education Initiatives, Room 1313 Symons Hall, prior to the internship. The contract must be finalized and signed by the research supervisor at the end of the semester before credit will be awarded.

BSCI300.name: Strategies for Success
BSCI300.description: Students often face an increased emphasis on critical thinking, pressure from a typically higher credit hour load, and a faster pace of exposure to new material when moving from lower- to upper-level coursework. The Biological Sciences program designed this course to help all transfer students make successful transitions, both academically and socially, to the University of Maryland at Shady Grove.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major in USG-Universities at Shady Grove; and must be in Biological Sciences: Physiology & Neurobiology program.

BSCI330.name: Cell Biology and Physiology
BSCI330.description: Biochemical and physiological mechanisms underlying cellular function. Properties of cells which make life possible and mechanisms by which cells provide energy, reproduce, and regulate and integrate with each other and their environment.

relationships.restrictions: Must not have completed BSCI230.
relationships.additional_info: And minimum grade of C- in BSCI170 and BSCI171; or minimum grade of C- in BSCI105.     (Sponsoring Dept.: BIOL). Specialization Areas: PHNB, CEBG, MICB, ECEV, and GENB. Students must pay a $40.00 laboratory materials fee.

BSCI330H.name: Cell Biology and Physiology
BSCI330H.description: Biochemical and physiological mechanisms underlying cellular function. Properties of cells which make life possible and mechanisms by which cells provide energy, reproduce, and regulate and integrate with each other and their environment.

BSCI338B.name: Special Topics in Biology; Marine Biology
BSCI338B.description: (Sponsoring Dept: BIOL). Acceptable towards Biological Sciences Specialization Areas: GENB and ECEV.

relationships.prereqs: BSCI160.

BSCI338N.name: Special Topics in Biology; Hormones and Behavior
BSCI338N.description: (Sponsoring Dept.: BIOL). Acceptable toward Biological Sciences Specialization Areas: ECEV, GENB (Cell Biology category), and PHNB. Cross-listing with PSYC489G.  A comprehensive overview of the field of behavioral endocrinology, the study of the relationship between hormones and behavior, from a psychobiological perspective. Examine the major mammalian endocrine systems, how hormones influence sex determination, how hormones underlie sex differences in brain structure and function, the role of hormones in parental and social behaviors, mood disorders, homeostasis, cognition, and stress. Both normal and abnormal hormonal pathologies will be discussed. Due to the physiological and experimental perspectives, much of the phenomenology will be based on research in species other than humans. This species comparative approach will reveal interesting "ways of doing things" that are intriguingly different from how "humans do things."

relationships.prereqs: C- or better in BSCI330, NEUR200, or PSYC202.

BSCI338Z.name: Special Topics in Biology; Field Research
BSCI338Z.description: (Sponsoring Dept: BIOL). Cannot be used as credit toward the major requirements for any Biological Sciences major. Contact the Biology Department Undergraduate Office for course information.

BSCI339R.name: Selected Topics in Biology; Evolution of Aging
BSCI339R.description: Prerequisites: C- or better in BSCI370. (Sponsoring Dept: BIOL).  Acceptable toward Biological Sciences Specialization Areas: ECEV and GENB (Additional Courses Category). Discuss alternative reasons for why animals age at different rates. Weekly meetings will be student-led discussions of classic and recent literature. Topics will include, but are not limited to, evolutionary theories of aging, biomarkers of aging, sex differences in aging, experimental manipulations that alter lifespan in model and nonmodel organisms, and the interactions between the immune system and aging.

BSCI339Y.name: Selected Topics in Biology; Invertebrate Behavioral Physiology Research Seminar
BSCI339Y.description: Credit cannot be applied to the requirements of any Biological Sciences Major.

BSCI339Z.name: Selected Topics in Biology; Cell Death and Cancer Research Seminar
BSCI339Z.description: Credit cannot be applied to the requirements of any Biological Sciences Major.

BSCI348.description: (Sponsoring Dept.: CBMG). May be repeated, but only 3 credits may be applied to major requirements.

BSCI348A.description: (Sponsoring Dept.: CBMG). Students will act as Undergraduate Teaching Assistants for BSCI223.  Students must be available for one of the BSCI223 lab periods. Students interested in this teaching/leadership opportunity should contact Dr. John Buchner for application information: This course is applicable for the Enrichment credits required of all Biological Sciences students in majors with 0404 codes. For others this is elective credit.

BSCI348R.description: (Sponsoring Dept.: CBMG). This course is an opportunity for students interested in microbiology to pursue a research project in an off-campus lab. The student must see the instructor and complete an information sheet found on the web site, prior to enrolling in the course. Click here for more course information.

BSCI353.name: Principles of Neuroscience
BSCI353.description: Principles of nervous system function, ranging from molecular and cellular basis of neuron function through nervous system integration.

relationships.prereqs: 1 course with a minimum grade of C- from (BSCI207, BSCI330).
relationships.additional_info: (Sponsoring Dept.: BIOL). Acceptable toward Bilogical Sciences Specialization Areas: CEBG (Cell Biology), Development, Physiology), and PHNB.

BSCI357.name: Neurobiology of Chemosensory Systems
BSCI357.description: Chemosensation is essential for all forms of life, orchestrating several physiological processes, such as feeding, sexual behaviors, and body homeostasis. This course will review the function of chemosensory systems, including olfaction, gustatory and central chemoreception, among others. Through lectures and discussion of papers, we will examine the cell biology, systems neuroscience, and evolutionary aspects in these chemosensory systems.

relationships.prereqs: Minimum grade of C- in BSCI353 or NEUR306.
relationships.additional_info: (Sponsoring Dept.: BIOL). Applicable towards Biological Sciences Specialization Areas: GENB and PHNB.

BSCI360.name: Principles of Animal Behavior
BSCI360.description: Study of animal behavior with emphasis on its evolution and function. Topics include genetic basis of behavior, communication, aggression, foraging, cooperation, mate selection, and relevance for conservation.

relationships.prereqs: BSCI160 and BSCI161; or BSCI106.
relationships.additional_info: And BSCI170 and BSCI171; or BSCI105. And BSCI222.(Sponsoring Dept.: BIOL). Acceptable toward Biological Sciences specialization areas: PHNB, and GENB.

BSCI361.name: Principles of Ecology
BSCI361.description: Basic principles of population, community, and ecosystem ecology. Use of these principles to predict possible consequences of human-caused changes in the environment and to understand the level of uncertainty of those predictions.

relationships.prereqs: BSCI160 and BSCI161; or BSCI106.
relationships.additional_info: And (MATH130, MATH136, or MATH140).(Sponsoring Dept.: BIOL). Acceptable toward Biological Sciences Specialization Areas: ECEV and GENB.

BSCI363.name: The Biology of Conservation and Extinction
BSCI363.description: Ecology, evolutionary biology, and paleontology will be applied to the study of conservation, species invasions, and extinction.

relationships.prereqs: Minimum grade of C- in BSCI361.
relationships.additional_info: (Sponsoring Dept.: BIOL). Acceptable toward Biological Sciences Specialization Areas: ECEV and GENB (Ecology, Behavior & Organismal).

BSCI366.name: Environmental Physiology of Animals
BSCI366.description: Explores the diverse challenges animals face in staying alive and reproducing in the context of the environments in which they live. We will consider universal constraints imposed by fundamental laws of physics and chemistry and how these underlie both the physiological challenges faced by animals and the solutions diverse animal lineages have evolved to meet these challenges.

relationships.prereqs: BSCI207.

BSCI370.name: Principles of Evolution
BSCI370.description: Understanding evolutionary processes in a natural and human environment, including adaptation; DNA sequence, protein, and genome evolution; evolution of developmental mechanisms; mechanisms of evolutionary change (mutation, natural selection, drift); epidemiology; coevolution and biological control; speciation; comparative methods; extinction and conservation; human evolution.

relationships.prereqs: Minimum grade of C- in BSCI160, BSCI161, and BSCI222 .
relationships.additional_info: (Sponsoring Dept.: BIOL) Applies to Biological Sciences Specialization Areas: PHNB, GENB, and ECEV.

BSCI374.name: Mathematical Modeling in Biology
BSCI374.description: Students will learn empowering mathematical techniques through the understanding of biological models. Models are chosen from a variety of biological disciplines. Mathematical skills that will be developed along the way include: solving non-linear difference equations, eigenvector analysis, and the implementation of these algorithms as computer models.

relationships.prereqs: MATH131, MATH136, or MATH141.
relationships.additional_info: The HLSC374 version of this course is restricted to students in the Honors College Integrated Life Sciences program.  Cross-listed with: HLSC374.   Students must pay a $40.00 laboratory materials fee.

BSCI374H.name: Mathematical Modeling in Biology
BSCI374H.description: Students will learn empowering mathematical techniques through the understanding of biological models. Models are chosen from a variety of biological disciplines. Mathematical skills that will be developed along the way include: solving non-linear difference equations, eigenvector analysis, and the implementation of these algorithms as computer models.

relationships.prereqs: MATH131, MATH136, or MATH141.

BSCI379G.description: Prequisite: permission of department. See CBMG department Undergraduate office. (Sponsoring Dept: CBMG). Click here for more course information.

students participating in the CBMG Departmental Honors Program. (Sponsoring Dept.: CBMG).
