relationships.restrictions: Must be in Business and Management (Master's) program; or permission of BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business.

BUSM706.name: Innovation & Product Development
BUSM706.description: Focuses on the development of innovations - new products or new services - from the perspective of a marketer. For an innovation to be successful in the market, it has to be customer-centric: hence, in this course, we study how to develop and bring to market elegant and efficient solutions to strong customer needs. This is a fundamental business challenge, faced while working in a startup or in an established company; when developing a new product or a new service; and when serving customers who are individuals or large corporations.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Business and Management (Master's) program; or permission of BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business.

BUSM715.name: Digital Marketing
BUSM715.description: It has been a quarter century since the commercial use of the Internet and the World Wide Web began and during that time the business landscape has changed at a frenetic pace. Large multinational corporations such as Alphabet/Google, Facebook, Amazon, Alibaba and eBay, unheard of twenty years ago, have emerged as key players in our modern economy. In 2017 holiday season, online sales increased over 16 percent of overall spending online in 2016 with online retail spending in the U.S., the highest percentage since tracking began in 1999. Sales made through mobile devices have increased at a rapid rate to around 22 to 40 percent of all online sales. Corporations now highlight the importance of creating a digital relationship with customers. Moreover, digital technologies and devices such as smartphones, smart products, the Internet of Things, Artificial Intelligence, and deep learning all promise significant transformations of consumers lives in the near future. It is against this backdrop this course seeks to understand how the developments in digital technology are re-shaping the process and the strategy of marketing in the broad space we call digital marketing.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Business and Management (Master's) program OR Permission of BMGT-Robert  H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business.

BUSM754.name: Competitive and Collaborative Negotiation
BUSM754.description: Increase negotiating self-confidence and improve capacity to achieve win-win solutions to organizational problems. Improve effectiveness at finding creative solutions to conflict.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Business and Management (Master's) program; or permission of BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business.

BUSM758J.name: Special Topics in Business; Financial Management I

BUSM758N.name: Special Topics in Business; Managing Change

BUSM758P.name: Special Topics in Business; Financial Management II

BUSM788B.name: Global Business Experience; Doing Business in Brazil

BUSM788G.name: Global Business Experience; Doing Business in India

BUSM788J.name: Global Business Experience; Doing Business in South Africa

BUSM788W.name: Global Business Experience; Doing Business in Asia: Supply Chain Challenges and Opportunities in Asia

BUSO600.name: Leadership and Teamwork
BUSO600.description: Course examines concepts of team-building and leadership which are critical to managerial success. Topics include leadership, decision making, communication and conflict, work motivation, building effective teams, and organizational change and culture.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Business and Management (Master's) program; or permission of BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business.

BUSO603.name: Data Analysis
BUSO603.description: Many different skills are required in arriving at informed managerial decisions. Among these are analytical and quantitative skills. Data Analysis is one in a sequence of two courses that seeks to develop these two important skills. More formally, the goals of this course are: to introduce basic statistical techniques: summarizing and presenting data; confidence intervals and hypothesis tests; regression analysis.; to implement these techniques using spreadsheets; and to become active users of data analysis in making managerial decisions.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Business and Management (Master's) program; or permission of BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business.

BUSO604.name: Managerial Economics and Public Policy
BUSO604.description: Basic microeconomic principles used by firms, including supply and demand, elasticities, costs, productivity, pricing, market structure and competitive implications of alternative market structures. Market failures and government intervention. Public policy processes affecting business operations.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Business and Management (Master's) program; or permission of BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business.

BUSO612.name: Marketing Management
BUSO612.description: Analysis of marketing problems and evaluation of specific marketing efforts regarding the organization's products and services, pricing activities, channel selection, and promotion strategies in both domestic and international markets.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Business and Management (Master's) program; or permission of BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business.

BUSO616.name: Managerial Accounting
BUSO616.description: Use of accounting data in corporate planning and control. Cost-volume- profit analysis, budgeting, pricing decisions and cost data, transfer pricing, activity-based management, performance measures, and standard costing.

relationships.prereqs: BUSI610; or BUSO602; or BUSM602.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Business and Management (Master's) program; or permission of BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business.

BUSO624.name: Operations Management
BUSO624.description: Operations management is concerned with efficient and effective design and operation of business processes for delivering products and/or services. Emphasis is given to process analysis and design, capacity management and bottlenecks, waiting lines and the impact of uncertainty in process performance, quality management, lean, six-sigma, and revenue management.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Business and Management (Master's) program; or permission of BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business.

BUSO700.name: Fundamentals of Business
BUSO700.description: This course introduces students to the language of business. Topics covered include financial accounting, financial management, data models, strategy, leadership and teamwork, and a brief action learning project on innovation. Pre-work includes the DISC assessment, and a requires a passing grade on a spreadsheet pre-work course.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Business and Management (Master's) program; or permission of BMGT-Robert H Smith School of Business.

BUSO701.name: Integrative Business Capstone
BUSO701.description: This is an experiential course that involves an integrative business experience. This experience may be simulated through a software package or through content, speakers and events that are based in a realistic business setting. Students compete in teams. Each team makes decisions in areas such as human resources, compensation packages, geographic expansion through sales offices, debt versus equity financing, manufacturing and inventory management, marketing, including pricing, advertising and product design. The impact of each of these decisions flows through the three financial statements and results in financial outcomes and ratios that measure the success of each team. Additional metrics include stakeholders beyond investors such as employee morale, community engagement, and environmental impact. Students compete for financing and for customers. Multiple presentations are made by students during the simulation to explain their strategy, their tactics, and their planned investments.

relationships.prereqs: Students must have completed a minimum of 48 credit hours.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Business and Management (Master's) program; or permission of BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business.

BUSO711.name: Executive Powers and Negotiation
BUSO711.description: Increase negotiating self-confidence and improve capacity to achieve win-win solutions to organizational problems. Improve effectiveness at finding creative solutions to conflict.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Business and Management (Master's) program; or permission of BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business.

BUSO731.name: Social Media and Web Analytics
BUSO731.description: Examines the process of developing, implementing, and analyzing strategies for successfully marketing a variety of existing and potential products and services using electronic media. Besides well-established Internet marketing tools such as e-mail, search engines and display advertising, a substantial part of the course is dedicated to understanding social media, analyzing successful social media strategies, and tracking their effectiveness. The course offers hands-on experience with many popular as well as emerging techniques unique to electronic media. Special attention is given to metrics appropriate for the new media.

relationships.prereqs: BUSM612; or BUSO612; or BUSI650.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Business and Management (Master's) program; or permission of BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business.

BUSO751.name: Supply Chain Risk Management
BUSO751.description: Supply chain managers are facing an increasingly volatile operating environment, with constant danger of trading community disruption from business, social and environmental risks. Students are provided with a working knowledge of both the core techniques of supply chain risk assessment and mitigation; as well as best practices in establishing formal corporate supply chain risk management programs. A semester-long X-Treme Supply Chain Simulation will enable students to gain hands-on experience in navigating a computer company through a complex and risky four quarters of global business operations.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Business and Management (Master's) program; or permission of BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business.

BUSO758A.name: Special Topics in Business; Marketing Analytics

BUSO758G.name: Special Topics in Business; Financial Restructuring

BUSO782.name: Financial Planning and Control Systems for Managers and Consultants
BUSO782.description: This course provides an analysis of several topics concerning financial planning/control systems (management accounting systems). Topics covered: design and use of cost management systems (including activity based costing systems), financial performance measures for enhancing firm value, managerial incentive contracts and accounting data, management accounting and Internet-based transactions, managing earnings and financial ratios, use of balanced scorecard to evaluate financial/nonfinancial managerial performance, management accounting systems and competitor analysis, behavioral aspects of budgeting, post-auditing of capital investments, accounting/economics aspects of information security, and transfer pricing.

relationships.prereqs: Permission of BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Business and Management (Master's) program; or permission of BMGT-Robert H.
relationships.additional_info: Smith School of Business. Or BUSO616; and BUSO602.   Smith School of Business.

BUSO788B.name: Business Consulting; Doing Business in Brazil

BUSO788G.name: Business Consulting; Doing Business in India

BUSO788J.name: Business Consulting; Doing Business in South Africa

BUSO788W.name: Business Consulting; Doing Business in Asia: Supply Chain Challenges and Opportunities in Asia

CBMG626.name: Quantitative Modeling for Experimental Biologists
CBMG626.description: A toolkit for understanding processes through the generation of useful models constrained by data. Topics explored include Simulations, Information Theory, Dynamical Systems, and Control Theory.

relationships.prereqs: BIOL705; or permission of the instructor .
relationships.additional_info: Recommended: Some familiarity with programming (NetLogo, R and/or Python) is helpful.

CBMG688A.name: Special Topics in Cell Biology and Molecular Genetics; Research Experiences

CBMG688C.name: Special Topics in Cell Biology and Molecular Genetics

CBMG688D.name: Special Topics in Cell Biology and Molecular Genetics; Genetics: Cell Biology I - Structure and Function

CBMG688J.name: Special Topics in Cell Biology and Molecular Genetics; Genetics: Immunology and Host Defense

CBMG688K.name: Special Topics in Cell Biology and Molecular Genetics; Genetics: Molecular Virology

CBMG688P.name: Special Topics in Cell Biology and Molecular Genetics; Programming for Biology

CBMG688W.name: Special Topics in Cell Biology and Molecular Genetics; Principles of Microscopy

CBMG699.name: Special Problems in Cell Biology and Molecular Genetics

CBMG699D.name: Special Problems in Cell Biology and Molecular Genetics; Molecular Genetics: Bioinformatics and Computation Biology
CBMG699D.description: Contact department or instructor for details.

CBMG699K.name: Special Problems in Cell Biology and Molecular Genetics; Biological Sciences Teaching and Learning in Higher Education
CBMG699K.description: Cross-listed with BIOL608K, CHEM608K, and ENTM699K. Credit will be grant edfor only one of the following: BIOL608K, CBMG699K, CHEM608K, or   ENTM699K.

CBMG699X.name: Special Problems in Cell Biology and Molecular Genetics; Host Pathogen Interactions

CBMG699Z.name: Special Problems in Cell Biology and Molecular Genetics; Protein Translation

CCJS100.name: Introduction to Criminal Justice
CCJS100.description: Introduction to the administration of criminal justice in a democratic society, with emphasis on the theoretical and historical development of law enforcement. The principles of organization and administration for law enforcement; functions and specific activities; planning and research; public relations; personnel and training; inspection and control; direction; policy formulation.

CCJS105.name: Introduction to Criminology
CCJS105.description: Criminal behavior and the methods of its study; causation; typologies of criminal acts and offenders; punishment, correction and incapacitation; prevention of crime.

CCJS200.name: Statistics for Criminology and Criminal Justice
CCJS200.description: Introduction to descriptive and inferential statistics, graphical techniques, and the computer analysis of criminology and criminal justice data. Basic procedures of hypothesis testing, correlation and regression analysis, and the analysis of continuous and binary dependent variables. Emphasis upon the examination of research problems and issues in criminology and criminal justice.

relationships.prereqs: CCJS100 or CCJS105; and 1 course with a minimum grade of C- from (STAT100, MATH107, MATH111, MATH120, MATH130, MATH135, MATH140).
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Criminology and Criminal Justice program; or permission of BSOS-Criminology & Criminal Justice department.

CCJS225.name: Responses to Violence
CCJS225.description: Conflict is unfortunately resolved through violence in a number of settings. It ranges from interpersonal to international in its scope. This course investigates the strengths and weakness of a number of resolutions to reducing violence over the course of history using both state centered and informal control.

CCJS230.name: Criminal Law in Action
CCJS230.description: Law as one of the methods of social control. Criminal law: its nature, sources and types; theories and historical developments. Behavioral and legal aspects of criminal acts. Classification and analysis of selected criminal offenses.

relationships.prereqs: CCJS100.

CCJS300.name: Criminological and Criminal Justice Research Methods
CCJS300.description: Introduction to the formulation of research questions covering crime and justice, research designs, data collection, and interpretation and reporting in criminological and justice-system settings.

relationships.prereqs: CCJS100 and CCJS105; and (PSYC200, CCJS200, ECON321, BMGT230, or SOCY201).

CCJS301.name: Fundamentals in Criminal Justice
CCJS301.description: Provides an overview of the three major components of the American criminal justice system: police, courts, and corrections. Each component will be explored in its development over time as well as various issues surrounding each component. This course will also cover important issues that are relevant to current debates including race, reentry, technology and crime, juvenile justice, and future directions for criminal justice.

relationships.restrictions: Must be enrolled at The Universities at Shady Grove; and must be in the Criminal Justice minor; or by permission of department; and must not be in the Criminology and Criminal Justice major.

CCJS310.name: Criminal Investigations
CCJS310.description: An introduction to modern methods used in detection, investigation, and solution of crime. Students will be taught basic and advanced investigative techniques utilized by law enforcement agencies. Analysis of actual cases will be used to demonstrate practical uses of these techniques.

relationships.prereqs: CCJS100 and CCJS230.

CCJS318C.name: Special Topics in Criminology & Criminal Justice; Public Speaking for Criminal Justice Professionals

relationships.restrictions: Must be a major within the BSOS-Criminology & Criminal Justice department.

CCJS318E.name: Special Topics in Criminology & Criminal Justice; The Hostage Negotiator: Crisis Communication Skills

CCJS318G.name: Special Topics in Criminology & Criminal Justice; Introduction to Forensic Science

CCJS320.name: Introduction to Criminalistics
CCJS320.description: An introduction to modern methods used in the detection, investigation and solution of crimes. Practical analysis of evidence in a crime laboratory, including fingerprints and other impressions, firearms ID and ballistics, hairs and fibers, document examination, and use of polygraph.

relationships.prereqs: CCJS100 and CCJS230.
relationships.additional_info: Students must pay a $53.00 lab fee.

CCJS325.name: Slavery in the Twenty First Century: Combating Human Trafficking
CCJS325.description: The trafficking of human beings in its historical, legal, economic, political and social contexts. Scope of the global problem, different forms of human trafficking, and regional trends and practices. Roles of government, the international community and individual actors. Strategies to combat trafficking.

CCJS330.name: Contemporary Criminological Issues
CCJS330.description: Topics may include career criminals, prison overcrowding, prediction, ecological studies of crimes, family and delinquency, entrepreneurship in criminal justice and criminology, and similar criminological problems.

relationships.prereqs: CCJS100 and CCJS105.

CCJS332.name: Major Transitions: From Undergraduate to Professional
CCJS332.description: This course is designed to assist criminology and criminal justice students explore career opportunities. Topics will include: graduate school, law school, career opportunities in federal, state, local, and public agencies, resume writing, and internships.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Criminology and Criminal Justice program; and sophomore standing or higher.

CCJS340.name: Policing
CCJS340.description: Critical issues relating to policing. Topics include police discretion, role of police, use of force, misconduct, police research, administration, personnel, and etc.

relationships.prereqs: CCJS100.

CCJS342.name: Corrections
CCJS342.description: Examination of the American correctional system.  Identification of historical and contemporary themes, issues, and trends.  Evaluation of correctional policies,  practices and research.

relationships.prereqs: CCJS100.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major within the BSOS-Criminology & Criminal Justice department.

CCJS345.name: Courts and Sentencing
CCJS345.description: Contemporary issues in the American court system such as prosecution, sentencing and punishment.  Theoretical perspectives on courtroom decision-making integrated with empirical research. Courts and sentencing processes, including initial charging, pretrial detention and final sentencing outcomes. Innovations in courts and sentencing.

relationships.prereqs: CCJS100.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major within the BSOS-Criminology & Criminal Justice department.

CCJS352.name: Drugs and Crime
CCJS352.description: An analysis of the role of criminal justice in the control of drug use and abuse.

relationships.prereqs: CCJS100.

CCJS359.name: Field Training in Criminology and Corrections
CCJS359.description: Prerequisites: CCJS 105 or CRIM 220; and CCJS 350 or CRIM 450; and permission of department. For majors only.

CCJS360.name: Victimology
CCJS360.description: Overview of the history and theory of victimology.  Analysis of victimization patterns with special emphasis on types of victims and crimes. The interaction between victims of crime and the criminal justice system with respect to the role of the victim and the services offered to the victim.

relationships.prereqs: CCJS105.

CCJS370.name: Race, Crime and Criminal Justice
CCJS370.description: Role and treatment of racial/ethnic minorities in the criminal justice system. Course will provide students with historical and theoretical framework for understanding this dynamic.

relationships.prereqs: CCJS100.

CCJS386.name: Experiential Learning
CCJS386.description: Restriction: Permission of BSOS-Criminology & Criminal Justice department; and junior standing or higher.

CCJS388H.name: Independent Reading Course in Criminology and Criminal Justice

CCJS389H.name: Independent Research in Criminology and Criminal Justice

relationships.prereqs: junior standing.

CCJS399.name: Independent Study in Criminology and Criminal Justice

relationships.prereqs: written consent of faculty under whose direction the study is to be performed, and at least twelve hours of CCJS credits.

CCJS418C.name: Seminar in Criminology and Criminal Justice; Gender and Crime

CCJS418D.name: Seminar in Criminology and Criminal Justice; Evolving Legal Issues

relationships.prereqs: CCJS100 and CCJS230.

CCJS418E.name: Seminar in Criminology and Criminal Justice; Applications of Data Science in Criminology

relationships.prereqs: CCJS100, CCJS105, CCJS200 and CCJS300.
relationships.restrictions: Permission of department.

CCJS418P.name: Seminar in Criminology and Criminal Justice; Marijuana, Law and Society

CCJS418Q.name: Seminar in Criminology and Criminal Justice; Crime and Place

relationships.prereqs: CCJS100, CCJS105, and CCJS300.

CCJS440.name: Security Administration
CCJS440.description: Designed to introduce students to the complex issues of Security Administration and the critical terrorism issues facing the nation. Emphasis is placed on understanding the historical and contemporary issues effecting U.S. Counterterrorism Policy. It also explores the challenges facing today's security administrators including: ethics, classified information, intelligence, terrorist organizations and incidents, physical and personnel security, transportation and border security issues.

relationships.prereqs: CCJS100 and CCJS340.

CCJS450.name: Advanced Juvenile Delinquency
CCJS450.description: Examination of juvenile delinquency in the United States. Nature and extent of juvenile delinquency, historical approaches, sociological and criminological theories and research, social contexts including the institutions of families, schools, and peers, and social responses. Prevention, punishment, and treatment programs, both within and outside of the juvenile justice and criminal justice systems.

relationships.prereqs: CCJS105 and CCJS300.

CCJS451.name: Crime and Delinquency Prevention
CCJS451.description: Methods and programs in prevention of crime and delinquency.

relationships.prereqs: CCJS105 and CCJS300.

CCJS453.name: White Collar and Organized Crime
CCJS453.description: Definition, detection, prosecution, sentencing and impact of white collar and organized crime. Special consideration given to the role of federal law and enforcement practices.

relationships.prereqs: CCJS300; and (CCJS350 or CCJS105).

CCJS454.name: Contemporary Criminological Theory
CCJS454.description: Examination of the main theoretical accounts that explain the underlying causes of criminal behaviors. Explore how individual choices, socialization experiences, biological factors and social structure affect criminal behaviors.

relationships.prereqs: CCJS300 and CCJS105.

CCJS461.name: Psychology of Criminal Behavior
CCJS461.description: Biological, environmental, and personality factors which influence criminal behaviors. Biophysiology and crime, stress and crime, maladjustment patterns, psychoses, personality disorders, aggression and violent crime, sex-motivated crime and sexual deviations, alcohol and drug abuse, and criminal behavior.

relationships.prereqs: CCJS105 and CCJS300.

CCJS498I.name: Selected Topics in Criminology and Criminal Justice; Digital Forensics

CCJS498K.name: Selected Topics in Criminology and Criminal Justice; Child Abuse Investigations

CCJS498L.name: Selected Topics in Criminology and Criminal Justice; Ethics in Criminal Justice

CCJS498N.name: Selected Topics in Criminology and Criminal Justice; Community Policing

CCJS498P.name: Selected Topics in Criminology and Criminal Justice; Truth and Justice in the Disinformation Era

CCJS498V.name: Selected Topics in Criminology and Criminal Justice; Use of Force

CCJS498X.name: Selected Topics in Criminology and Criminal Justice; Forensic Investigations in the Criminal Justice System

CCJS498Z.name: Selected Topics in Criminology and Criminal Justice; A Matter of Life and Death: Criminal Sentencing Issues

CCJS600.name: Criminal Justice
CCJS600.description: Current concept of criminal justice in relationship to other concepts in the field. Historical perspective. Criminal justice and social control. Operational implications. Systemic aspects. Issues of evaluation.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in one of the following programs (Criminology and Criminal Justice (Master's); Criminology and Criminal Justice (Doctoral)) ; or permission of BSOS-Criminology & Criminal Justice department.

CCJS604.name: Policy Analysis Project
CCJS604.description: An application of statistical and conceptual tools to criminal justice data in the student's area of concentration, resulting in a paper reporting the conceptualization, analytic methods and results. The topic of the independent study will be chosen through individual consultation with the instructor.

CCJS620.name: Fundamentals of Criminological Research
CCJS620.description: Designed to help criminology students understand and apply three important components of statistics: decriptive statistics (including probability theory), fundamentals of statistical inference, and regression analysis. Course assumes familiarity with basic descriptive statistics. The emphasis of the classes on descriptive statistics is the calculation and interpretation of summary statistical measures for describing raw data. Covers the basic rules of probability and different probabilistic processes that could describe criminal activity. The sessions on fundamentals of statistical inferences are designed to provide background for executing and interpreting hypothesis tests and confidence intervals. The latter portion of the course focuses on regession analysis. Uses the statistical software, Stata.

CCJS631.name: Ethics in Criminal Justice
CCJS631.description: Provides students with an overview of the major ethical perspectives, which are typically used to inform and justify the workings of the criminal justice system. The course draws on a number of case studies in order to introduce students to a broad range of ethical dilemmas, and students develop and hone a decision-making process designed to resolve such dilemmas.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in one of the following programs: Criminology and Criminal Justice (Master's); Criminology and Criminal Justice (Doctoral); Sociology (Master's); Sociology (Doctoral); or permission from BSOS-Criminology & Criminal Justice department.

CCJS632.name: Making Sense of Criminal Justice Methods and Statistics
CCJS632.description: Teaches students how to better understand research that relies on statistics and to then apply this understanding to common criminal justice problems. The course will introduce basic statistical concepts that are necessary for analyzing crime and evaluating criminal justice programs and policies. Students will learn to interpret and assess the quality of reports that present crime trends, descriptive statistics, correlations, data mining efforts, geo-spatial and social media analytics, risk analysis for repeat offenders, hot spots of crime, and experimental research. By the end of the semester, students will learn to assess critically the quality of published research and evaluate its implications for criminal justice policy.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in one of the following programs: Criminology and Criminal Justice (Master's); Criminology and Criminal Justice (Doctoral); Sociology (Master's); Sociology (Doctoral); Master of Professional Studies in Public Safety Leadership and Administration (MPLA); Graduate Certificate in Criminal Justice Administration (Z130); or permission from BSOS-Criminology & Criminal Justice department.

CCJS650.name: Research Practicum
CCJS650.description: Provides the opportunity for students to develop and complete a research project, which will provide information on research proficiency for the determination of advancement to doctoral candidacy

CCJS652.name: Seminar in Juvenile Delinquency
CCJS652.description: Analysis of delinquency and its control.

CCJS654.name: History of Criminological Thought
CCJS654.description: A study of the development of criminological thought from antiquity to the present.

relationships.prereqs: CCJS454; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

CCJS670.name: Race, Crime, and Criminal Justice
CCJS670.description: Provides an historical overview of the operation and evolution of the criminal justice system and the impact of race. How race affects definitions of crime and criminality, the workings of the criminal justice system, the development of criminological theory, and the role of criminal justice ethics in the study of race and crime will be considered.

CCJS710.name: Advanced Statistics Methods - Limited Dependent Variables
CCJS710.description: Application of advanced data analysis strategies to criminological and criminal justice problems, with specific focus on limited dependent variables.

relationships.prereqs: Must have completed an approved doctoral level statistics course.

CCJS720.name: Criminal Justice System Planning: Policy Analysis for Crime Control
CCJS720.description: System theory and method; examination of planning methods and models based primarily on a systems approach to the operations of the criminal justice system.

relationships.prereqs: Must have completed 1 course in research methodology; and 1 course in CCJS.

CHBE100.name: Exploring ChBE
CHBE100.description: Overview of the specializations and career paths available in chemical and biomolecular engineering. Academic planning, policies and resources will be covered including introduction to undergraduate research, study abroad, internship and co-op opportunities as well as chemical engineering student groups. A peer mentoring program will enable students to interact with successful upper-class chemical engineering students and build their chemical engineering peer network.

relationships.prereqs: Permission of instructor; and permission of ENGR-Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering department.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major within the ENGR-Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering department.

CHBE250.name: Computer Methods in Chemical Engineering
CHBE250.description: Algorithm development and application of software to the analysis of chemical engineering problems. File management and editing, graphics and numerical methods. Use of spreadsheets, statistics/math software and process simulators for the design of chemical process equipment.

relationships.prereqs: CHBE101; and must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in MATH241.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major within the ENGR-Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering department.

CHBE301.name: Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering Thermodynamics I
CHBE301.description: Principles of thermodynamics and their application to engineering problems. First and second laws of thermodynamics, properties of gases, liquids and solids, phase equilibrium, flow and non-flow systems, energy conversion, production of work from heat, thermodynamic analysis of processes, equilibrium stage operations and the thermodynamics of chemically reacting systems.

relationships.prereqs: CHBE101; and must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in CHBE250 and MATH241.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Engineering: Chemical program; and permission of ENGR-Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering department.

CHBE333.name: Chemical Engineering Seminar
CHBE333.description: To develop oral communication skills through a series of class presentations of current chemical engineering topics.

relationships.restrictions: Junior standing; and must be in a major within ENGR-Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering department; and permission of ENGR-Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering department.

CHBE410.name: Statistics and Design of Experiments
CHBE410.description: An introduction to probability, statistics, and design of experiments for chemical engineers.

relationships.prereqs: Minimum grade of C- in CHBE250, MATH241, and MATH246.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major within the ENGR-Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering department; and permission of ENGR-Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering department.

CHBE422.name: Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering Transport Phenomena I
CHBE422.description: Principals of fluid dynamics as applied to model development and process design. Mass, momentum and energy conservation. Statics and surface tension. Equation of Continuity and Navier-Stokes Equation with application to laminar flow. Dimensional analysis. Macroscopic balances, Bernoulli Equation and friction factors with application to turbulent flow.

relationships.prereqs: Minimum grade of C- in CHBE101, CHBE250, MATH241, and MATH246.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major within the ENGR-Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering department; and permission of ENGR-Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering department.

CHBE437.name: Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering Laboratory
CHBE437.description: Application of chemical engineering process and unit operation principals in small-scale semi-commercial equipment. Data from experimental observations are used to evaluate performance and efficiency of operations. Emphasis on correct presentation of results inreport form.

relationships.prereqs: CHBE424, CHBE426, and CHBE440.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major within ENGR-Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering department; and permission of ENGR-Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering department.

CHBE440.name: Chemical Kinetics and Reactor Design
CHBE440.description: Fundamentals of chemical reaction kinetics and their application to the design and operation of chemical reactors. Reaction rate theory, homogeneous reactions and catalysis electrochemical reactions. Catalytic reactor design.

relationships.prereqs: Minimum grade of C- in CHBE301, MATH241, and MATH246.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Engineering: Chemical program; and permission of ENGR-Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering department.

CHBE442.name: Chemical and Biomolecular Systems Analysis
CHBE442.description: Dynamic response applied to process systems. Goals and modes of control, Laplace transformations, analysis and synthesis of simple control systems, closed loop response, dynamic testing.

relationships.prereqs: CHBE424 and CHBE426.

CHBE444.name: Process Engineering Economics and Design I
CHBE444.description: Principles of chemical engineering economics and process design. Equipment sizing and costing. Economic evaluation of projects. Flowsheet synthesis. Introduction to flowsheet simulators and concepts of flowsheet optimization. Synthesis of Heat Exchanger Networks and Distillation Sequences.

relationships.prereqs: CHBE424, CHBE426, and CHBE440.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major within the ENGR-Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering department; and permission of ENGR-Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering department.

CHBE452.name: Introduction of Machine Learning in Chemical Engineering
CHBE452.description: Introduction of data science and machine learning approaches to modern problems in chemical engineering and materials science. This course develops data science approaches, including their foundational mathematical and statistical basis, and applies these methods to data sets of limited size and precision. Methods for regression and clustering will be developed and applied, with an emphasis on validation and error quantification. Techniques that will be developed include linear and nonlinear regression, clustering and logistic regression, dimensionality reduction, unsupervised learning, and artificial neural networks. These methods will be applied to a range of engineering problems, including conducting polymers, stretchable conductors, organic synthesis, and quality control in manufacturing.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of Department or Instructor.
relationships.additional_info: Recommended:  Basic knowledge of chemical engineering, materials science, ordinary differential equations, and Python is desirable.  Jointly offered with: CHBE652.

CHBE472.name: Control of Air Pollution Sources
CHBE472.description: Sources and effects of air pollutants, regulatory trends, atmospheric dispersion models, fundamentals of two-phase flow as applied to air pollution and air pollution control systems, design of systems for control of gases and particulate matter.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of ENGR-Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering department.
relationships.additional_info: Jointly offered with: CHBE672.

CHBE473.name: Electrochemical Energy Engineering
CHBE473.description: The lecture will start from the basic electrochemical thermodynamics and kinetics, with emphasis on electrochemical techniques, fundamental principle and performance of batteries, and supercapacitors.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of ENGR-Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering department.
relationships.additional_info: Jointly offered with: CHBE673.

CHBE474.name: Biopharmaceutical Process Development and Manufacturing
CHBE474.description: Covers the fundamental steps involved in process development and manufacturing of biopharmaceuticals. An overview of different classes of biopharmaceuticals as well as manufacturing requirements for clinical development and regulatory approval will be provided. In depth coverage of manufacturing steps including cell culture, purification and formulation as well as drug product manufacturing, analysis and stability will be covered. Scientific literature will be used to highlight current challenges and novel solutions in each step of the manufacturing process. Scale up considerations, GMP requirements and process economics will also be introduced.

relationships.prereqs: BIOE120; and permission of instructor.
relationships.restrictions: Permission of ENGR-Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering department.
relationships.additional_info: Jointly offered with: CHBE674.

CHBE486.name: Heterogeneous Catalysis for Energy Applications
CHBE486.description: Introduction to heterogeneous catalytic science and technology for energy conversion and hydocarbon processing. Preparation and mechanistic characterization of catalyst systems, kinetics of catalyzed reactions, adsorption and diffusion influences in heterogenious reactions. An overview of heterogeneous catalysis in various energy-related applications, including petroleum refining, chemicals from biomass, valorization of shale gas, and CO2 utilization will be introduced.

relationships.prereqs: Minimum grade of C- in CHBE302, CHBE424, and CHBE440; and permission of instructor.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major within the ENGR-Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering department.

CHBE493.name: Chemical Processes in Beer Brewing
CHBE493.description: Covers chemical engineering principles and chemical processes involved in the brewing and quality control of beer. Topics will include extraction and isomerization of bittering compounds from hops, enzymatic reactions involved in mashing beer, colloidal chemistry of haze formation, and microbiology of yeast and fermentation. Quantitative models will be applied to these processes based on fundamental chemical engineering principles from reaction kinetics, thermodynamics, transport phenomena, and colloid and interfacial science.

relationships.prereqs: Minimum grade of C- in CHBE424 and CHBE440; and permission of instructor.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major within the ENGR-Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering department; and permission of ENGR- & Biomolecular Engineering department.
relationships.additional_info: Neither the students nor the instructor will not be making or working with alcoholic beverages in the course.

CHBE494.name: Sustainable Separations and Carbon Capture
CHBE494.description: Provides a comprehensive overview of sustainable separations and carbon dioxide capture using synthetic membranes and sorbents.

relationships.prereqs: Minimum grade of C- in CHBE424, CHBE426 and CHBE440; and permission of instructor.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major within the ENGR-Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering department; and must have permission of ENGR- & Biomolecular Engineering department.

CHBE610.name: Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics
CHBE610.description: Advanced application of the general thermodynamic methods to chemical engineering problems. First and second law consequences; estimation and correlation of thermodynamic properties; phase and chemical reaction equilibria.

relationships.prereqs: CHBE301; and CHBE302.
relationships.restrictions: Permission of ENGR-Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering department.
relationships.additional_info: Or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

CHBE620.name: Methods of Engineering Analysis
CHBE620.description: Application of selected mathematical techniques to the analysis and solution of engineering problems; included are the applications of matrices, vectors, tensors, differential equations, integral transforms, and probability methods to such problems as unsteady heat transfer, transient phenomena in mass transfer operations, stagewise processes, chemical reactors, process control, and nuclear reactor physics.

relationships.prereqs: MATH246 and CHBE250; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

CHBE652.name: Introduction of Machine Learning in Chemical Engineering
CHBE652.description: Introduction of data science and machine learning approaches to modern problems in chemical engineering and materials science. This course develops data science approaches, including their foundational mathematical and statistical basis, and applies these methods to data sets of limited size and precision. Methods for regression and clustering will be developed and applied, with an emphasis on validation and error quantification. Techniques that will be developed include linear and nonlinear regression, clustering and logistic regression, dimensionality reduction, unsupervised learning, and artificial neural networks. These methods will be applied to a range of engineering problems, including conducting polymers, stretchable conductors, organic synthesis, and quality control in manufacturing.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of Department or Instructor.
relationships.additional_info: Recommended: Basic knowledge of chemical engineering, materials science, ordinary differential equations, and Python is desirable.  Jointly offered with: CHBE452.

CHBE672.name: Control of Air Pollution Sources
CHBE672.description: Sources and effects of air pollutants, regulatory trends, atmospheric dispersion models, fundamentals of two-phase flow as applied to air pollution and air pollution control systems, design of systems for control of gases and particulate matter.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of ENGR-Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering department.
relationships.additional_info: Jointly offered with: CHBE472.

CHBE686.name: Advanced Heterogeneous Catalysis for Energy Applications
CHBE686.description: Introduction to heterogeneous catalytic science and technology for energy conversion and hydocarbon processing. Preparation and mechanistic characterization of catalyst systems, kinetics of catalyzed reactions, adsorption and diffusion influences in heterogenious reactions. An overview of heterogeneous catalysis in various energy-related applications, including petroleum refining, chemicals from biomass, valorization of shale gas, and CO2 utilization will be introduced.

relationships.prereqs: Minimum grade of C- in CHBE302, CHBE424, and CHBE440; and permission of instructor.
relationships.restrictions: Permission of instructor.
relationships.additional_info: Jointly offered with: CHBE486.

CHBE694.name: Sustainable Separations and Carbon Capture
CHBE694.description: Provides a comprehensive overview of sustainable separations and carbon dioxide capture using synthetic membranes and sorbents.

relationships.prereqs: Minimum grade of C- in CHBE424, CHBE426 and CHBE440; and permission of instructor.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major within the ENGR-Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering department; and must have permission of ENGR- & Biomolecular Engineering department.

CHEM131.name: Chemistry I - Fundamentals of General Chemistry
CHEM131.description: An overview of the Periodic Table, inorganic substances, ionic and covalent bonding, bulk properties of materials, chemical equilibrium, and quantitative chemistry. CHEM131 is the first course in a four-semester sequence for students majoring in the sciences, other than Chemistry and Biochemistry majors.

relationships.prereqs: Must have math eligibility of MATH120 or higher.
relationships.additional_info: Recommended: For Science majors.  Students without the math pre-requisite will be administratively dropped.
relationships.credit_granted_for: CHEM103, CHEM131, CHEM135, CHEM153 or CHEM146.

CHEM131S.name: Chemistry I - Fundamentals of General Chemistry
CHEM131S.description: An overview of the Periodic Table, inorganic substances, ionic and covalent bonding, bulk properties of materials, chemical equilibrium, and quantitative chemistry. CHEM131 is the first course in a four-semester sequence for students majoring in the sciences, other than Chemistry and Biochemistry majors.

relationships.prereqs: Must have math eligibility of MATH120 or higher.
relationships.additional_info: Recommended: For Science majors.   College Park Scholars - Life Sciences. Students without the math pre-requisite will be administratively dropped.
relationships.credit_granted_for: CHEM103, CHEM131, CHEM135, CHEM153 or CHEM146.

CHEM132.name: General Chemistry I Laboratory
CHEM132.description: Introduction to the quantification of chemical substances, including the concept of the mole and chemical stoichiometry. Additional work involves the synthesis of ionic substances and their qualitative characterization. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM131.

relationships.prereqs: Must have math eligibility of MATH120 or higher.
relationships.additional_info: Laboratory sessions will begin after the first lecture. Students must pay a $40.00 laboratory materials fee.
relationships.credit_granted_for: CHEM103, CHEM132, CHEM136, CHEM143, CHEM147 or CHEM177.

CHEM132C.name: General Chemistry I Laboratory
CHEM132C.description: Introduction to the quantification of chemical substances, including the concept of the mole and chemical stoichiometry. Additional work involves the synthesis of ionic substances and their qualitative characterization. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM131.

relationships.prereqs: Must have math eligibility of MATH120 or higher.
relationships.additional_info: Students must pay a $40.00 laboratory materials fee.
relationships.credit_granted_for: CHEM103, CHEM132, CHEM136, CHEM143, CHEM147 or CHEM177.

CHEM132S.name: General Chemistry I Laboratory
CHEM132S.description: Introduction to the quantification of chemical substances, including the concept of the mole and chemical stoichiometry. Additional work involves the synthesis of ionic substances and their qualitative characterization. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM131.

relationships.prereqs: Must have math eligibility of MATH120 or higher.
relationships.additional_info: College Park - Life Sciences.  Laboratory sessions will begin after the first lecture. Students must pay a $40.00 laboratory materials fee.
relationships.credit_granted_for: CHEM103, CHEM132, CHEM136, CHEM143, CHEM147 or CHEM177.

CHEM134.name: Chemical Principles for Engineering
CHEM134.description: Basic chemistry for engineering students. Introduction to organic structures and polymers, gas laws, liquids, solids, phase changes, chemical kinetics and electrochemistry.

relationships.prereqs: Minimum grade of C- in CHEM131; or minimum grade of C- in CHEM146.

CHEM135.name: General Chemistry for Engineers
CHEM135.description: The nature and composition of matter, solutions, chemical reactions, equilibria, and electrochemistry, with applications to various fields of engineering.

relationships.prereqs: Must have math eligibility of MATH120 or higher.
relationships.credit_granted_for: CHEM103, CHEM113, CHEM131, CHEM135, or CHEM146.

CHEM136.name: General Chemistry Laboratory for Engineers
CHEM136.description: A laboratory course for engineering majors intending to take CHEM231 and CHEM232.

relationships.prereqs: Must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in CHEM135 and must have math eligibility of MATH120 or higher.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major in ENGR-A.
relationships.additional_info: James Clark School of Engineering.Prerequisite: Must have math eligibility of MATH120 or higher. Students must pay a $40.00 laboratory materials fee.

CHEM146.name: Principles of General Chemistry
CHEM146.description: An overview of the Periodic Table, inorganic substances, ionic and covalent bonding, bulk properties of materials, chemical equilibrium, and quantitative chemistry. CHEM146 is the first course in a four-semester sequence for Chemistry and Biochemistry majors.

relationships.prereqs: Must have math eligibility of MATH140 or higher.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in one of the following programs (Chemistry; Biochemistry).
relationships.credit_granted_for: CHEM103, CHEM131, CHEM135, CHEM143, or CHEM146.

CHEM177.name: Introduction to Laboratory Practices and Research in the Chemical Sciences
CHEM177.description: First semester laboratory course required for CHEM and BCHM majors. Introduction to laboratory techniques, including safety practices, scientific ethics, and presentation of current research topics.

relationships.prereqs: Must have math eligibility of MATH120 or higher.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major within CMNS-Chemistry & Biochemistry department; or permission of CMNS-Chemistry & Biochemistry department.
relationships.additional_info: Students must pay a $40.00 laboratory materials fee.

CHEM231.name: Organic Chemistry I
CHEM231.description: The chemistry of carbon: aliphatic compounds, aromatic compounds, stereochemistry, arenes, halides, alcohols, esters and spectroscopy.

relationships.prereqs: CHEM131, CHEM135, or CHEM146; and (CHEM132, CHEM136, CHEM147, or CHEM177); and a grade of C- or better in the prerequisites is required of College of Computer, Mathematical, and Natural Sciences majors and recommended for all students.

CHEM232.name: Organic Chemistry Laboratory I
CHEM232.description: Provides experience in developing some basic laboratory techniques, recrystallization, distillation, extraction, chromatography.

relationships.prereqs: CHEM131 and CHEM132; or (CHEM135 and CHEM136); or (CHEM146 and CHEM147).
relationships.additional_info: And a grade of C- or better in the prerequisites is required for College of Computer, Mathematical, and Natural Sciences majors and recommended for all students.      Laboratory sessions will begin after the first lecture of CHEM 231. Students must pay a $40.00 laboratory materials fee.

CHEM241.name: Organic Chemistry II
CHEM241.description: A continuation of CHEM231 with emphasis on molecular structure; substitution reactions; carbonium ions; aromaticity; synthetic processes; macromolecules.

relationships.prereqs: CHEM231 and CHEM232; or CHEM237.
relationships.additional_info: And a grade of C- or better in the prerequisites is required for College of Computer, Mathematical, and Natural Sciences majors and recommended for all students.

CHEM242.name: Organic Chemistry Laboratory II
CHEM242.description: Synthetic organic chemistry through functional group manipulation, introduction to instrumentation essential to analysis and structure elucidation.

relationships.prereqs: CHEM231 and CHEM232; or CHEM237.
relationships.additional_info: And a grade of C- or better in the prerequisites is required for College of Computer, Mathematical, and Natural Sciences majors and recommended for all students.      Students must pay a $40.00 laboratory materials fee.

CHEM247.name: Principles of Organic Chemistry II
CHEM247.description: A continuation of CHEM237 with emphasis on molecular structure, substitution reactions; carbonium ions; aromaticity; synthetic processes; macromolecules.

relationships.prereqs: Minimum grade of C- in CHEM237; or permission of CMNS-Chemistry & Biochemistry department.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in one of the following programs (Chemistry; Biochemistry) ; or must be an honors student.
relationships.additional_info: Students must pay a $40.00 laboratory materials fee.

CHEM271.name: General Chemistry and Energetics
CHEM271.description: An introduction to the physical aspects of chemistry; chemical kinetics, thermodynamics and electrochemistry in the context of current chemistry research.

relationships.prereqs: CHEM241 and CHEM242; or CHEM247.
relationships.additional_info: And a grade of C- or better in the prerequisites for College of Computer, Mathematical, and Natural Sciences majors and recommended for all students.

CHEM272.name: General Bioanalytical Chemistry Laboratory
CHEM272.description: An introduction to analytical chemistry with an emphasis on bio-analytical instrumentation and techniques.

relationships.prereqs: CHEM241 and CHEM242; or CHEM247.
relationships.additional_info: And a grade of C- or better in the prerequisites is required for College of Computer, Mathematical, and Natural Sciences majors and recommended for all students.    Students must pay a $40.00 laboratory materials fee.

CHEM277.name: Fundamentals of Analytical and Bioanalytical Chemistry Laboratory
CHEM277.description: Quantitative analysis, inorganic analytical chemistry, and an introduction to bio-analytical instrumentation and techniques.

relationships.prereqs: Minimum grade of C- in CHEM241 and CHEM242; or minimum grade of C- in CHEM247.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in one of the following programs (Chemistry; Biochemistry).
relationships.additional_info: Students must pay a $40.00 lab materials fee.

CHEM398.name: Special Projects
CHEM398.description: Limited to chemistry honors students. Consult with Dr. Montague-Smith.

CHEM399X.name: Introduction to Chemical Research; Chemistry Instruction

CHEM403.name: Radiochemistry
CHEM403.description: Radioactive decay; introduction to properties of atomic nuclei; nuclear processes in cosmology; chemical, biomedical and environmental applications of radioactivity; nuclear processes as chemical tools; interaction of radiation with matter.

relationships.prereqs: Must have completed one year of college chemistry and one year of college physics.

CHEM425.name: Instrumental Methods of Analysis
CHEM425.description: Modern instrumentation in analytical chemistry. Electronics, spectroscopy, chromatography and electrochemistry.

relationships.prereqs: CHEM272 and CHEM271; or (CHEM276 and CHEM277).
relationships.additional_info: Students must pay a $40.00 laboratory materials fee.

CHEM441.name: Advanced Organic Chemistry
CHEM441.description: An advanced study of the compounds of carbon, with special emphasis on molecular orbital theory and organic reaction mechanisms.

relationships.prereqs: Must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in CHEM481; and 1 course with a minimum grade of C- from (CHEM241, CHEM247).
relationships.additional_info: Jointly offered with CHEM641.

CHEM460.name: Structure Determination Using Spectroscopic Methods
CHEM460.description: The use of infrared, ultraviolet-visible, proton and carbon-13 nuclear magnetic resonance and mass spectroscopy for structure determination in organic chemistry.

relationships.prereqs: Must have completed CHEM243; or CHEM247; or (CHEM241 and CHEM242).

CHEM481.name: Physical Chemistry I
CHEM481.description: Thermodynamics and kinetics of chemical and molecular systems. Topics may include internal energy, heat, work, enthalpy, entropy, free energy, and spontaneity as well as reaction order, differential rate laws, integrated rate laws, and rate laws for multi-step processes.

relationships.prereqs: Minimum grade of C- in CHEM135; or minimum grade of C- in CHEM271 and CHEM272; or minimum grade of C- in CHEM276 and CHEM277.
relationships.additional_info: And minimum grade of C- in MATH141. And minimum grade of C- in PHYS260 and PHYS261; or minimum grade of C- in PHYS141.

CHEM482.name: Physical Chemistry II
CHEM482.description: Quantum mechanical nature of atoms and molecules. Topics may include model systems for electronic, vibrational, rotational and translational energies as well as connections to molecular spectroscopy and thermal distributions.

relationships.prereqs: Minimum grade of C- in CHEM135; or minimum grade of C- in CHEM271 and CHEM272; or minimum grade of C- in CHEM276 and CHEM277.
relationships.additional_info: And minimum grade of C- in MATH141. And minimum grade of C- in PHYS260 and PHYS261; or minimum grade of C- in PHYS141.

CHEM483.name: Physical Chemistry Laboratory I
CHEM483.description: An introduction to the principles and application of quantitative techniques in physical chemical measurements. Experiments will be coordinated with topics in CHEM481.

relationships.prereqs: Must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in CHEM481.
relationships.additional_info: Students must pay a $40.00 lab materials fee. In-person lab times to be arranged with instructor.

CHEM484.name: Physical Chemistry Laboratory II
CHEM484.description: A continuation of CHEM 483. Advanced quantitative techniques necessary in physical chemical measurements. Experiments will be coordinated with topics in CHEM 482.

relationships.prereqs: CHEM481 and CHEM483; and must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in CHEM482.
relationships.additional_info: Students must pay a $40.00 laboratory materials fee. In-person lab times to be arranged with instructor.

CHEM498B.name: Special Topics in Chemistry; Chemistry of the Elements

CHEM601.name: Structure and Bonding of Molecules and Materials
CHEM601.description: Development of the tools necessary to use the knowledge of structure and bonding of molecules and solids in the practice of synthetic inorganic and materials chemistry. Several bonding models are covered, from the simple valence bond and ligand field models to a quantitative group theoretical treatment of molecular orbital theory and band structure descriptions of solids. Concepts of electron counting and oxidation state and ligand characteristics are revisited in terms of the more sophisticated bonding models. Finally, these models are used to analyze the reactivity, magnetic and spectroscopic properties of inorganic coordination compounds. Prior advanced inorganic and/or advanced quantum chemistry courses are not prerequisites.

CHEM608K.name: Selected Topics in Inorganic Chemistry; Chemistry Teaching and Learning in Higher Education
CHEM608K.description: Cross-listed with BIOL608K, CBMG699K, and ENTM699K. Credit will be grant edfor only one of the following: BIOL608K, CBMG699K, CHEM608K, or   ENTM699K.

CHEM611.name: Professional Skills for New Graduate Students
CHEM611.description: Covers a wide range of topics in professional development for new graduate students.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in one of the following programs (Chemistry (Master's); Biochemistry (Master's); Biochemistry (Doctoral); Chemistry (Doctoral)) ; and must be a new graduate student.

CHEM624.name: Electrical Methods of Quantitative Analysis
CHEM624.description: The use of conductivity, potentiometry, polarography, voltammetry, amperometry, coulometry, and chronopotentiometry in quantitative analysis.

relationships.prereqs: CHEM482; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

CHEM648P.name: Special Topics in Organic Chemistry; Chemical Biology

CHEM682.name: Chemical Kinetics and Dynamics
CHEM682.description: The dynamics of atoms and molecules as they undergo chemical and physical change. Topics will be developed from a fundamental perspective and modern applications will be discussed. Topics include: chemical kinetics rate equations, atomic and molecular collisions; rate theories; atomic, molecular and chemical lasers; control of matter with light.

relationships.prereqs: CHEM482; or permission of instructor.
relationships.restrictions: Restricted to graduate students or advanced undergraduates with prerequisites.

CHEM684.name: Chemical Thermodynamics
CHEM684.description: Prerequisite: CHEM482; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

CHEM699.name: Special Problems in Chemistry
CHEM699.description: Open only to non-thesis Master's degree candidates.

relationships.credit_granted_for: one ofthe following: CHEM889E, CHEM889F, or CHPH709A.
one ofthe following: CHEM889E, CHEM889F, or CHPH709A.

CHIN101.name: Intensive Elementary Chinese I
CHIN101.description: Introduction to speaking, reading, and writing Chinese with an emphasis on mastering the essentials of pronunciation, basic characters and structural patterns.

relationships.prereqs: Must have attained appropriate Foreign Language Placement Test (FLPT) score.

CHIN105.name: Elementary Chinese - Accelerated Track
CHIN105.description: Accelerated instruction in Mandarin Chinese at the elementary level for students with prior Chinese language background, either through home use or formal instruction.

relationships.prereqs: Must have appropriate Foreign Language Placement Test (FLPT) score.
relationships.restrictions: Must not have completed CHIN103, CHIN102, or CHIN101.

CHIN201.name: Intermediate Spoken Chinese I
CHIN201.description: Emphasis on development of conversational skills with vocabulary build-up and controlled conversation.

relationships.prereqs: CHIN102; or must have attained appropriate Foreign Language Placement Test (FLPT) score.
relationships.additional_info: Must be taken in conjunction with CHIN202.

CHIN202.name: Intermediate Written Chinese I
CHIN202.description: Reading and writing skills with emphasis on grammar and Chinese characters.

relationships.prereqs: CHIN103; or must have attained appropriate Foreign Language Placement Test (FLPT) score.
relationships.additional_info: Must be taken in conjunction with CHIN201.

CHIN301.name: Advanced Chinese I
CHIN301.description: Readings in expository and fictional writing with conversation and composition.

relationships.prereqs: CHIN202; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.
relationships.additional_info: And must have taken a placement interview offered by the department for Non-majors.

CHIN305.name: Life in China through TV Plays I
CHIN305.description: Using authentic Chinese language material in short TV plays to learn about society and life in China.

relationships.prereqs: CHIN203 and CHIN204; or permission of ARHU-School of Languages, Literatures, and Cultures department.

CHIN315.name: Modern Chinese Literature in Translation
CHIN315.description: Major works of fiction and drama from 1920 to the present read in the context of social and literary change. Emphasis on western and traditional Chinese influences on the writers and their works. No knowledge of Chinese required.

CHIN331.name: Chinese Calligraphy: Theory and Practice
CHIN331.description: History of the writing system; major scripts, modes, and styles. Intermediate brushwork and lectures on the culture. Characters for practice selected to correspond to lecture topics. Taught in English.

relationships.prereqs: CHIN220; or permission of instructor.

CHIN401.name: Readings in Modern Chinese I
CHIN401.description: Readings in history, politics, economics, sociology, and literature. Emphasis on wide-ranging, rapid reading, reinforced by conversations and compositions.

relationships.prereqs: CHIN302; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.
relationships.additional_info: And must have taken a placement interview offered by the department for Non-majors.

CHIN411.name: Business Chinese I
CHIN411.description: Conversation, reading, and writing applicable to Chinese business transactions, social meetings, and meetings with government organizations, plus background material in English on professional business practices and social customs associated with business.

relationships.prereqs: CHIN402; or permission of ARHU-School of Languages, Literatures, and Cultures department.
relationships.additional_info: And must have taken a placement interview offered by the department for Non-majors.

CHIN418T.name: Special Topics in Contemporary Chinese Fiction and Film; Where Truth Lies: Chinese Cinema between Fact and Fiction
CHIN418T.description: This course explores Chinese/Sinophone films and media that unsettle the boundary between fiction and nonfiction in this class. Course materials under discussion draw on a variety of genres, forms, and approaches: reportage, mockumentary, docudrama, found footage, true crime series, crowd-sourced video remix, filmed reenactments, essay film and ephemeral media of various kinds, etc.

CHIN441.name: Traditional Chinese Fiction
CHIN441.description: Major works of fiction from the 4th century tales of the marvelous through the 19th century Qing novel. Readings are in classical Chinese and English. Designed for students with advanced language skills. Taught in English.

relationships.prereqs: Permission of ARHU-School of Languages, Literatures, and Cultures department.

CHPH709A.name: Seminar in Chemical Physics; Physical Chemistry
CHPH709A.description: Jointly offered with CHEM898E and CHEM898F.

relationships.credit_granted_for: o ne ofthe following: CHEM889E, CHEM889F, or CHPH709A.

CHPH709B.name: Seminar in Chemical Physics; Statistical Physics

CHPH718I.name: Special Topics in Chemical Physics; Chemical Physics Rotation

CHSE200.name: College Success and Life Planning - Managing College and Career Life through Goal Development and Planning
CHSE200.department: Counseling, Higher Education, and Special Education
CHSE200.description: The overarching goal of this course is to guide new students affiliated with the TerpsEXCEED program in navigating the initial stages of college, career and campus life management. The course is organized around Academic and Career Habits, Cultural Know-How, Balance of Multiple Roles, and Self-Direction in order to address (a) skills and interest assessments, (b) goal setting, (c) organizational and independent living skills development, (d) travel and transportation orientation to navigate and access campus and College Park, (e) financial planning, (f) safety, (g) social activity access, and (h) basic scheduling and time management. TerpsEXCEED students will be matched with typical student peer supports for a more normalized college experience.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in the TerpsEXCEED Program; and permission from TerpsEXCEED Director.
relationships.additional_info: Priority enrollment for students in the TerpsEXCEED program.

CHSE205.name: Disability: From Stigma and Sideshow to Mainstream and Main Street
CHSE205.department: Counseling, Higher Education, and Special Education
CHSE205.description: Explores the cultural, historical, educational, and medical roots of difference among human beings and examines the impact of cultural and technological changes on individuals traditionally identified as disabled. The course is designed to develop a broad understanding of the concept of "disability" and the emerging technologies that shape contemporary understanding of this phenomenon and the lives of those considered disabled.

CHSE328C.name: Common Ground Deliberative Dialogues; Civicus
CHSE328C.department: Counseling, Higher Education, and Special Education

CHSE338B.name: Navigating Social Identity Difference through Intergroup Dialogue; Race, Gender, or Socioeconomic Status
CHSE338B.department: Counseling, Higher Education, and Special Education

CHSE338I.name: Navigating Social Identity Difference through Intergroup Dialogue; Religion and Spirituality, Size and Appearance
CHSE338I.department: Counseling, Higher Education, and Special Education

CHSE338L.name: Navigating Social Identity Difference through Intergroup Dialogue; Race, Gender, or Citizenship
CHSE338L.department: Counseling, Higher Education, and Special Education

CINE245.name: Film Form and Culture
CINE245.description: Introduction to film as art form and how films create meaning. Basic film terminology; fundamental principles of film form, film narrative, and film history. Examination of film technique and style over past one hundred years. Social and economic functions of film within broader institutional, economic, and cultural contexts.

relationships.additional_info: Cross-listed with: ENGL245.

CINE280.name: Film Art in a Global Society
CINE280.description: Comparative study of a variety of film traditions from around the world, including cinema from Hollywood, Europe, Asia and developing countries, with a stress on different cultural contexts for film-making and viewing.

relationships.additional_info: Cross-listed with: CMLT280.

CINE283.name: Iranian Cinema
CINE283.description: Introduction to Iranian cinema, society, and culture. Taught in English.

relationships.additional_info: Cross-listed with: PERS283.

CINE301.name: Cinema History I: The Silent Era
CINE301.description: Examines the development of silent cinema from the 1890s to the early 1930s drawing on at least five distinct national traditions (French, German, Russian, British, and American). Introduces students to key cinematic conventions as they emerged around the world.

relationships.prereqs: ENGL245, CINE245, or FILM245; or permission of ARHU-College of Arts & Humanities.

CINE319A.name: Special Topics in Documentary, Animation, Experimental Cinema, and Other Visual Media; David Bowie, Film, and Audio-Visual Media

relationships.prereqs: ENGL245, FILM245, CINE245, FILM283, or SLLC283; or permission of instructor.

CINE319C.name: Special Topics in Documentary, Animation, Experimental Cinema, and Other Visual Media; Images of Revolt: Strike, Riot, Uprising

CINE319M.name: Special Topics in Documentary, Animation, Experimental Cinema, and Other Visual Media; Introduction to Filmmaking
CINE319M.description: This practice-based course offers an introduction to the foundational skills, techniques, and principles of filmmaking. Prior film or video production experience is not necessary.

CINE329T.name: Special Topics in National/International Cinemas; Sports in Film

CINE337.name: Contemporary Chinese Art and Film
CINE337.description: Contemporary Chinese art and film are arguably the most vibrant of all national arts at the turn of the millennium and have become the face - both figuratively and literally - of contemporary China, a complex society with historic overlays of Confucianism, Taoism, Buddhism, Communism, Post-socialism, and state capitalism. Students will consider a wide range of art forms (painting, photography, video, installation, web-based media, and film) in four broad themes (uses of the past; critiques of power; representations of race, gender, and sexuality; socially engaged art) and explore the complex intertwining of the political, historical, and aesthetic aspects in Chinese contemporary art and film, as well as the multiple contexts in which these artworks are created and circulated.

relationships.additional_info: Cross-listed with: ARTH392, FILM329L.

CINE344.name: Film and the Fantastic
CINE344.description: Survey of fantastic cinema, encompassing American classics, Hollywood recent productions, and independent films, as well as Asian horror films, anime, and European fantasy.

relationships.prereqs: ENGL245, FILM245, or CINE245; or permission of ARHU-School of Languages, Literatures, and Cultures department.
relationships.additional_info: Cross-listed with: SLLC344.  Prerequisite: ENGL245, FILM245, CINE245, SLLC283, or FILM283; or permission of instructor.  Credit granted for ENGL329I or CINE344.

CINE345.name: The Films of Alfred Hitchcock
CINE345.description: An examination of important Hitchcock films from the perspective of innovation, aesthetics, and cultural history.

relationships.prereqs: ENGL245, FILM245, or CINE245; or permission of ARHU-College of Arts & Humanities.
relationships.additional_info: Prerequisite: ENGL245, FILM245, or CINE245; or permission of ARHU- College of Arts & Humanities.   Credit only granted for FILM345, CINE345 or ENGL329J.

CINE359C.name: Special Topics in Genres/Auteurs/Cinema Movements; Disaster Cinema
CINE359C.description: Exploration of disaster films in Hollywood and global cinema during the past century. The course will examine disaster films, such as Godzilla, King Kong, and Contagion, as a form of cinema's critical encounter with war, colonialism, and scientific development.

CINE359O.name: Special Topics in Genres/Auteurs/Cinema Movements; New Wave Cinemas of the Soviet Bloc

CINE369N.name: Special Topics in Film Theories; Voice, Music, Sound

CINE369P.name: Special Topics in Film Theories; Paranoia and Conspiracy Narrative in Contemporary Cinema

CINE388.name: Experiential Learning: Cinema and Media Studies

CINE411.name: Experimental Film
CINE411.description: Introductory survey of European and U.S. American experimental cinema.

relationships.additional_info: Cross-listed with: SLLC411.

CINE423.name: Women and French Cinema
CINE423.description: Cultural identity, social boundaries and gender roles in French film as well as introduction to film textual analysis and diverse film theories (semiotics, film and psychoanalysis, feminist film theory, structuralism, narratology, spectatorship and cultural studies). Taught in French.

relationships.additional_info: Cross-listed with: FREN423.

CINE429D.name: Special Topics in National/International Cinemas; Representation of Identity in Haitian Popular Cinema
CINE429D.description: This course will provide a nuanced understanding of Haiti and the Haitian diaspora by viewing popular Haitian films. Among the issues we will consider are the ways in which identity is negotiated through the lenses of class, language, im/migration, gender, and colorism.

CINE429F.name: Special Topics in National/International Cinemas; Where Truth Lies: Chinese Cinema between Fact and Fiction
CINE429F.description: Cross-listed with CHIN418T.  This course explores Chinese/Sinophone films and media that unsettle the boundary between fiction and nonfiction in this class. Course materials under discussion draw on a variety of genres, forms, and approaches: reportage, mockumentary, docudrama, found footage, true crime series, crowd-sourced video remix, filmed reenactments, essay film and ephemeral media of various kinds, etc.

CINE429N.name: Special Topics in National/International Cinemas; New German Cinema

CINE441.name: Italian Cinema I: Neorealism
CINE441.description: Explores representations of Italy in cinema with special focus on identity formation and the movement of Italian neorealism and post neorealism. Taught in English.

relationships.additional_info: Cross-listed with: ITAL436.

CINE459L.name: Special Topics in Genres/Auteurs/Cinema Movements; The Transnational Cinema of Ang Lee
CINE459L.description: Cross-listed with ARTH489L and WGSS498K.  Students will examine how the award-winning director Ang Lee has been able to explore important issues of culture, gender, race, identity, and values across borders in a transnational world. Films to be studied are from a wide spectrum of genres and may include "The Wedding Banquet," "Sense and Sensibility," "The Ice Storm," "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon," "Hulk," "Brokeback Mountain," "The Life of Pi," and "Gemini Man."

CINE499.name: Directed Study in Cinema and Media Studies

CLAS170.name: Ancient Myths and Modern Lives
CLAS170.description: What are myths and why do we tell them? What powers do myths have? We will tackle these questions by looking at the enduring and fascinating myths from ancient Greece and Rome. In addition to studying how they shaped ancient societies, we will also look at their modern influence and reflect upon the power that myths still hold in our contemporary world. Taught in English.

relationships.additional_info: This course cannot be taken for language credit. Cross-listed with: RELS170.

CLAS190.name: Discovering the World of Ancient Rome
CLAS190.description: An exploration of the cultural traits and developments of ancient Roman civilization from its roots in Etruscan culture, through the rise of the Roman Republic, to the expansion of Roman cultural influence in the ancient world and the emergence of the Roman Empire. Drawing upon the evidence of the archaeological remains as well as ancient historical and literary documents, students gain a basic familiarity with the principal monuments and artifacts of ancient Roman civilization, the various institutions and values that characterized the Romans, and the significant historical events that transformed the culture over the course of antiquity.

relationships.additional_info: Cross-listed with: HIST219T.

CLAS274.name: What is Romance?
