MATH602.description: Projective and injective modules, homological dimensions, derived functors, spectral sequence of a composite functor. Applications.

relationships.prereqs: MATH600.

MATH606.name: Algebraic Geometry I
MATH606.description: Prime and primary ideals in Noetherian rings, Hilbert nullstellensatz, places and valuations, prevarieties (in the sense of Serre), dimension, morphisms, singularities, varieties, schemes, rationality.

relationships.prereqs: MATH600 and MATH601.

MATH621.name: Algebraic Number Theory II
MATH621.description: Valuation of a field, algebraic function fields, completion of a valuation field, ramification exponent and residue class degree, ramification theory, elements, differents, discriminants, product formula and characterization of fields by the formula, Gauss sum, class number formula of cyclotomic fields.

relationships.prereqs: MATH600.
relationships.additional_info: And MATH620; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

MATH630.name: Real Analysis I
MATH630.description: Lebesgue measure and the Lebesgue integral on R, differentiation of functions of bounded variation, absolute continuity and fundamental theorem of calculus, Lp spaces on R, Riesz-Fischer theorem, bounded linear functionals on Lp, measure and outer measure, Fubini's theorem.

relationships.prereqs: MATH411; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

MATH634.name: Harmonic Analysis
MATH634.description: L1 theory: Fejer theorem, inversion theorem, ideal structure, Tauberian theorem. L2 theory: Plancherel-Parseval theorems, Paley-Wiener theorem. Lp theory: Hausdorff-Young theorem. Distribution theory: Bochner's theorem, Wiener continuous measures theorem, Malliavin theorem, Schwartz theory, almost periodic functions.

relationships.prereqs: MATH630.

MATH642.name: Dynamical Systems I
MATH642.description: Foundations of topological dynamics, homeomorphisms, flows, periodic and recurrent points, transitivity and minimality, symbolic dynamics. Elements of ergodic theory, invariant measures and sets, ergodicity, ergodic theorems, mixing, spectral theory, flows and sections. Applications of dynamical systems to number theory, the Weyl theorem, the distribution of values of polynomials, Vander Waerden's theorem on arithmetic progressions.

relationships.prereqs: MATH432.
relationships.additional_info: And MATH630; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

MATH673.name: Partial Differential Equations I
MATH673.description: Analysis of boundary value problems for Laplace's equation, initial value problems for the heat and wave equations. Fundamental solutions, maximum principles, energy methods. First order nonlinear PDE, conservation laws. Characteristics, shock formation, weak solutions. Distributions, Fourier transform.

relationships.prereqs: MATH411; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.
relationships.additional_info: Cross-listed with: AMSC673. Offered fall only.

MATH675.name: Analysis and PDEs
MATH675.description: Introduction to tools of modern analysis  which have been used in recent years in the study of partial differential equations:  Fourier transform, Calderon-Zygmund theory, interpolation, Lebesgue spaces, Lorentz spaces, Sobolev spaces, Besov spaces,  Littlewood-Paley theory, multipliers, Bernstein inequalities, the fractional Leibniz rule, Strichartz estimates, velocity averaging lemma. Applications to some of the following PDEs: the Navier-Stokes equations, Euler equations, nonlinear Schrodinger equations, nonlinear wave equations, the Patlak Keller Segel model.

relationships.prereqs: MATH630 or MATH674; or permission of instructor.

MATH695.name: Teaching Seminar
MATH695.description: A course intended for first year teaching assistants. Topics include: everyday mechanics of teaching; teaching methods and styles; technology; course enrichment, diversity in the classroom; sexual harassment; teacher-student interactions; presentations by students.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in one of the following programs (Mathematics (Doctoral); Mathematics (Master's); Mathematical Statistics (Doctoral); Applied Mathematics and Scientific Computation (Master's); Mathematical Statistics (Master's); Applied Mathematics and Scientific Computation (Doctoral)).

MATH712.name: Mathematical Logic I
MATH712.description: Sentential logic, first-order languages, models and formal deductions. Basic model theory including completeness and compactness theorems, other methods of constructing models, and applications such as non-standard analysis.

MATH730.name: Fundamental Concepts of Topology
MATH730.description: Survey of basic point set topology, fundamental group, covering spaces, Van Kampen's theorem, simplicial complexes, simplicial homology, Euler characteristics and classification of surfaces.

relationships.prereqs: MATH403, MATH410, and MATH411; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

MATH742.name: Geometric Analysis
MATH742.description: Calculus of Variations, Bochner technique, Morse theory, weak solutions and elliptic regularity, maximum principle for elliptic and parabolic equations, Green's function of the Laplacian, isoperimetric and Sobolev inequalities, continuity method, curvature and comparison results, harmonic maps, curvature prescription problems.

relationships.prereqs: MATH673 and MATH674; or MATH740.

MATH808C.name: Selected Topics in Algebra; Algebraic Combinatorics

MATH818E.name: Selected Topics in Logic; Model Theory via unary expansions

MATH848A.name: Selected Topics in Geometry and Topology

MATH848T.name: Selected Topics in Geometry and Topology; Geometric group theory, homeomorphism groups and mapping class groups

MATH848W.name: Selected Topics in Geometry and Topology; Introduction to Conformal Field Theory

MATH858G.name: Selected Topics in Analysis; Geormetic Methods in Analysis

MEES498I.name: Topics in Marine-Estuarine-Environmental Sciences; Chesapeake Bay Health
MEES498I.description: Jointly offered with MEES698I.  Offered synchronously to all MEES partner institutions via video. Please contact the instructor(s) for access and logistical information as needed.

MEES603.name: Responsible Conduct of Research
MEES603.description: Explores the "rules of the road" for being a scientist. Using a case study approach, the seminar will cover concepts of how science is regulated, what constitutes misconduct, how research is planned, conducted, and reported authorship and data ownership, and the ethical treatment of human and animal subjects. The course will focus mainly on mentor-trainee interactions and diversity in the sciences.

relationships.additional_info: Offered synchronously to all MEES partner institutions via video. Please contact the instructor(s) for access and logistical information as needed.

MEES607.name: Quantitative Methods in Environmental Sciences
MEES607.description: Mathematical approaches and solutions (both analytical and numerical) that cut across environmental disciplines, and will introduce analytical techniques.

relationships.prereqs: MATH120 and MATH121; or must have completed MATH220 and MATH221; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

MEES608B.name: Seminar in Marine-Estuarine-Environmental Sciences; Responsible Conduct of Research
MEES608B.description: Offered synchronously to all MEES partner institutions via video. Please contact the instructor(s) for access and logistical information as needed.

MEES608D.name: Seminar in Marine-Estuarine-Environmental Sciences; Scientific Writing and Communication
MEES608D.description: Offered synchronously to all MEES partner institutions via video. Please contact the instructor(s) for access and logistical information as needed.

MEES608O.name: Seminar in Marine-Estuarine-Environmental Sciences; Topics in OMICS
MEES608O.description: Offered synchronously to all MEES partner institutions via video. Please contact the instructor(s) for access and logistical information as needed.

MEES613.name: Environmental Statistics I
MEES613.description: Extends the quantitative training for students in the environmental sciences. It will explore the basic practices of statistics to inter-disciplinary environmental data. The goal is to train students with the statistical knowledge and tools needed to conduct statistical analysis in their own research. The statistical programming language R is used in class, to complete homework sets, and to analyze online data.

relationships.additional_info: Offered synchronously to all MEES partner institutions via video. Please contact the instructor(s) for access and logistical information as needed.

MEES615.name: Scientific Writing and Communication
MEES615.description: This professional development course will provide graduate students with a solid foundation in the fundamental concepts of scientific writing and communication to both scientists and citizens. Main topics will include the peer-review process and paper structure, how to develop strong editing and review skills, and how to craft effective research and outreach talks. Additional topics will include scientific ethics and application of communication skills to proposals, networking, job applications, and interviews. Students must agree to write new text for each writing assignment.

relationships.restrictions: Must have completed first year of graduate study; or permission of the instructor; and must have permission of the Marine Estuarine Environmental Sciences (MEES) Program.
relationships.additional_info: Offered synchronously to all MEES partner institutions via video. Please contact the instructor(s) for access and logistical information as needed.

MEES620.name: Environment and Society
MEES620.description: Students will obtain foundational knowledge of core theories and methods that integrate cultural and socio-economic research into environmental science. Key topics include: coupled natural and human systems, cultural models of the environment, social networks, ecological economics, political ecology, environmental justice, and science communication.

relationships.additional_info: Offered over the interactive video network. Cross-listed with: ANTH620.  Offered synchronously to all MEES partner institutions via video. Please contact the instructor(s) for access and logistical information as needed.

MEES640.name: Interconnected Earth Systems:  Land, Ocean, and Estuary
MEES640.description: Explores the interconnected physical and biogeochemical systems of land, estuary, and ocean with cross cutting themes of human impacts and global change. Broad concepts will be combined with targeted interactive case studies to demonstrate how these systems are linked by humans, climate, and water.

relationships.additional_info: Offered synchronously to all MEES partner institutions via video. Please contact the instructor(s) for access and logistical information as needed.

MEES650.name: Advanced Wetland Ecology
MEES650.description: Plant and animal communities, biogeochemistry, and ecosystem properties of wetlands. Lectures are supplemented by field trips (normally 2 days total during the semester) and in-class labs. Hands-on activities and exercises include identification of wetland plant species, wetland mapping and delineation, and collection and analysis of field data on wetland vegetation, soil, and hydrology. Wading boots (at least hip length) are strongly recommended.

relationships.prereqs: BIOM301; and ENST360 or other ecology equivalent; or permission of AGNR-Environmental Science and Technology department; or permission of CMNS-Marine & Estuarine-Environmental Science Program).
relationships.additional_info: Wading boots (at least hip length) are strongly recommended.  Cross-listed with: ENST650. Jointly offered with: ENST450, MEES650.

MEES660.name: Ecological Systems
MEES660.description: An introduction to the field of ecology is provided for matriculating graduate students and prepares them for more advanced concepts. Students will be exposed to ecology both in theory and practice through lectures, readings, and quantitative exercises, round table debates and discussions with current practitioners.

relationships.additional_info: Offered synchronously to all MEES partner institutions via video. Please contact the instructor(s) for access and logistical information as needed.

MEES680.name: Cell and Molecular Biology for the Environmental Scientist- From Genes to Ecosystems
MEES680.description: Introduces environmental scientists to the methods and approaches that are the foundations for today's breakthroughs in molecular and cellular biology. Detailed examination of papers published in the last few years along with online background materials will be used to reinforce the connection of key concepts to experimentation.

relationships.additional_info: Offered synchronously to all MEES partner institutions via video. Please contact the instructor(s) for access and logistical information as needed.

MEES682.name: Fishery Science and Management
MEES682.description: Aquatic production and fisheries yields. Introduction to fish population dynamics and assessment methods. Effects of fishing on resource potential yields. Causes of fluctuations in resource abundance. An emphasis on the relationship between science and management.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of instructor.

MEES698B.name: Special Topics in Marine-Estuarine-Environmental Sciences; Environmental Statistics I
MEES698B.description: Offered synchronously to all MEES partner institutions via video. Please contact the instructor(s) for access and logistical information as needed.

MEES698C.name: Special Topics in Marine-Estuarine-Environmental Sciences; Spatial Ecology in R
MEES698C.description: Offered synchronously to all MEES partner institutions via video. Please contact the instructor(s) for access and logistical information as needed. Many ecological questions in terrestrial and marine systems originate from the observation that organisms and the ecological processes that influence them vary in space. This course emphasizes the study of spatial ecological patterns (including animal movement), the processes that generate and maintain these patterns and processes, and the construction of models in R to analyze, simulate, and understand the interplay between spatial pattern, ecological processes, and scale. The objective of the course is to introduce students to ecological theories and concepts relevant to the study of spatial ecological patterns in terrestrial and marine systems, while providing the R skills necessary to articulate and answer scientific questions by confronting models with data.

MEES698E.name: Special Topics in Marine-Estuarine-Environmental Sciences; Ecosystem Restoration
MEES698E.description: Jointly offered with GEOL453 and GEOL789L. Overview of critical ecosystem functions across biomes/geologic settings emphasizing tradeoffs in restoration designs. Case studies illuminate structure's influence over biophysical and biogeochemical processes supporting ecosystems; then show how properties of physical, chemical, and ecosystem processes can be altered by different restoration strategies, to optimize ecosyst em services and habitat quality. Includesa semester research project.

MEES698I.name: Special Topics in Marine-Estuarine-Environmental Sciences; Chesapeake Bay Health
MEES698I.description: Jointly offered with MEES498I.  Offered synchronously to all MEES partner institutions via video. Please contact the instructor(s) for access and logistical information as needed.

MEES698M.name: Special Topics in Marine-Estuarine-Environmental Sciences; Modeling Chemical Equilibrium in Natural Waters

MEES698V.name: Special Topics in Marine-Estuarine-Environmental Sciences; Environmental Field Methods

MEES698W.name: Special Topics in Marine-Estuarine-Environmental Sciences; Chemistry of Natural Water
MEES698W.description: Cross-listed with ENCE651.  Application of principles from chemical thermodynamics and kinetics to the study and interpretation of the chemical composition of natural waters is rationalized by considering metal ion solubility controls, pH, carbonate equilibria, adsorption reactions, redox reactions and the kinetics of oxygenation reactions which occur in natural water environments.

MEES708X.name: Advanced Topics in Marine-Estuarine-Environmental Science; R Programming - Part 1 Module (Basics)

MEES708Y.name: Advanced Topics in Marine-Estuarine-Environmental Science; R Programming - Part 2 Module (Advanced)

MEES718U.name: Study Groups on Issues in Marine Estuarine Enviornmental Sciences; Ecosystem Services and Urban Estuaries

MEES718V.name: Study Groups on Issues in Marine Estuarine Enviornmental Sciences; Nature-Based Solutions for Coastal Adaptation

MEES718X.name: Study Groups on Issues in Marine Estuarine Enviornmental Sciences; Environmental Impacts of Technology-critical Elements (TCEs) in a Changing Global Economy

MEES718Y.name: Study Groups on Issues in Marine Estuarine Enviornmental Sciences; Narrowing Knowledge Gaps in Support of an International Treaty to Combat Plastic Pollution

MIEH300.name: A Public Health Perspective: Introduction to Environmental Health
MIEH300.department: Maryland Institute for Applied Environmental Health
MIEH300.description: Environmental health is that branch of public health that deals with the human health effects of exposure to chemical, physical, and biological agents in the community, workplace, and home. Activities within Environmental Health Sciences are associated with recognizing, assessing, understanding, and mitigating the impacts of chemical, physical, and biological agents as well as understanding how human behavior and action impacts the environment. This course focuses on the central concepts, principles, issues, and applications of the essential scientific components and strategies of control of major environmental health problems.

relationships.prereqs: Minimum grade of C- in CHEM131 and CHEM132; and must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in SPHL100 or PHSC300.
relationships.restrictions: Must have earned a minimum of 60 credits; and must be in Public Health Science program; or permission of SPHL-School of Public Health.

MIEH309.name: Environmental Health Research
MIEH309.department: Maryland Institute for Applied Environmental Health

MIEH321.name: Environmental Determinants of Emerging Infectious Diseases
MIEH321.department: Maryland Institute for Applied Environmental Health
MIEH321.description: Examines the influences of environmental factors, economic development, migration, and land use changes on emergence and reemergence of infectious diseases. Explores how population growth, development, and climate change impact natural reservoirs of infectious diseases and how they are transmitted through human populations. Includes historical accounts, newly emerging and reemerging diseases.

relationships.prereqs: Must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in SPHL100.

MIEH333.name: Every Drop Counts: Water, Food and Global Public Health
MIEH333.department: Maryland Institute for Applied Environmental Health
MIEH333.description: In-depth interdisciplinary study of the public health issues related to water use for global food production. Topics will include accessibility and availability of safe water for agriculture worldwide, potential microbiological and chemical hazards in agricultural water, alternative water sources such as reclaimed wastewater and return flows, food safety approaches to managing agricultural water, and agricultural influences on surface and groundwater quality. Political, social, and economic factors relating to agricultural water will be addressed, with special focus on regions that are leaders in innovative water management and regions where access to clean water for agriculture is a major challenge.

relationships.prereqs: ENSP101 or MIEH300; or permission of department.
relationships.additional_info: Cross-listed with: ENSP360.

MIEH415.name: Airborne Infection: The Science of COVID-19 and prevention of future pandemics
MIEH415.department: Maryland Institute for Applied Environmental Health
MIEH415.description: In the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, the elusive pathway - the aerobiological pathway - of infection transmission remains controversial and the world remains unprepared to control pandemic respiratory viruses. This course will focus on the science of infectious disease aerobiology and explore the historical roots of confusion and current political-economic forces that impede understanding and control of airborne infection transmission. Emphasis will be on reading and interpretation of original literature, understanding and using basic mathematical models, and evaluation of intervention strategies in the context of the hierarchy of hazard controls in public health.

relationships.additional_info: Cross-listed with: MIEH615.

MIEH600.name: Foundations of Environmental Health
MIEH600.department: Maryland Institute for Applied Environmental Health
MIEH600.description: Overview of the chemical, physical and biological hazards present in our living and working environment and their effects on human health. Topics include: exposure assessment, industrial hygiene and safety, pesticides, community and indoor pollution, food-borne diseases, solid and hazardous wastes, water resources, risk assessment, ecological issues and environmental laws.

MIEH605.name: Fundamentals of Global Health
MIEH605.department: Maryland Institute for Applied Environmental Health
MIEH605.description: Exploration of theoretical frameworks and practicial perspectives in global health with particular attention to the analysis of the biological, epidemiological, social, cultural and behavioral interactions that affect global health study and project implementation. The emphasis is on innovative solutions to health issues in underserved populations.

MIEH609.name: Methods in Environmental Health
MIEH609.department: Maryland Institute for Applied Environmental Health

MIEH615.name: Airborne Infection: The Science of COVID-19 and prevention of future pandemics
MIEH615.department: Maryland Institute for Applied Environmental Health
MIEH615.description: In the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, the elusive pathway - the aerobiological pathway - of infection transmission remains controversial and the world remains unprepared to control pandemic respiratory viruses. This course will focus on the science of infectious disease aerobiology and explore the historical roots of confusion and current political-economic forces that impede understanding and control of airborne infection transmission. Emphasis will be on reading and interpretation of original literature, understanding and using basic mathematical models, and evaluation of intervention strategies in the context of the hierarchy of hazard controls in public health.

relationships.additional_info: Cross-listed with: MIEH415.

MIEH688.name: Seminar in the Maryland Institute for Applied Environmental Health: Current Topics in Environmental Health
MIEH688.department: Maryland Institute for Applied Environmental Health

MIEH691.name: UMD Global STEWARDS: Project-Based Data Practicum at the Nexus of Food, Energy, and Water Systems
MIEH691.department: Maryland Institute for Applied Environmental Health
MIEH691.description: The range of food-energy-water (FEW) systems challenges from local to global scales. During the semester, students will gain real-world experience by participating in the conceptualization and/or conduct of an interdisciplinary FEW systems project. Projects may employ engineering, life sciences, epidemiological or policy approaches; earth system sciences frameworks; computational methods; and/or other innovative approaches. Through this work, students will gain hands-on experience in study design, research methods, and data analysis across varying FEW disciplines. Each student will bring a diverse set of expertise to the projects, creating a microcosm for interdisciplinary team science. During the course, students will have the opportunity to refine oral and written communication skills, including team writing. The deliverable for the course may include a grant proposal, a manuscript, a FactSheet, an Op-Ed, or another actionable type of science/policy writing.

relationships.prereqs: MIEH690,.
relationships.restrictions: Permission of instructor; and must be in UMD Global STEWARDS Fellows.

MIEH699.name: UMD Global STEWARDS: Seminal Findings, and Research and Policy in Progress at the Food, Energy, Water Nexus
MIEH699.department: Maryland Institute for Applied Environmental Health

MIEH735.name: Food Toxicology
MIEH735.department: Maryland Institute for Applied Environmental Health
MIEH735.description: An introduction to basic concepts in toxicology in relation to toxic food contaminants and additives; both synthetic and naturally occurring. Focus on exposure routes, molecular targets and susceptible individuals. Also includes regulatory toxicology with respect food toxins.

relationships.additional_info: Recommended: BCHM462, BSCI440, or CHEM131.  Cross-listed with NFSC735.

MIEH740.name: Environmental Health Risk Assessment
MIEH740.department: Maryland Institute for Applied Environmental Health
MIEH740.description: Review of the major methods of human and ecological risk assessment conducted by the U.S. Environment Protection Agency. Emphasis on sources of uncertainty.

relationships.prereqs: MIEH600; or permission of instructor.

MIEH770.name: Law and Policy in Environmental Health
MIEH770.department: Maryland Institute for Applied Environmental Health
MIEH770.description: Overview of laws that affect the environment, and the various ways in which businesses are regulated by the government in the interest of protecting the environment. International, Federal, state, and local laws and regulations related to the protection of human health and the regulation of environmental containments, including biological, physical and chemical factors affecting community health. Examination of the interactions between and differing responsibilities of various agencies enforcing environmental laws and regulations.

relationships.prereqs: MIEH600; or permission of instructor.

MIEH778.name: Practical Experience in Public Health
MIEH778.department: Maryland Institute for Applied Environmental Health

MIEH780.name: Occupational Health
MIEH780.department: Maryland Institute for Applied Environmental Health
MIEH780.description: A synthesis of epidemiology, toxicology, exposure science, risk assessment, and policy. Emphasis will be on methods for anticipating, recognizing, evaluating and controlling workplace hazards; the hierarchy of controls; and current hot topics in occupational health.

relationships.prereqs: MIEH720 and MIEH771; and must have completed SPHL602.
relationships.additional_info: Or permission of instructor.

MIEH783.name: Proposal Development and Marketing for Public Health Scientists
MIEH783.department: Maryland Institute for Applied Environmental Health
MIEH783.description: Every scientist, whether in academia, government, or industry, must write compelling proposals if they are to succeed in having resources to pursue their passions and interests. To write a compelling proposal, we must develop clear and concise hypotheses and definitive ways to test them. But to have an impact, to get funded, to graduate, we must also excel at marketing our ideas and our achievements to other scientists and the public. This course is designed for doctoral students and postdoctoral fellows who want to develop and hone their proposal development and marketing skills.

MIEH786.name: Capstone Project in Public Health
MIEH786.department: Maryland Institute for Applied Environmental Health
MIEH786.description: Capstone experience provding opportunity to apply knowledge and skills to a specific public health problem or issue. Completion of project relevant to public health under the direction of an advisor.

relationships.prereqs: Permission of SPHL-Maryland Institute for Applied Environmental Health.

MIEH788.name: Critical Readings in Environmental Health
MIEH788.department: Maryland Institute for Applied Environmental Health

MIEH789.name: Independent Study
MIEH789.department: Maryland Institute for Applied Environmental Health

MIEH799.name: Master's Thesis Research
MIEH799.department: Maryland Institute for Applied Environmental Health

MIEH898.name: Pre-Candidacy Research
MIEH898.department: Maryland Institute for Applied Environmental Health

MIEH899.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research
MIEH899.department: Maryland Institute for Applied Environmental Health

MITH388T.name: Digital Humanities Research Assistantship; Maryland Institute for Technology in the Humanities Internships
MITH388T.department: Maryland Institute for Technology in the Humanities

MITH729.name: Colloquium in Digital Studies
MITH729.department: Maryland Institute for Technology in the Humanities

MLAW100.name: Justice and the Law
MLAW100.description: An exploration into the relationship between justice and law, including psychological, philosophical, political and legal approaches to justice, as well as an analytical framework for understanding human rights.

relationships.restrictions: Course enrollment is restricted to students in the College Park Scholars Justice and Legal Thought Program (CPJT).

MLAW304.name: Introduction to Law and Social Inquiry
MLAW304.description: An exploration of the relationship between law and society from an interdisciplinary perspective. Major themes cover the impact of law on society, society on law and social change.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in the Law and Society (MLAW) minor.

MLAW305.name: Law and Legal Institutions in Social Context
MLAW305.description: An exploration of case law, statutes, and regulations separately and together in their social context.

relationships.prereqs: MLAW304.
relationships.restrictions: Must be a student in  the Law and Society Minor.

MLAW315.name: Citizenship and Naturalization in America
MLAW315.description: Notions of who is an American - and who is not - are deeply rooted in the American ethos. Although the United States has long been praised for its inclusiveness vis-a-vis citizenship - including a policy of jus soli, or birthright citizenship - a closer look reveals a difficult history involving the categorical exclusion of many groups from American citizenship. We will examine this history, focusing particularly on Black and Native Americans and immigrants, and drawing upon legal cases, historical texts, and personal narratives detailing the lived experiences of those seeking American citizenship. We will trace this history to the present and explore the current process and requirements for becoming an American citizen. Students will have an opportunity to engage guests and discussions from the Maryland Carey School of Law and other experts.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in the Law and Society minor (MLAW); or must be in College Park Scholars Justice and Legal Thought (CPJT).

MLAW358T.name: Selected Topics in Law and Society; Tackling Trafficking: The Legal System's Responses to Human Trafficking

MLAW358X.name: Selected Topics in Law and Society; Introduction to Constitutional Law
MLAW358X.description: Prerequisites: GVPT170 and GVPT331. Jointly offered with GVPT431.

MLAW378J.name: Special topics in Law and Society; Bioethics and the Law
MLAW378J.description: This seminar will examine the impact of advancements in the biosciences on a variety of legal and policy issues. Topics will likely include the doctrine of informed consent, physician-assisted suicide and euthanasia, assisted reproduction, conscientious refusals to provide medical care, the allocation and sale/donation of body parts and services, and medical and law enforcement uses of genetic information, as well as topics arising out of the Covid-19 pandemic. In examining these various issues, students will consider the content and consistency of current law, the policy goals motivating legal regulation, the impact of technological innovation, and directions for legal reform.

MLAW378K.name: Special topics in Law and Society; The US Supreme Court and American Society
MLAW378K.description: This course investigates the United States Supreme Court and its role in politics, government, and society. Other than its constitutional justification, why do we need and have a U.S. Supreme Court? What are some of the most important opinions issued by the Supreme Court that changed society, for the good, and bad? Who are the Court's most important justices? And most of all, how does the Court work? This course will trace the development of the constitutional doctrine of the Court, the growth of the Court's institutional power, and the Court s interaction with Congress, the president, and society. Discussed are major constitutional law decisions, their political contexts, and the social and behavioral factors that affect judges, justices, and federal court jurisprudence. There will be a strong emphasis on how the Court's decisions have impacted law and society and how the Court helps to maintain a certain kind of society.

MLAW378P.name: Special topics in Law and Society; Introduction to Criminal Procedure
MLAW378P.description: This class will provide students with a basic understanding of the constitutional law undergirding criminal investigations in the United States. Focused primarily on the Fourth, Fifth and Sixth Amendments, students will leave the class able to identify and apply the basic tenets of search and seizure law as it applies to various police-citizen interactions.

MLAW388.name: Law and Society Internship
MLAW388.description: students within the Law and Society minor.

MLSC250.name: Lol that's not funny: Language change and linguistic creativity in online communication
MLSC250.description: Recent developments in technology, from texting to Zoom, have created new environments for human language use. Examining how communication is changing in these environments highlights humans' endless linguistic ingenuity -- ranging from new vocabulary and punctuation conventions to the use of hashtags, emoji and memes. At the same time, these linguistic innovations exemplify broader patterns of language change and diversity that have been documented and studied by language scientists. In this course, we will engage with the study of language variation and change through a survey of language use in different online environments, and will apply insights from linguistic research to analyze our own and others' language use in more nuanced ways.

MSML601.name: Probability and Statistics
MSML601.description: Provides a solid understanding of the fundamental concepts of probability theory and statistics. The course covers the basic probabilistic concepts such as probability space, random variables and vectors, expectation, covariance, correlation, probability distribution functions, etc. Important classes of discrete and continuous random variables, their inter-relation, and relevance to applications are discussed. Conditional probabilities, the Bayes formula, and properties of jointly distributed random variables are covered. Limit theorems, which investigate the behavior of a sum of a large number of random variables, are discussed. The main concepts random processes are then introduced. The latter part of the course concerns the basic problems of mathematical statistics, in particular, point and interval estimation and hypothesis testing.

relationships.prereqs: Undergraduate courses in calculus and basic linear algebra.
relationships.additional_info: Cross-listed with: DATA601, BIOI601.

MSML602.name: Principles of Data Science
MSML602.description: An introduction to the data science pipeline, i.e., the end-to-end process of going from unstructured, messy data to knowledge and actionable insights. Provides a broad overview of what data science means and systems and tools commonly used for data science, and illustrates the principles of data science through several case studies.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in one of the following programs: (Data Science Post-Baccalaureate Certificate, Master of Professional Studies in Data Science and Analytics, or Master of Professional Studies in Machine Learning).
relationships.additional_info: Cross-listed with: DATA602, BIOI602.

MSML603.name: Principles of Machine Learning
MSML603.description: A broad introduction to machine learning and statistical pattern recognition. Topics include: Supervised learning: Bayes decision theory, discriminant functions, maximum likelihood estimation, nearest neighbor rule, linear discriminant analysis, support vector machines, neural networks, deep learning networks. Unsupervised learning: clustering, dimensionality reduction, PCA, auto-encoders. The course will also discuss recent applications of machine learning, such as computer vision, data mining, autonomous navigation, and speech recognition.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in one of the following programs: (Data Science Post-Baccalaureate Certificate, Master of Professional Studies in Data Science and Analytics, or Master of Professional Studies in Machine Learning).
relationships.additional_info: Cross-listed with: DATA603, BIOI603, MSQC603.
relationships.credit_granted_for: BIOI603, DATA603, MSML603, MSQC603 or CMSC643.

MSML642.name: Robotics
MSML642.description: An introduction to the design and programming of robotics systems. Topics include kinematics, differential motion and velocity, dynamics and forces. Sensors, actuators and drive systems. Trajectory planning and motion control systems, open-loop and closed-loop controllers, state estimation and Kalman filters. It will also discuss recent applications of machine learning to motion planning, grasping, manipulation, and related areas.

relationships.prereqs: DATA/MSML/MSQC603.

MSML650.name: Cloud Computing
MSML650.description: The course will present the state of the art in cloud computing technologies and applications. Topics will include: telecommunications needs, architectural models for cloud computing, cloud computing platforms and services. Data center networking, server, network and storage virtualization technologies, and containerization. Cloud operating and orchestration systems. Security, privacy, and trust management; resource allocation and quality of service; interoperability and internetworking.

relationships.additional_info: Cross-listed with: DATA650.

MSML651.name: Big Data Analytics
MSML651.description: The challenges, tools and methods to design and implement machine learning algorithms for very large datasets, and the configuration and operation of distributed computing platforms to execute them. Topics include scalable learning techniques, data streaming and data flow analytics, machine learning on large graphs. Massively parallel computing models such as map-reduce, and techniques to reduce the memory, disk storage and/or communication requirements of parallel machine learning algorithms. SQL and no-SQL database systems, distributed file systems, key-value stores, document databases, graph databases and large dataset visualization.

MSQC601.name: Mathematics and Methods of Quantum Computing
MSQC601.description: This course will provide the student with the necessary physical intuition and background information on quantum physics to be able to understand and appreciate a variety of applications in quantum computing such as quantum currency, encryption, random number generation.

MSQC602.name: Physics of Quantum Devices
MSQC602.description: An introduction to quantum physics with emphasis on topics at the frontiers of research, and developing understanding through exercises.This course aims to build a bridge between natural principles such as light and atoms and a variety of modern applications. This course will provide the student with the necessary physical intuition and background information on quantum physics so that to be able to understand and appreciate a variety of applications in quantum computing such as quantum currency, encryption, random number generation

MSQC603.name: Principles of Machine Learning
MSQC603.description: A broad introduction to machine learning and statistical pattern recognition. Topics include: Supervised learning: Bayes decision theory, discriminant functions, maximum likelihood estimation, nearest neighbor rule, linear discriminant analysis, support vector machines, neural networks, deep learning networks. Unsupervised learning: clustering, dimensionality reduction, PCA, auto-encoders. The course will also discuss recent applications of machine learning, such as computer vision, data mining, autonomous navigation, and speech recognition.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in one of the following programs: (Data Science Post-Baccalaureate Certificate, Master of Professional Studies in Data Science and Analytics, or Master of Professional Studies in Machine Learning).
relationships.additional_info: Cross-listed with: DATA603, BIOI603, MSML603.
relationships.credit_granted_for: BIOI603, DATA603, MSML603, MSQC603 or CMSC643.

MUED155.name: Fundamentals for the Classroom Teacher
MUED155.description: The fundamentals of music theory and practice, related to the needs of the classroom and the kindergarten teacher.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in one of the following programs (Early Childhood Education; Elementary Education) ; or must be a Pre-Elementary Education major; or must be a Pre-Early Childhood Education major.

MUED186.name: Pre-professional Experiences I
MUED186.description: An orientation into the role of the music teacher in the school and community. On-site school visits at elementary, middle and high school levels form the basis for discussion and exploration of all facets of the music education profession.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Music Education program.
relationships.additional_info: Fulfills the College of Arts and Humanities requirement for ARHU158.

MUED213.name: String Technique and Pedagogy I
MUED213.description: A study of violin, viola, cello and bass technique and pedagogy; beginning level. Emphasizes group process playing and teaching.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Music Education program.

MUED215.name: Woodwind Technique and Pedagogy
MUED215.description: Playing experience on instruments of the woodwind family. Historical and acoustical background. Basic concepts of teaching. Methods and materials. Techniques of individual and class instruction.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of ARHU-School of Music department.

MUED320.name: Teaching Secondary Instrumental Music I
MUED320.description: Prepare instrumental-emphasis music education majors to synthesize the knowledge and skills that will enable them to extend secondary-level musical skill through planned instruction and development of teaching materials.

relationships.prereqs: MUED187.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Music Education program.

MUED333.name: Classroom Vocal Pedagogy
MUED333.description: An introduction to the fundamentals of group vocal pedagogy for the choral and general classroom teacher, including the teaching of posture, breathing, resonance, registration, articulation and foreign language diction as appropriate to needs of the child or adolescent singer in K-12 classroom settings.

relationships.prereqs: MUED187 and MUED186.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Music Education program.

MUED420.name: Teaching Secondary Instrumental Music II
MUED420.description: Prepare instrumental-emphasis music education majors to synthesize the knowledge and skills that will enable them to develop and/or maintain an exemplary, curricular-oriented, research-based, comprehensive secondary instrumental program.

relationships.prereqs: MUED320 and MUED311.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Music Education program.

MUED422.name: Teaching General Music II
MUED422.description: Designed as an advanced music methods course and field experience for students who are preparing for a career in general music. The field experience is a practicum that is co-supervised by the university instructor and a general music educator.

relationships.prereqs: MUED322 and MUED333.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Music Education program.

MUED474.name: Field Experiences: Pre-Student Teaching
MUED474.description: Field experiences to fulfill teaching requirements in K-12 music teacher education program.

relationships.prereqs: MUED420 and MUED411; or (MUED472 and MUED471).
relationships.restrictions: Permission of ARHU-School of Music department; and senior standing.

MUED484.name: Student Teaching in Elementary School: Music
MUED484.description: Fulfills elementary teaching requirements in K-12 music teacher education program. Limited to music education majors who have previously applied.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of ARHU-School of Music department; and must be in Music Education program.

MUED494.name: Student Teaching in Secondary School: Music
MUED494.description: Fulfill secondary teaching requirements in K-12 music teacher education program. Limited to music education majors who have previously applied.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of ARHU-School of Music department; and must be in Music Education program.
relationships.additional_info: Students must pay a $750.00 student teaching fee.

MUED499B.name: Workshops, Clinics, Institutes; Music and Community Engagement

MUED690.name: Research Methods in Music and Music Education
MUED690.description: The application of methods of research to problems in the fields of music and music education. The preparation of bibliographies and the written exposition of research projects in the area of the student's major interest.

MUED697.name: Curriculum & Assessment in Music Education
MUED697.description: Theoretical and practical knowledge related to curriculum,assessment, and evaluation in music education. Course topics include: a) aspects of philosophy,sequencing, and design in music curricula; b) reliability, validity, and fairness in assessment; c) planning for and designing assessment of student knowledge and skills; d) policy, procedures, and outcomes associated with music teacher evaluation.

MUED698B.name: Current Trends in Music Education; Music and Community Engagement

MUED698Q.name: Current Trends in Music Education; Qualitative and Mixed Methods Research in Music Education

MUED698V.name: Current Trends in Music Education; Vocal Pedagogy for the Choral Conductor

MUED785.name: Teaching Music in Higher Education
MUED785.description: Prepare students for music faculty positions in higher education institutions. The course readings, discussions, assignments, and experiences are aimed to develop the knowledge, skills, and dispositions necessary to be a successful member of the faculty at a variety of institutions.

MUED790.name: Design and Analysis of Research in Music Education
MUED790.description: Advanced applications of quantitative and qualitative social science research paradigms to research problems in the field of music education. Topics include the formation of researchable questions; the design of experimental, quasi-experimental, descriptive, and qualitative research studies; and the analysis and interpretation of research data.

relationships.prereqs: Must have completed a college-level statistics course.
relationships.additional_info: And MUED690; or an equivalent master's level research in music education course.

MUSC102.name: Class Piano
MUSC102.description: Functional piano training for beginners. Development of techniques for school and community playing. Basic piano techniques; chord, arpeggio and scale techniques; melody and song playing; simple accompaniments, improvisation for accompaniments and rhythms; sight reading and transposition and playing by ear.

relationships.additional_info: For MUSC majors only.

MUSC102B.name: Class Piano
MUSC102B.description: Functional piano training for beginners. Development of techniques for school and community playing. Basic piano techniques; chord, arpeggio and scale techniques; melody and song playing; simple accompaniments, improvisation for accompaniments and rhythms; sight reading and transposition and playing by ear.

MUSC106.name: Beginning Classical Guitar
MUSC106.description: Introduction to classical guitar notation, technique, literature and performance. No previous musical experience required.

relationships.additional_info: For students with no previous musical experience.

MUSC123.name: Movement for Singers
MUSC123.description: Systematic exercises, improvisations and dances in conjunction with artistic vocal expression. Performance and critique of stage deportment, gestures and recital techniques.

relationships.prereqs: Permission of ARHU-School of Music department.

MUSC127.name: Vocal Diction: Italian
MUSC127.description: Augmentation of private voice study. Phonetics and diction for singers of Italian vocal literature.

relationships.prereqs: Permission of ARHU-School of Music department.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major within the ARHU-School of Music department.

MUSC140.name: Music Fundamentals I
MUSC140.description: Introductory theory course. Notation, scales, intervals, triads, rhythm, form and basic aural skills.

relationships.restrictions: Must not be in any of the following programs (Music (Professional Program); Music Education).

MUSC150.name: Theory of Music I
MUSC150.description: A study of basic concepts and skills in tonal melody and harmony through analysis and composition.

relationships.prereqs: Departmental audition and entrance examination.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in one of the following programs (Music (Liberal Arts Program); Music (Jazz Performance Option); Music (Winds & Percussions Performance Option); Music (Voice Performance Option); Music Composition; Music (Professional Program); Music (Piano Performance Option); Music Performance-Winds and Percussion; Music Theory and Composition; Music Performance-Piano; Music Performance-Jazz Studies; Music Performance-Voice; Music Performance-Strings; Music (Strings Performance Option)).

MUSC202.name: Intermediate Class Piano I
MUSC202.description: Advanced keyboard techniques. Continuation of skills introduced in MUSC103. Transposition, modulation and sight reading; methods of teaching functional piano.

relationships.prereqs: MUSC103; or must have equivalent piano training.
relationships.additional_info: Only for voice and instrumental principals with limited piano experience.

MUSC204.name: Popular Music in Black America
MUSC204.description: Traces black popular music in the U.S. with a special focus on spirituals, ragtime, the blues, early jazz, R&B, Motown, funk, soul, and rap. Examines how these styles have been borrowed by the American music industry.

MUSC205.name: History of Popular Music, 1950-Present
MUSC205.description: A historical survey of rock music (blues, rock, soul, metal, rap, etc.) from circa 1950 to the present, with emphasis on popular music as music and popular music as social history.

MUSC210.name: The Impact of Music on Life
MUSC210.description: Music as a part of culture. Materials drawn from traditions throughout the globe to illustrate issues of historical and contemporary significance, including the impact of race, class and gender on the study of music.

MUSC215.name: World Popular Musics and Identity
MUSC215.description: Focus on popular musics in different cultures with an emphasis on cross-cultural comparisons and analysis of how musics and identity intersect.

MUSC227.name: Vocal Diction: German
MUSC227.description: Augmentation of private study. Phonetics and diction for singers of German vocal literature.

relationships.prereqs: Permission of ARHU-School of Music department.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major within ARHU-School of Music department.

MUSC229A.name: Ensemble; Orchestra
MUSC229A.description: Audition required before permission of department will be granted, contact instructor to make arrangements.

MUSC229D.name: Ensemble; Wind Orchestra
MUSC229D.description: Open by audition, contact instructor to make arrangements.

MUSC229E.name: Ensemble; Wind Ensemble
MUSC229E.description: Open by audition, contact instructor to make arrangements.

MUSC229G.name: Ensemble; Marching Band: Woodwinds and Brass

MUSC229I.name: Ensemble; Marching Band: Drumline and Auxiliary

MUSC229J.name: Ensemble; Jazz Ensemble
MUSC229J.description: Audition required before permission of department will be granted, contact instructor to make arrangements.

MUSC229R.name: Ensemble; University Orchestra
MUSC229R.description: Audition required before permission of department will be granted, contact instructor to make arrangements.

MUSC229U.name: Ensemble; University Band
MUSC229U.description: Open by audition, contact instructor to make arrangements.

MUSC229Z.name: Ensemble; Jazz Combo
MUSC229Z.description: Audition required before permission of department will be granted, contact instructor to make arrangements.

MUSC240.name: Elements of Music Composition for Non-Majors
MUSC240.description: Emphasizes learning concepts and techniques of music composition through the study of music theory and structure used in both classical and popular music forms. Students will compose music using computer assisted and composition tools. These tools include cloud based digital audio workstations and music notation programs. Compositions will be written in these musical styles but not limited to classical, jazz, and popular. Students will also explore methods of sharing their compositions on various digital platforms.

relationships.prereqs: MUSC 140, or by permission of instructor.
relationships.restrictions: Must not be in any of the following programs: (Music (Professional Program); Music Education).
relationships.additional_info: Recommended: Ability to read music on a grand staff (treble and bass clef).

MUSC250.name: Advanced Theory of Music I
MUSC250.description: A continuation of MUSC 151, with further study of chromatic and modulatory techniques of the nineteenth century. Emphasis on sight singing, ear training, analysis and compositional skills.

relationships.prereqs: Minimum grade of C- in MUSC151.

MUSC260.name: Music as Global Culture
MUSC260.description: Explores how and why people create, transform, and move music around the globe. Taking a comparative approach to Western art musics and other musics of the world, course will examine a variety of musical practices in their social, political, and economic contexts. Experiential knowledge will be developed through hands-on ethnographic research.

relationships.prereqs: MUSC151.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major within the ARHU-School of Music department.

MUSC328.name: Introduction to Chamber Music for Pianists

MUSC329A.name: Ensemble; University of Maryland Chorale
MUSC329A.description: Audition required before permission of department will be granted, contact instructor to make arrangements. Monthly evening rehearsals will be scheduled as announced.

MUSC329B.name: Ensemble; Chamber Singers
MUSC329B.description: Audition required before permission of department will be granted, contact instructor to make arrangements. Monthly evening rehearsals will be scheduled as announced.

MUSC329M.name: Ensemble; Ensemble: Tactus (Tenor & Bass Choir)
MUSC329M.description: Monthly evening rehearsals will be scheduled as announced.

MUSC329W.name: Ensemble; Treble Choir
MUSC329W.description: Monthly evening rehearsals will be scheduled as announced.

MUSC361.name: Music in Western Culture After 1900
MUSC361.description: Continuation of MUSC360. A historical study of Western classical music, popular music, and jazz since 1900.

relationships.prereqs: MUSC360.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major within the ARHU-School of Music department.

MUSC428.name: Repertoire Coaching of Vocal or Chamber Music

MUSC443.name: Solo Vocal Literature
MUSC443.description: The study of solo vocal literature from the Baroque Cantata to the Art Song of the present. The Lied, Melodie, vocal chamber music and the orchestral song are examined.

relationships.prereqs: MUSC330 and MUSC331; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

MUSC444.name: Wind and Percussion Literature
MUSC444.description: Recital program notes and written projects in wind or percussion literature.

relationships.prereqs: Permission of ARHU-School of Music department.

MUSC446.name: String Literature
MUSC446.description: Recital program notes and written projects in string literature.

relationships.prereqs: MUSP316; and permission of ARHU-School of Music department.

MUSC448B.name: Selected Topics in Music; Analysis of Popular Music

MUSC448E.name: Financial Entrepreneurship for Arts Leaders
MUSC448E.description: An introduction to financial entrepreneurship for the arts leader in order to prepare students for diverse and ever-changing careers in the arts and creative fields. Topics explored will include Professional Paperwork (resumes, cover letters, biographies, job searches), Financial Literacy (taxes, budgets, boards, tickets sales, musicians unions), Marketing (website development, social media, press packets, record labels vs. online distribution, headshots, audience development, community engagement, branded content), Communication (public speaking, writing), and Technology (online tools, computer software, peripherals, recording, photography/videography, on campus resources).

relationships.additional_info: Cross-listed with: ARHU340.

MUSC448G.name: Selected Topics in Music; History of Mass, from Machaut to the Present

MUSC448L.name: Selected Topics in Music; US Popular Music

MUSC448W.name: Selected Topics in Music; Instrumental Pedagogy

MUSC448Z.name: Selected Topics in Music; Music in the Baroque Era

MUSC450.name: Musical Form
MUSC450.description: A study of the principles of organization in music with emphasis on eighteenth and nineteenth century European music. Reading and analysis of scores exemplifying the musical forms.

relationships.prereqs: MUSC251.

MUSC451.name: Analysis of Music
MUSC451.description: A course in the analysis of music. Discussion of individual works, with emphasis on their unique characteristics and on the relation of analysis to performance.

relationships.prereqs: MUSC450; or permission of instructor.

MUSC453.name: Jazz Improvisation I
MUSC453.description: Jazz theory, notational conventions, improvisation techniques, reading and analysis of music, and performance in small combo format.

relationships.prereqs: MUSC251; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.
relationships.additional_info: And permission of ARHU-School of Music department.

MUSC455.name: Theory of Jazz
MUSC455.description: Analysis of jazz harmony, with emphasis on principles of substitution, reharmonization, and syntax. Topics may also include chord/scale relationships, phrasing and articulation, notation, and introductory arranging concepts such as orchestration and form.

relationships.prereqs: MUSC250; or permission of ARHU-School of Music department.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major within ARHU-School of Music department.

MUSC464.name: The Theories of Heinrich Schenker
MUSC464.description: An advanced analysis course in tonal music with specific emphasis on the theories of the early 20th century theorist Heinrich Schenker. Specific analyses of music by Bach, Mozart, Haydn, Beethoven, Chopin, and Brahms.

relationships.prereqs: MUSC251 and MUSC450; and permission of ARHU-School of Music department.
relationships.restrictions: Must not have completed MUSC651.

MUSC467.name: Piano Pedagogy I
MUSC467.description: A study of major pedagogical treatises in music, and an evaluation of pedagogical techniques, materials, and procedures.

relationships.prereqs: Permission of ARHU-School of Music department.

MUSC469C.name: Orchestral Excerpts for String Players; Violin

relationships.restrictions: Permission of department.

MUSC469D.name: Orchestral Excerpts for String Players; Viola

relationships.restrictions: permission of department.

MUSC469E.name: Orchestral Excerpts for String Players; Orchestral Excerpts for String Players: Cello

MUSC469F.name: Orchestral Excerpts for String Players; Bass

MUSC469V.name: Orchestral Excerpts for String Players; Harp

relationships.prereqs: MUSC251.

MUSC492.name: Keyboard Music I
MUSC492.description: The history and literature of harpsichord and solo piano music from its beginning to the romantic period. Emphasis is placed on those segments of repertory which are encountered in performance and teaching situations at the present time.

relationships.prereqs: Permission of ARHU-School of Music department.

MUSC550.name: Theory of Music Graduate Review
MUSC550.description: Music theory review for graduate students:aural training, counterpoint, basic diatonic harmony, chromatic harmony, and analysis of complete works.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of ARHU-School of Music department.

MUSC601.name: Advanced English Lyric Diction
MUSC601.description: Concepts, strategies and techniques for singing operatic, oratorio and song literature in English: stress patterns, linkage, stressed and non stressed vowels, dipthongs, placement of consonants and vowels, and communication of text with emphasis on current performance practices. Use of the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) will be stressed.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in one of the following programs (Music - Doctoral (Doctoral); Music - Master (Master's)) .
relationships.additional_info: And permission of instructor; or admission to graduate voice program.

MUSC604.name: Advanced French Lyric Diction
MUSC604.description: Concepts, strategies and techniques for singing operatic and song literature in French: phoneticization, formation and singing of the vowel-sounds, semi-consonants, and consonants; the liaison; legato singing in French; the hiatus, mute and aspirate 'h'; stress and word rhythm. Use of the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) will be stressed.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in one of the following programs (Music - Doctoral (Doctoral); Music - Master (Master's)) .
relationships.additional_info: And permission of instructor; or admission to graduate voice program.

MUSC605.name: Opera Repertory I
MUSC605.description: Advanced vocal coaching of selections from the Italian, French, German, and English opera repertory: musical accuracy; language facility; diction clarity; and dramatic interpretation.

relationships.prereqs: MUSC602; or permission of instructor.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in one of the following programs (Music - Doctoral (Doctoral); Music - Master (Master's)).

MUSC608.name: Chamber Music Repertory; Chamber Music Repertoire

MUSC609.name: Piano Chamber Music Practicum and Analysis

MUSC611.name: Opera Techniques I
MUSC611.description: Techniques for opera performance: Improvisation; Acting I, Scene Study I; and Movement I. Practical application of styles and techniques to operatic repertoire.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of director of opera; and must be in one of the following programs (Music - Doctoral (Doctoral); Music - Master (Master's)).

MUSC613.name: Opera Techniques III
MUSC613.description: Continuation of MUSC 612. Techniques for opera performance: Scene Study III; Movement III; and Shakespeare.

relationships.prereqs: Minimum grade of B- in MUSC612; and permission of Director of Opera required.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in one of the following programs (Music - Doctoral (Doctoral); Music - Master (Master's)).

MUSC629A.name: Ensemble; Orchestra
MUSC629A.description: Audition required before permission of department will be granted, contact instructor to make arrangements.

MUSC629J.name: Ensemble; Jazz Ensemble
MUSC629J.description: Audition required before permission of department will be granted, contact instructor to make arrangements.

MUSC629R.name: Ensemble; Repertoire Orchestra
MUSC629R.description: Audition required before permission of department will be granted, contact instructor to make arrangements.

MUSC629U.name: Ensemble; University Band
MUSC629U.description: Open by audition, contact instructor to make arrangements.

MUSC629W.name: Ensemble; Wind Orchestra
MUSC629W.description: Open by audition, contact instructor to make arrangements.

MUSC629Z.name: Ensemble; Jazz Combo
MUSC629Z.description: Audition required before permission of department will be granted, contact instructor to make arrangements.

MUSC646.name: Introduction to Musicology
MUSC646.description: An introduction to the basics of musicological research, including sources, methodologies, and techniques, as well as the fundamentals of both academic and non-academic writing.

relationships.prereqs: Graduate student standing in in the School of Music.

MUSC648.name: Seminar in Music Research; Seminar in Music Research

MUSC649A.name: Ensemble; University of Maryland Chorale
MUSC649A.description: Audition required before permission of department will be granted, contact instructor to make arrangements.

MUSC649B.name: Ensemble; Chamber Singers
MUSC649B.description: Audition required before permission of department will be granted, contact instructor to make arrangements.

MUSC651.name: The Theories of Heinrich Schenker
MUSC651.description: The analytical methods of Heinrich Schenker with application of those theories to musical literature from the Baroque, Classical and Romantic periods.

relationships.prereqs: MUSC450; or permission of ARHU-School of Music department.

MUSC653.name: Jazz Improvisation I
MUSC653.description: Study of improvisational techniques and historical styles of jazz, including study of jazz "language" through transcription and analysis of recorded solos, and the exploration of creative processes and philosophical concepts.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of ARHU-School of Music department.

MUSC655.name: Theory of Jazz
MUSC655.description: Analysis of jazz harmony, with emphasis on principles of substitution, reharmonization, and syntax. Topics may also include chord/scale relationships, phrasing, articulation, notation and orchestration.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of ARHU-School of Music department.

MUSC659B.name: Seminar in Repertoire and Pedagogy; Orchestral Repertoire and Pedagogy

MUSC659C.name: Seminar in Repertoire and Pedagogy; Wind Repertoire and Pedagogy

MUSC669C.name: Orchestral Excerpts for String Players; Violin

MUSC669D.name: Orchestral Excerpts for String Players; Viola

MUSC669E.name: Orchestral Excerpts for String Players; Orchestral Excerpts for String Players: Cello

MUSC669F.name: Orchestral Excerpts for String Players; Bass

MUSC669V.name: Orchestral Excerpts for String Players; Harp

MUSC670.name: Advanced Analytical Techniques I
MUSC670.description: Analysis of representative masterpieces of the eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries.

relationships.prereqs: MUSC451; or permission of ARHU-School of Music department.

MUSC677.name: Introduction to Ethnomusicology
MUSC677.description: An introduction to the field of ethnomusicology: its origins as comparative musicology, its establishment as an autonomous discipline, and its contemporary trajectories.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of ARHU-School of Music department.

MUSC679K.name: Seminar in Ethnomusicology; Music and Folklorization

MUSC699B.name: Selected Topics in Music; Analysis of Popular Music

MUSC699F.name: Selected Topics in Music; Musical Movement and Music Analysis

MUSC699L.name: Selected Topics in Music; Translating Music/ally: From the Page to the Stage and Screen

MUSC699W.name: Selected Topics in Music; Instrumental Pedagogy

MUSC757.name: Aural Skills for Conductors
MUSC757.description: Advanced musicianship skills necessary for conductors.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of ARHU-School of Music department.

MUSC800P.name: Advanced Seminar in Music Pedagogy
MUSC800P.description: A detailed study of historical and contemporary methods of pedagogy, and analysis of pedagogical problems. Sectioning by instrument. Required of all candidates for the D.M.A. Degree in performance and literature.

relationships.prereqs: MUSC400; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.
relationships.restrictions: Permission of instructor.

MUSC800W.name: Advanced Seminar in Music Pedagogy
MUSC800W.description: A detailed study of historical and contemporary methods of pedagogy, and analysis of pedagogical problems. Sectioning by instrument. Required of all candidates for the D.M.A. Degree in performance and literature.

relationships.prereqs: MUSC400; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.
relationships.restrictions: Permission of instructor.

MUSC811.name: Doctoral Opera Techniques
MUSC811.description: Techniques for opera performance: Improvisation; Acting I, Scene Study I; and Movement I. Practical application of styles, techniques to operat e repertoire, and methodology seminar.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of ARHU-School of Music department.

MUSC813.name: Doctoral Opera Techniques III
MUSC813.description: Continuation of MUSC812. Techniques for opera performance: Scene Study III; Movement III; Acting III Shakespeare; Dance I; Stage Combat II; Stage Combat II; and methodology seminar.

relationships.prereqs: MUSC812; and permission of ARHU-School of Music department.

MUSC830P.name: Doctoral Seminar in Music Literature
MUSC830P.description: An analytical survey of the literature of music: keyboard music; vocal music; string music; wind instrument music; required of all candidates for the D.M.A. Degree in literature-performance.

relationships.prereqs: Must have completed at least twelve hours in music history and literature.

MUSC830S.name: Doctoral Seminar in Music Literature
MUSC830S.description: An analytical survey of the literature of music: keyboard music; vocal music; string music; wind instrument music; required of all candidates for the D.M.A. Degree in literature-performance.

relationships.prereqs: Must have completed at least twelve hours in music history and literature.

MUSC830W.name: Doctoral Seminar in Music Literature
MUSC830W.description: An analytical survey of the literature of music: keyboard music; vocal music; string music; wind instrument music; required of all candidates for the D.M.A. Degree in literature-performance.

relationships.prereqs: Must have completed at least twelve hours in music history and literature.

NACS640.name: Foundational Readings Seminar
NACS640.description: An introduction to the breadth of research in Neuroscience and Cognitive Science. Faculty will present papers to provide historical context and introduction to important issues in the fields of their research.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of instructor; and must be in Neurosciences and Cognitive Sciences (Doctoral) program.

NACS641.name: Introduction to Neurosciences
NACS641.description: Detailed examination of neurophysiology and sensorimotor systems.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of instructor.

NACS728F.name: Selected Topics in Neuroscience and Cognitive Science; Introduction to Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging

NACS728J.name: Selected Topics in Neuroscience and Cognitive Science; Neurobiology of Chemosensory Systems

NACS728X.name: Selected Topics in Neuroscience and Cognitive Science; Development of the Social Brain

NAVY100.name: Introduction to Naval Science
NAVY100.description: Introduction to the naval profession and concepts of sea power. Major topics explored are the mission, strategy, organization, and descriptions of the U.S. Navy and Marine Corps. Students will gain a basic understanding of warfighting capabilities, required leadership skills, training and education, and the duties and responsibilities of a U.S. Navy and Marine Corps Junior Officer. The student will learn Naval courtesy and customs, military justice, and nomenclature as well as the professional competencies required to become a naval officer.

NAVY200.name: Leadership and Management
NAVY200.description: Introductory course designed to familiarize students with the theories, processes, and behaviors that enable effective leadership and managerial competence. Students will engage in analytical discussions, review leadership development and education, and Navy/Marine Corps-based case study discussions in order to develop their understanding of personal strengths, values and growth opportunities in the context of team, group and organizational leadership.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of UGST-Navy ROTC.
relationships.additional_info: Priority enrollment will be given to students enrolled in the NROTC program.

NAVY300.name: Naval Ship Systems I (Engineering)
NAVY300.description: Introduces the student to a comprehensive fundamental understanding of United States naval engineering principles and systems.  Topics include thermodynamics, incompressible fluid flow, electrical theory, hydraulics and pneumatics, power train components, fluid/lube oil systems, desalination, fundamentals of nuclear power, propulsion systems (internal combustion, gas turbines, and steam), electrical distribution, ship stability and control and damage control. Students will also examine case studies to apply and analyze course topics within naval ships systems contexts.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of UGST-Navy ROTC.
relationships.additional_info: Priority enrollment will be given to students enrolled in the NROTC program. Recommended: MATH140 and MATH141.

NAVY400.name: Naval Operations and Seamanship
NAVY400.description: Capstone course for senior NROTC Navy-option midshipmen in advanced navigation, communications, naval operations, and naval warfare. Students learn through simulation in a computer classroom known as the Maritime Skills Simulator (MSS), in addition to lectures, discussions, and qualitative and quantitative tests/examinations. Students will engage in discussions regarding the moral and ethical responsibilities or military leaders, as well as the essential attributes of character required for effective leadership.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of UGST-Navy ROTC.
relationships.additional_info: Priority enrollment will be given to students enrolled in the NROTC program. Recommended: NAVY201.

NEUR200.name: Introduction to Neuroscience
NEUR200.description: In an evolutionary sense, the job of the nervous system is to produce, control, and coordinate behaviors that help an animal survive and reproduce. Neuroscience is the study of how the nervous system does that. Provides a broad introduction to neuroscience, always keeping the behavioral consequences in view.

relationships.prereqs: Minimum grade of C- in BSCI170 and BSCI171.
relationships.additional_info: Cross-listed with: PSYC202.

NEUR305.name: Neural Systems and Circuits
NEUR305.description: Overview of the fundamental principles underlying the systems and circuits of the human nervous system, with a focus on cognitive processes and how these systems interact. Students will engage in the analysis of case studies, apply their knowledge of the neural circuitry to explain everyday phenomena, hypothesize ways to further investigate the nervous system, and propose how knowledge of  neural circuits can be used in human society and the resulting implications.

relationships.prereqs: Minimum grade of C- in MATH120 or higher MATH course; and a minimum grade of C- in NEUR200 or BSCI353; or equivalent.

NEUR306.name: Cellular and Molecular Neuroscience
NEUR306.description: Students will gain an appreciation of neuroscience as the nexus of chemistry, physics, and biology. Additionally, they will gain an understanding of how: both individual and networks of neurons function as variable electrical circuits; our nervous systems transduce signals from the outside world and sets-off molecular cascades; the behavior of a neuron can be changed and or remain the same in response to changing variables.  Techniques used to study the nervous system at a cellular and molecular level will be discussed.

relationships.coreqs: Must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in PHYS132 or equivalent course.
relationships.prereqs: Earning C- or higher in NEUR200 or BSCI330.

NEUR329.name: Instructional Assistance Practicum
NEUR329.description: Repeatable to 9 credits.  Students serve as instructional assistants in selected undergraduate neuroscience courses. Roles and responsibilities and pre/co-requisites are determined on a course- specific basis and approved by the Program Curriculum Committee.

relationships.additional_info: Course not acceptable toward major requirements in the Neuroscience.

NEUR379.name: Special Topics: Research in Neuroscience
NEUR379.description: Recommended: At least a 3.0 neuroscience track GPA and no records of academic misconduct.  Repeatable to 12 credits. Research and/or integrated reading in a topic related to neuroscience, under the direction and close supervision of a member of the University of Maryland faculty.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of Neuroscience Program.

NEUR398H.name: Neuroscience Honors Seminar
NEUR398H.description: Repeatable to 4 credits. This seminar provides an opportunity for the honors students to share their research projects and sharpen their communication skills through presentations, discussions, and peer-review thesis writing. Guest speakers will be invited to provide additional information and insights into various topics in professional development practice, graduate school info and application, etc.

relationships.coreqs: NEUR379, NEUR479, or equivalent research credit with instructor permission.
relationships.prereqs: NEUR200.
relationships.restrictions: Permission of department.

NEUR405.name: Neuroscience Laboratory
NEUR405.description: Students will utilize neurophysiological techniques to examine fundamental principles of  neurons and neural circuits. This course will reinforce content from prerequisite NEUR courses. Students will also strengthen skills in experimental design and scientific writing.

relationships.prereqs: NEUR306 or BSCI353; and PHYS132.
relationships.additional_info: Recommended: NEUR305. Cross-listed with: BSCI455. Students must pay a $40 laboratory materials fee.

NEUR479.name: Advanced Research in Neuroscience
NEUR479.description: Recommended: Minimum neuroscience track GPA of 3.0.  Repeatable to 12 credits. Research and/or integrated reading in neuroscience under the direction and close supervision of a faculty member.

relationships.prereqs: Complete at least 3 credits of NEUR379 (or equivalent) with the same faculty member as NEUR479 credit.
relationships.restrictions: Permission of the Neuroscience Program.

NFSC100.name: Elements of Nutrition
NFSC100.description: Fundamentals of human nutrition. Nutrient requirements related to changing individual and family needs.

NFSC100H.name: Elements of Nutrition
NFSC100H.description: Fundamentals of human nutrition. Nutrient requirements related to changing individual and family needs.

relationships.additional_info: For general honors students only.

NFSC112.name: Food: Science and Technology
