Next, we cover situations in which experiments might not be possible, and show how these can be addressed through study design ex ante and ex post through analysis.

relationships.prereqs: Basic knowledge of data analysis.
relationships.restrictions: Permission of BSOS-Joint Program in Survey Methodology department.
relationships.additional_info: Familiarity with the R programming language and the RStudio IDE. Recommended: Experience in the use of SAS or STATA statistical analysis software.

SURV632.name: Cognition, Communication and Survey Measurement
SURV632.description: Major sources of survey error-such as reporting errors and nonresponse bias-from the perspective of social and cognitive psychology and related disciplines. Topics: psychology of memory and its bearing on classical survey issues (e.g., underreporting and telescoping); models of language use and their implications for the interpretation and misinterpretation of survey questions; and studies of attitudes, attitude change, and their possible application to increasing response rates and improving the measurement of opinions. Theories and findings from the social and behavioral sciences will be explored.

relationships.additional_info: SURV majors only.

SURV650.name: Economic Measurement
SURV650.description: An introduction to the field of economic measurement. Sound economic data are of critical importance to policymakers, the business community, and others. Emphasis is placed on the economic concepts that underlie key economic statistics and the translation of those concepts into operational measures. Topics addressed include business survey sampling; the creation of business survey sampling frames; the collection of data from businesses; employment and earnings statistics; price statistics; output and productivity measures; the national accounts; and the statistical uses of administrative data. Lectures and course readings assume prior exposure to the tools of economic analysis.

relationships.prereqs: Must have completed a course in intermediate microeconomics.
relationships.additional_info: Pre-taped lectures will be available for students to watch in advance of the scheduled class time. They will meet live via Webex for a weekly one-hour discussion.

SURV665.name: Introduction to Real World Data Management
SURV665.description: Data is omnipresent in the contemporary world coming in different shapes and sized: from survey data to found data. In order to make use of such data through analysis it is necessary first to import and clean it. This is often one of the most time consuming and difficult parts of data analysis. In this course you will learn both the conceptual steps needed in preparing data for analysis as well as the practical skills to do this. The course will cover all the essential skills needed to prepare data be it survey data, administrative data or found data.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of BSOS-Joint Program in Survey Methodology department.
relationships.additional_info: Basic knowledge of R and prior experience working with data is required for success in this course.

SURV699.name: Special Topics in Survey Methodology; Reading in Survey Methodology

SURV706.name: General Linear Models
SURV706.description: The main focus of this course lies on the introduction to statistical models and estimators beyond linear regression useful to social and economic scientists. It provides an overview of generalized linear models (GLM) that encompass non-normal response distributions to model functions of the mean. GLMs thus relate the expected mean E(Y) of the dependent variable to the predictor variables via a specific link function. This link function permits the expected mean to be non-linearly related to the predictor variables. Examples for GLMs are the logistic regression, regressions for ordinal data, or regression models for count data. GLMs are generally estimated by use of maximum likelihood estimation. The course thus not only introduces GLMs but starts with an introduction to the principle of maximum likelihood estimation.

relationships.restrictions: Must have permission of BSOS-Joint Program in Survey Methodology.
relationships.additional_info: Recommended: Sound understanding of Linear Regression Models, Calculus and Linear Algebra.

SURV720.name: Total Survey Error and Data Quality I
SURV720.description: Total error structure of sample survey data, reviewing current research findings on the magnitudes of different error sources, design features that affect their magnitudes, and interrelationships among the errors. Coverage, nonresponse, sampling, measurement, and postsurvey processing errors. For each error source reviewed, social science theories about its causes and statistical models estimating the error source are described. Empirical studies from the survey methodological literature are reviewed to illustrate the relative magnitudes of error in different designs. Emphasis on aspects of the survey design necessary to estimate different error sources. Relationships to show how attempts to control one error source may increase another source. Attempts to model total survey error will be presented.

relationships.prereqs: SURV625.
relationships.restrictions: Permission of instructor.
relationships.additional_info: It runs concurrently with the University of Michigan course.

SURV726.name: Multiple Imputation
SURV726.description: This course will provide a detailed introduction to multiple imputation, a convenient strategy for dealing with (item) nonresponse in surveys. We will motivate the concept and illustrate why multiple imputation should generally be preferred over single imputation methods. The main focus of the course will be on strategies to generate (multiple) imputations and how to deal with common problems when applying the methods for large scale surveys. We will also discuss various options for assessing the quality of the imputations. All concepts will be demonstrated using software illustrations in R.

relationships.prereqs: Be comfortable with generalized linear models and basic probability theory through coursework or work experience; and familiarity with the statistical software R; and must have completed Surv 725 Item Nonresponse and Imputation or be familiar with the content through relevant work experience.
relationships.restrictions: Permission of BSOS-Joint Program in Survey Methodology department.

SURV727.name: Fundamentals of Computing and Data Display
SURV727.description: The first part of this course provides an introduction to web scraping and APIs for gathering data from the web and then discusses how to store and manage (big) data from diverse sources efficiently. The second part of the course demonstrates techniques for exploring and finding patterns in (non-standard) data, with a focus on data visualization.  The course focuses on R as the primary computing environment, with excursus into SQL and Big Data processing tools.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major within the BSOS-Joint Program in Survey Methodology department; or permission of BSOS-Joint Program in Survey Methodology department.
relationships.additional_info: Students without any R knowledge are encouraged to work through one or more R web tutorials prior or during the first weeks of the course.   It runs concurrently with the University of Michigan course.

SURV740.name: Fundamentals of Inference
SURV740.description: Focuses on the fundamentals of statistical inference in the finite population setting. Overview and review fundamental ideas of making inferences about populations.  Basic principles of probability sampling; focus on differences between making predictions and making inferences; explore the differences between randomized study designs and observational studies; consider model-based vs. design-based analytic approaches; review techniques designed to improve efficiency using auxiliary information; and consider non-probability sampling and related inferential techniques.

relationships.prereqs: SURV410 and SURV420; or (SURV615 and SURV616); or permission of Instructor required.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major within the BSOS-Joint Program in Survey Methodology department; or permission of BSOS-Joint Program in Survey Methodology department.
relationships.additional_info: It runs concurrently with the University of Michigan course.

SURV753.name: Machine Learning II
SURV753.description: Social scientists and survey researchers are confronted with an increasing number of new data sources such as apps and sensors that often result in (para)data structures that are difficult to handle with traditional modeling methods. At the same time, advances in the field of machine learning (ML) have created an array of flexible methods and tools that can be used to tackle a variety of modeling problems. Against this background, this course discusses advanced ML concepts such as cross validation, class imbalance, Boosting and Stacking as well as key approaches for facilitating model tuning and performing feature selection.  In this course we also introduce additional machine learning methods including Support Vector Machines, Extra-Trees and LASSO among others. The course aims to illustrate these concepts, methods and approaches from a social science perspective. Furthermore, the course covers techniques for extracting patterns from unstructured data as well as interpreting and presenting results from machine learning algorithms. Code examples will be provided using the statistical programming language R.

relationships.prereqs: SURV751; or comparable knowledge or experience.
relationships.additional_info: Recommended: Familiarity with the statistical programming language R.

SURV829.name: Doctoral Research Seminar in Survey Methodology

TDPS201.name: Introduction to Technical Production
TDPS201.description: Students are provided with an overview of topics related to the technical production of theatre and dance including: scenic, prop and costume construction, lighting, sound and video execution and management structures.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in a major within the ARHU-Dance department; or must be in a major within the ARHU-Theatre department.
relationships.additional_info: Students must pay a $25.00 lab fee.

TDPS258C.name: Special Topics in Introductory Performing Arts; Cultural Institutions in the United States

TDPS358T.name: Special Topics in Intermediate Performing Arts; Technology for Performing Arts: Theory and Practice
TDPS358T.description: Students must pay a $25 lab fee. An introduction to experimental technology systems, and how to adapt them for use in live performance. Students will be introduced to a variety of new media tools.

TDPS408F.name: Seminar in Theory and Practice of Critical Difference; Black Femme Playwrights in Chocolate City

TDPS458F.name: Special Topics in Advanced Performing Arts; Aesthetics of Collaboration in Performance: Theory & Practice
TDPS458F.description: This class offers practical methods for the creation and analysis of collaborative performance projects. Taking for granted that all performance works engage collaboration, this class is organized around themes of media, materiality, site-specificity, and working within and against systems. These themes are the organizing principles for student projects, as well as exemplary works of theory and performance. Finally, this class, being about collaboration, looks at strategies for working together, and carries with it an ethic of kindness, constructive critique, and mutual support.

THET110.name: Introduction to the Theatre
THET110.description: In the age of pop music and blockbuster films, of memes and viral videos, we often forget that theatre was one of the original forms of popular entertainment.   We will focus on theatre practitioners including actors, directors, designers and backstage personnel to understand how theatre is produced.  We will also consider popular entertainment in Europe and America, with a particular focus on musical theatre and Broadway to explore how theatre communicates, resonates, and remains relevant to all audiences.

THET116.name: Fundamentals of Theatrical Design
THET116.description: Examines theatre as an environmental art that is realized through collaboration between set, costume, and lighting designers.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of ARHU-School of Theatre, Dance & Performance Studies department.
relationships.additional_info: Students must pay a $25.00 lab fee.

THET222.name: Foundations of Acting and Performance
THET222.description: Students will become familiar with the tools and process of acting through the discipline of acting exercises, analyzing character and performing. Students will research various theatre artists that have contributed  to the  acting process. Through monologue and scene work students will learn listening skills, communicative, collaborative and embodiment skills and will learn how to use the self in the imaginative process and research. And, most importantly, students will learn creative process through practice.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of ARHU-School of Theatre, Dance & Performance Studies department.
relationships.additional_info: Students must pay a $25.00 lab fee.

THET223.name: Text and Context in Western Theatre
THET223.description: Introduction to the analysis and critique of the play script.  Students will have the opportunity to read, analyze, and interpret western dramatic literature from a range of periods and styles.  Texts are analyzed from a variety of theatrical analytical perspectives, with an eye towards choices theatre artists must make in the creation of a theatrical production.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of ARHU-School of Theatre, Dance & Performance Studies department.

THET274.name: Introduction to Stage Management
THET274.description: Familiarization with the techniques and skills required of a Stage Manager in a theatrical production, including organization, production meetings, rehearsals, tech and running a show. The outcome at the conclusion of the course is the ability to function as an Assistant Stage Manager in a supervised situation.

relationships.prereqs: THET114 or TDPS201; and permission of ARHU-School of Theatre, Dance & Performance Studies department.
relationships.additional_info: Students must pay a $25.00 lab fee.

THET285.name: The Art of Communication and Presentation
THET285.description: An introduction to the fundamental practice and theory of public speaking and oral communication using theatrical techniques of both performance and the craft of storytelling.

relationships.credit_granted_for: COMM107, COMM200, INAG110, JOUR130, or THET285.

THET286.name: Experiential Learning I
THET286.description: Introductory internship in theatre. Constructed to help students in their sophomore year gain practical experience in a supportive work environment in the theatre. Student must research and propose internship to a Faculty Advisor and Internship Venue.

relationships.prereqs: THET222, THET223, and THET116.
relationships.additional_info: And THET114; or TDPS201. And permission of ARHU-School of Theatre, Dance & Performance Studies department.

THET287.name: Subversive Cultures and Performance
THET287.description: Every society has rebels - those who refuse to conform to the mainstream's rigid rules, aesthetics, and beliefs. From unruly skateboarders, punk rockers, bohemian poets, and radical theater performers, to national revolutionary movements and brick-throwing anarchists - such groups form niches that are defined by their exclusion from society. We will look at how their beliefs and actions fit into a particular historical context, and how their actions drive social change.

THET293.name: Black Theatre and Performance I
THET293.description: Thematic and historical survey of African-American drama from the late nineteenth century to the 1960s. Emphasis on sociopolitical context, thematic thrust, issues, styles, the aesthetic reflected in the work, impact on African-American and general theatre audiences.

THET310.name: Voice for the Actor I
THET310.description: Freeing the natural voice. In-depth experience of connection of actor's voice to thought, impulse and emotion. Tools for releasing tension, increasing resonance and range, and refining articulation will be explored.

relationships.prereqs: THET116, THET222, THET223, and TDPS201; and must Interview; and permission of ARHU-School of Theatre, Dance & Performance Studies department.
relationships.restrictions: Sophomore standing or higher.
relationships.additional_info: Students must pay a $25.00 lab fee.

THET325.name: Actor's Process I
THET325.description: Focus on use of self in creating character. Tools employed include decision-making and use of imagery, personalization, objectives, adjectives, and verbs.

relationships.prereqs: Must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in THET310; or permission of Instructor.
relationships.additional_info: And must audition; and permission of ARHU-School of Theatre, Dance & Performance Studies department.Students must pay a $25.00 lab fee.

THET326.name: Viewpoints
THET326.description: Viewpoints is a movement-based performance course for students who already have a  foundation in the basics of acting and/or dance.  The Viewpoints are a set of tools and vocabulary; using 9 categories of time and space, students will fully explore the possibilities of using their physical instruments (the body) to their fullest on stage.

relationships.prereqs: THET222, THET223, THET116, and TDPS201; and permission of ARHU-School of Theatre, Dance & Performance Studies department.
relationships.additional_info: Students must pay a $25 lab fee.

THET328L.name: Special Topics in Intermediate Theatre and Performance; Acting for Digital and Live Performance

THET330.name: Play Directing I
THET330.description: A lecture-laboratory course dealing with the techniques of coordinating, designing and guiding the production of a script through to performance. Study and practice in stage composition, movement, pacing, script and character analysis, and rehearsal routines. Emphasis on methods of communicating a script to an audience.

relationships.prereqs: THET222, THET223, and THET116.
relationships.restrictions: Junior standing or higher.
relationships.additional_info: And THET114; or TDPS201. And permission of ARHU-School of Theatre, Dance & Performance Studies department.

THET340.name: Playwriting I
THET340.description: Will introduce students to the art of playwriting through exploratory writing exercises, the reading of successful plays, the development of new short scripts, how to make theatrical choices, and how to use the six elements of storytelling.

relationships.prereqs: THET222, THET223, THET116, and TDPS201.
relationships.restrictions: Permission of ARHU-School of Theatre, Dance & Performance Studies department.

THET351.name: Musical Theatre I
THET351.description: An introduction for students interested in developing their skills with musical theatre, specifically the work of the actor interpreting songs and text in musicals. With a primary focus on American Musical Theatre repertoire, students will prepare and present various solo, duet, and group numbers.

THET371.name: Scenic Design I
THET371.description: A study of design theory and style. Methods and techniques of coordination of all elements of scenic design for theatre.

relationships.prereqs: THET222, THET223, and THET116; and (THET114; or TDPS201).
relationships.additional_info: Or permission of ARHU-School of Theatre, Dance & Performance Studies department.

THET377.name: Lighting Design I
THET377.description: A study of the theories of electrification, instruments, design, color, and control for the stage. Practical work on productions.

relationships.prereqs: THET222, THET223, and THET116.
relationships.additional_info: And THET114; or TDPS201; or permission of ARHU-School of Theatre, Dance & Performance Studies department.Students must pay a $25 lab fee.

THET380.name: Sound Design
THET380.description: Theatre Sound Design is a first course in designing sound for stage productions.

relationships.prereqs: THET116.
relationships.restrictions: Sophomore standing or higher.
relationships.additional_info: And THET114; or TDPS201; or permission of ARHU-School of Theatre, Dance & Performance Studies department. Students must pa a $25 lab fee.

THET385.name: Media Design
THET385.description: Focuses on learning the grammar and conceptual thinking behind multimedia design for live performance.  Students will learn how our new multimedia tools can enhance the sense of liveness as well as explore the different ways in which technology can be implemented into preproduction thinking, rehearsal experimenting, and ultimately, effective use in performance.

relationships.prereqs: THET222, THET223, THET116, and TDPS201; and permission of ARHU-School of Theatre, Dance & Performance Studies department.
relationships.additional_info: Students must pay a $25 lab fee.

THET386.name: Experiential Learning
THET386.description: Restriction: Junior standing or higher; and permission of ARHU-School of Theatre, Dance & Performance Studies department.

THET390.name: History of Theatre I
THET390.description: The history of Western theatre from its origins in classical antiquity through the mid-seventeenth century with emphasis on plays and playwrights, architecture and decor, acting and costuming, and significant personalities. Includes explorations of interrelationships between Western theatre and the theatre of other cultures.

relationships.prereqs: Permission of ARHU-School of Theatre, Dance & Performance Studies department.

THET408C.name: Seminar: Theory and Performance Studies; Digital Narratives: Representation and Resistance

THET408K.name: Seminar: Theory and Performance Studies; Installation, Curation, and Performance as Research
THET408K.description: A combination of discussion and workshop, this seminar will involve a hands-on examination of the principles and strategies involved in: 1) Constructing art installations. 2) Curating exhibits. 2) Presenting Researchin a performative format. Our work will be located at the intersection of these three forms with the specific objective of cultivating the critical tools of what we will call "three dimensional thinking." With thisobjective in mind, each student will work on a semester-long research project, which they will present in a "performative format" at the end of the semester.

THET411.name: Voice for the Actor II
THET411.description: Learn the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) and apply to exploration of sound and language. Designed to increase voice and speech awareness, and create a base knowledge from which to approach any accent or dialect.

relationships.prereqs: THET324 or THET325; and must audition; and permission of ARHU-School of Theatre, Dance & Performance Studies department.
relationships.restrictions: Junior standing or higher.

THET428A.name: Special Topics in Advanced Theatre and Performance; Advanced Sound Design
THET428A.description: Students must have completed THET380; or permission of instructor. Students must pay a $25 lab fee.

THET428L.name: Special Topics in Advanced Theatre and Performance; Advanced Techniques Lighting Design: Programming
THET428L.description: Required pre-requisite THET377. Students must pay a $25 lab fee.

THET477.name: Design Studio in Lighting
THET477.description: Designed for students who have successfully completed THET377 and wish to further develop their lighting design skills. Emphasis is on theoretical design of productions and realized light lab projects. Particular design projects will vary.

relationships.prereqs: THET377; and permission of ARHU-School of Theatre, Dance & Performance Studies department.
relationships.additional_info: Jointly offered with THET659.  Credit     only granted for: THET477 or THET659.Students must pay a $25 lab fee.

THET481.name: Theatre Graphics II: Computer Assisted Design
THET481.description: Study and practical application of computer generated graphical design for use in theatrical production.

relationships.prereqs: THET114 or TDPS201; and THET116; and permission of ARHU-Theatre department.
relationships.restrictions: Sophomore standing or higher.
relationships.additional_info: Students must pay a $25 course fee.

THET499B.name: Independent Study; Figure Drawing
THET499B.description: Students must pay a $25 lab fee

relationships.restrictions: Must be a graduate student in a Theatre program.
relationships.additional_info: Only students in the doctoral program may register for THET700.

THET606.name: Teaching Theatre
THET606.description: Strategies and materials for teaching a typical introductory course in theatre, with emphasis on specific problems of classroom instruction (e.g., creating a supportive climate, promoting active learning by students, constructing appropriate tests, adapting methods to content, and resolving discipline problems).

THET608F.name: Seminar: Theory and Performance Studies; Aesthetics of Collaboration in Performance: Theory & Practice
THET608F.description: This class offers practical methods for the creation and analysis of collaborative performance projects. Taking for granted that all performance works engage collaboration, this class is organized around themes of media, materiality, site-specificity, and working within and against systems. These themes are the organizing principles for student projects, as well as exemplary works of theory and performance. Finally, this class, being about collaboration, looks at strategies for working together, and carries with it an ethic of kindness, constructive critique, and mutual support.

THET608I.name: Seminar: Theory and Performance Studies; Auto-Ethnographies

THET649.name: Advanced Design Studio in Costume
THET649.description: Students must pay a $25 course fee. Class is for First, Second, and Third Year MFA students.

THET659.name: Advanced Design Studio in Lighting
THET659.description: Students must pay a $25 course fee.

THET669B.name: Independent Study; Studio Art for Scenic Designers
THET669B.description: Students mus pa a $25 lab fee.

THET669R.name: Independent Study; Advanced Rendering
THET669R.description: Students must pay a $25 lab fee.

THET669T.name: Independent Study; Theatre Graphics II: Computer Assisted Design
THET669T.description: Students must pay a $25 course fee.

THET679.name: Advanced Design Studio in Multimedia and Projection Design
THET679.description: Students must pay a $25 lab fee.

THET698G.name: Seminar: Theatre History; History of Theatre to 1700

relationships.restrictions: Must be a graduate student in a Theatre program.
relationships.additional_info: Only students in the doctoral program may register for THET700.

THET711.name: Critical Theory
THET711.description: A doctoral methods course. Major developments in modern and postmodern critical theory with particular emphasis on application to the fields of Theatre and Performance Studies.

relationships.prereqs: THET700.
relationships.additional_info: Recommended: THET712.

TLPL101.name: Inquiry Approach to Teaching STEM (Step 1)
TLPL101.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL101.description: Explore STEM teaching and learning and classroom complexity, and develop teaching skills through discussion-based, collaborative class sessions, and experiences in local schools. To explore/understand the fundamentals of inquiry teaching, students will observe, plan and teach student-centered lessons.

relationships.additional_info: Students must allow for a three-hour window between 7:45 AM and 3:15 PM in their schedule for field experiences in a local school 3-4 times during the semester.  A background check is required and will be facilitated by the Terrapin Teacher program coordinator.

TLPL102.name: Inquiry Teaching of STEM in Middle School
TLPL102.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL102.description: Second course in the Terrapin Teachers teacher preparation sequence. Students gain field experience and continue exploring teaching as a career by conducting teacher observations, and planning and implementing lessons in local, high-need middle school classrooms. Students work closely with UM master teachers to build upon the inquiry-based teaching practices developed in TLPL 101.  Students work with mathematics and science curricula while attending to state and district standards, in order to develop and enact lessons that are responsive to students' reasoning in math and science.

relationships.prereqs: Must have completed TLPL101.
relationships.additional_info: Attendance at each class session will be vital to student success in the course.     To complete the observations and lessons, students must allow a three hour block of time during the local middle school operational hours from 7:45 am to 3:15 pm.  A background check is required.

TLPL206.name: Forbidden Books: Censorship of Children's and Young Adult Literature
TLPL206.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL206.description: Critically examines the history of censorship from Plato to Fake News with a focus on contemporary censorship analyzed through historical, political, ethical, moral, philosophical, and socio-cultural perspectives. The course considers the evolving definition of censorship, the common elements found in all forms of censorship, the rationalizations and arguments for censorship, and the consequences and unintended results of censorship.

TLPL250.name: Historical and Philosophical Perspectives on Education
TLPL250.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL250.description: An examination of illustrative historical and philosophical examples of the interplay of ideas and events in the shaping of educational aims and practices from ancient cultures to modern technological societies.

TLPL251.name: Community, Learners, and Classroom Climate
TLPL251.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL251.description: An exploration of teaching in public schools, grades 1-12: student diversity, societal changes, and the expectations of teachers and public schools. Three hour per week field component.

relationships.additional_info: Two-hour seminar each week on campus plus a four-hour lab each week which includes three hours in a local public school classroom and commute time to and from campus. Most schools are within a 20-minute commute with more travel time needed if public transportation is required. Allow for travel time between on-campus coursework and the off-campus public school experience. All schools require a Prince Georges County Public School security process that includes fingerprinting and a background check at an additional cost, prior to the start of the experience.

TLPL288D.name: Special Problems in Education; Developmental Heuristics
TLPL288D.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL288P.name: Special Problems in Education; Experiential Learning of Geoscience: An Agency and School Visit Experience
TLPL288P.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL298.name: Special Problems in Education
TLPL298.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL305B.name: Curriculum and Instruction Cluster
TLPL305B.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL305M.name: Curriculum and Instruction Cluster
TLPL305M.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL312.name: Curriculum and Instruction in Elementary Education: Mathematics
TLPL312.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL312.description: Materials and procedures to help children sense arithmetical meanings and relationships. Development of an understanding of the number system and arithmetical processes. Includes laboratory/field experiences.

relationships.prereqs: TLPL361.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Elementary Education program; and minimum cumulative GPA of 2.
relationships.additional_info: 75; Or permission of EDUC-Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership department.

TLPL321.name: Curriculum and Instruction in Elementary Education: Science
TLPL321.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL321.description: Objectives, methods, materials and activities for teaching science in the elementary school; emphasis on teaching strategies which help children learn the processes and concepts of science. Includes laboratory/field experiences.

relationships.prereqs: TLPL361.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Elementary Education program; and minimum cumulative GPA of 2.
relationships.additional_info: 75; Or permission of EDUC-Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership department.

TLPL340.name: Introduction to Children's Literature and Critical Literacy
TLPL340.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL340.description: Analysis of literary materials for children and youth. Timeless and ageless books, and outstanding examples of contemporary publishing. Evaluation of the contributions of individual authors, illustrators and children's book awards.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Elementary Education program; or must be a Pre-Education Major.

TLPL341.name: Assessing Language and Literacy Development in Elementary Classrooms
TLPL341.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL341.description: An exploration of the social and cognitive processes involved in reading and writing, the developmental nature of those processes, the foundational concepts associated with effective literacy assessment, a variety of formative and summative literacy assessments, and the nature of individual differences in reading and writing.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in the Elementary Education program; and permission of EDUC-Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership.

TLPL343.name: Promoting Skilled and Motivated Readers in Diverse Elementary Classrooms (Part 2)
TLPL343.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL343.description: Application of the materials, curriculum, teaching and learning practices and assessment methods associated with classroom reading programs designed to promote skilled and motivated readers in diverse elementary classrooms.  Teacher candidates will learn to assess and scaffold students' self-regulated literacy learning in line with students' individual needs and Maryland College and Career Ready Standards.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in the Elementary Education program; and permission of EDUC-Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership.

TLPL360.name: Foundations of Education
TLPL360.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL360.description: Social context of education and conflicts over philosophies, values, an goals that are reflected in educational institutions in our pluralistic society. Helps teachers become reflective, critical thinkers about the social and philosophical issues they face and the choices they make.

TLPL401.name: Student-Centered Curriculum and Instruction
TLPL401.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL401.description: A focus on using student-centered teaching and learning approaches in high school STEM classrooms. Students will develop and implement a multi-day series of lessons, building upon the foundations of inquiry-based practices developed in prior courses. Students will also consider the implications of cultural awareness on teaching practices broadly, as well as in the specific contexts of their fieldwork.

relationships.prereqs: Permission of instructor; and TLPL102; and must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in TLPL488M.
relationships.additional_info: Field experience for this course will require students to be available for a 2-4 hour block of time at various points throughout the semester to complete observations and teach lessons between 8:00 a.    m. and 3:30 p.m. A background check is required and will be facilitated through the Terrapin Teacher program coordinator.

TLPL403.name: Teaching and Learning High School Mathematics
TLPL403.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL403.description: Methods of teaching and assessing the high school mathematics curriculum; aligning tasks and activities to curriculum standards; lesson planning; and selection and use of technology. The course also focuses on managing large group dynamics in the high school mathematics classroom.

relationships.prereqs: Must have 2 semesters of calculus; or permission of EDUC-Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership department.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Secondary Educ: Mathematics program; and minimum cumulative GPA of 2.
relationships.additional_info: 75; Or permission of EDUC-Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership department.

TLPL407.name: Teaching and Learning Mathematics in the Elementary School, Part 2
TLPL407.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL407.description: Focuses on teaching and learning rational numbers (fractions and decimals) and developing algebraic thinking. Special emphasis will be placed on developing equitable teaching practices that enable culturally and linguistically diverse students to develop knowledge and skills that promote mathematical proficiency. Mathematical concepts: Content knowledge: rational numbers (fractions and decimals) and the four arithmetic operations, algebraic thinking, some aspects of geometry and measurement.

TLPL413.name: Teaching and Learning Middle School Mathematics
TLPL413.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL413.description: Methods of teaching and assessing the middle school mathematics curriculum. Understanding the conceptual difficulties students have in moving from whole numbers to rational numbers, additive thinking to multiplicative thinking, and arithmetic to algebra. Lesson planning and selection of technology and other materials are applied in the context of supervised tutoring of students having difficulty in middle school mathematics. Lab and field experience required.  Supervised tutoring takes place on site at a local middle school therefore TLPL413 students will be expected to travel to a local middle school for 8-10 of the class meetings.

relationships.restrictions: Minimum cumulative GPA of 2.
relationships.additional_info: 75; and permission of EDUC-Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership department.

TLPL414.name: Knowing and Learning in Mathematics and Science
TLPL414.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL414.description: Special and intensive treatment of current topics and issues in mathematics and science teaching and learning, policy and leadership. The overall goal of the course is to orient future teachers to the discourses and theories that shape what we know about how students learn math and science.

relationships.prereqs: Must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in TLPL102.

TLPL420.name: Knowledge, Reasoning, and Learning in Science
TLPL420.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL420.description: For prospective science teachers. Investigations of the nature of knowledge, reasoning, and learning in middle and secondary science. Readings from cognitive science and science education research; studies of student thinking in interview and classroom observations; analyses of curricula. Includes laboratory and field experiences.

relationships.restrictions: Minimum cumulative GPA of 2.
relationships.additional_info: 75; and permission of EDUC-Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership department.

TLPL423.name: Interdisciplinary Teaching in the Middle Grades I
TLPL423.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL423.description: For prospective middle school teachers. Studying and planning interdisciplinary instructional practices in middle school. Utilizes context and experiences from students' field placements. Use of technology and incorporation of technology into instruction.

relationships.prereqs: TLPL413 and TLPL420; or permission of instructor.
relationships.restrictions: Minimum cumulative GPA of 2.
relationships.additional_info: 75; and must be in the Middle School Teacher Education Program, major code 0804P.

TLPL425.name: Learning and Teaching in Science
TLPL425.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL425.description: Studies of student learning and instructional practices in science teaching.

relationships.prereqs: TLPL420; or permission of instructor.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Secondary Educ: Science program.

TLPL433.name: Foundations of Art Education
TLPL433.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL433.description: Introduction to the field of Art Education and the role of the visual arts in grades PreK-12 for today's diverse school populations.  The fundamental, historical and philosophic components of art education with an emphasis on arts disciplines and curriculum.  Includes a school-based practicum.  For those considering art education as a major.

relationships.restrictions: Minimum cumulative GPA of 2.

TLPL436.name: Studio Processes and Materials: 2D
TLPL436.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL436.description: A discussion/studio format used to develop skills, materials, resources and education strategies for using technology and two-dimensional art in K-12 programs.

relationships.prereqs: ARTT210.
relationships.restrictions: Minimum cumulative GPA of 2.
relationships.additional_info: 75; and permission of EDUC-Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership department; and junior standing or higher; and must not be in any of the following programs (Early Childhood Education; Elementary Education; Secondary Educ: Science; Secondary Educ: English Language Arts; Secondary Educ: Mathematics; Secondary Educ: Foreign Languages; Secondary Educ: Social Studies; Physical Education; Music Education; Special Education).

TLPL440.name: Issues in the Education of English Language Learners
TLPL440.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL440.description: Introduction to and analysis of current and historical research, practice, trends, and public policy issues in education as they relate to English language learners in K-12 and other settings.

TLPL442.name: Foundations of Literacy and Biliteracy Development
TLPL442.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL442.description: An overview of the research on literacy and biliteracy development for English learners. Specifically, the course explores the theoretical models and processes of teaching reading and writing, current literacy/biliteracy issues, assessment, and strategies for developing literacy and biliteracy skills for English learners.

TLPL443.name: Understanding Cross-Cultural Communication for Teaching English Language Learners
TLPL443.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL443.description: Theories of intercultural communication and techniques for applying them in the teaching of English as a second language (ESL) and content classes. Research and evaluation of selected aspects of a culture as basis for creating, selecting and using culturally-responsive teaching materials and methods.

TLPL445.name: Methods I: K-12 World Language Methods and Technology
TLPL445.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL445.description: The first of two sequential courses required for achieving competence i teaching a foreign language. The sequel to this course is EDCI433 (Methods II) entitled: Advanced K-12 Foreign Language Methods and Technology. EDCI410 requires on-going examination of theories relevant to language acquisition. Students will also investigate the instructional methods that reflect those theories. Lab and field experiences required.

relationships.restrictions: Minimum cumulative GPA of 2.
relationships.additional_info: 75; and permission of EDUC-Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership department.

TLPL446.name: Language Variation and Multilingualism in Elementary Classrooms
TLPL446.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL446.description: Issues in language variation and multilingualism in elementary classrooms, schools and communities with a focus on classroom practice, assessment, and policy.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Elementary Education program; and minimum cumulative GPA of 2.
relationships.additional_info: 75. Or permission of EDUC-Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership department.

TLPL447.name: Art Education Methods II
TLPL447.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL447.description: Methods II builds upon the pedagogical foundation of Methods I and provides future art teachers with the means for developing pre K-12 art lessons and unit plans for a balanced qualitative art program for today's diverse and inclusive schools and classrooms.

relationships.prereqs: TLPL435; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.
relationships.restrictions: Minimum cumulative GPA of 2.
relationships.additional_info: 75; and must be in Secondary Educ: Art program.

TLPL450.name: Advanced K-12 World Language Methods and Technology
TLPL450.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL450.description: Teaches advanced best practices for effective foreign language instruction. Topics include: using authentic assessment and materials, applying national standards, teaching writing and culture, motivating students, providing strategy instruction, infusing technology, preparing for K-12 employment, and creating a professional portfolio.

relationships.prereqs: TLPL445.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Secondary Educ: Foreign Languages program; and minimum cumulative GPA of 2.
relationships.additional_info: 75. Or permission of EDUC-Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership department.    EDCI438 must be taken concurrently with EDCI433.

TLPL451.name: Teaching and Learning in Secondary Education: English
TLPL451.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL451.description: An introduction for prospective middle and secondary English teachers into the basic issues, concepts, orientations, and processes that shape the teaching of English for diverse students in schools. Candidates explore their own perspectives in relation to local and national trends and develop basic teaching understanding and skills through on-campus seminars, teaching laboratory experiences, and guided field experiences. Students should reserve one full day or two half days per week for field experience.

TLPL456.name: Teaching Writing
TLPL456.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL456.description: Examines current theory, research, best practice, curricula and materials for teaching written communication in grades K-12. Focuses on analytical, argumentative, informative/explanatory, literary analysis, narrative, descriptive, and research writing. Emphasizes instructional planning, assessment, writer problem-solving strategies, information search, development, organization and style appropriate to task, purpose and audience for both non-digital and digital text. English Language Learner and special needs pupil issues considered.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Secondary Educ: English Language Arts program; and minimum cumulative GPA of 2.
relationships.additional_info: 75. Or permission of EDUC-Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership department.

TLPL457.name: Literature for Adolescents
TLPL457.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL457.description: Reading and analysis of fiction and nonfiction; methods for critically assessing quality and appeal; current theory and methods of instruction; research on response to literature; curriculum design and selection of books.

relationships.restrictions: Minimum cumulative GPA of 2.
relationships.additional_info: 75; and permission of EDUC-Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership department.

TLPL462.name: Reading in the Secondary School
TLPL462.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL462.description: Provides secondary school teachers with understanding the need for and approaches to teaching students to read and learn from content area texts.

relationships.restrictions: Minimum cumulative GPA of 2.
relationships.additional_info: 75; and must be in one of the following programs (Middle School Education; Secondary Educ: Science; Secondary Educ: English Language Arts; Secondary Educ: Mathematics; Secondary Educ: Foreign Languages; Secondary Educ: Social Studies; Secondary Educ: Art) ; and permission of department required for post-baccalaureate students.

TLPL470.name: Knowledge, Reasoning, and Learning in Secondary Social Studies
TLPL470.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL470.description: An exploration of the nature of knowledge and reasoning in social studies disciplines as well as how students learn social studies. Assessment and investigation of students' conceptions and misconceptions as well as their disciplinary thinking. Implications for teaching and initial lesson design are explored through on-campus seminars as well as guided field experiences. Students should reserve a regular half-day per week for the field experience in local schools. This course is required for admission to the secondary social studies double major.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of EDUC-Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership department; and minimum cumulative GPA of 2.

TLPL471.name: Curriculum, Teaching, and Assessment in Secondary Social Studies
TLPL471.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL471.description: An exploration of curriculum development, teaching, and assessment in secondary history/social studies. Focus on identifying students' conceptions of social studies topics and designing lessons that advance students' disciplinary thinking and understanding.

relationships.prereqs: TLPL470.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Secondary Educ: Social Studies program; and minimum cumulative GPA of 2.
relationships.additional_info: 75. Or permission of EDUC-Center for Learning & Educational Technology.

TLPL475.name: Equitable Classrooms
TLPL475.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL475.description: An exploration and application of major theoretical frameworks surrounding equity and critical pedagogy. Creating habits of mind that help teachers see all students as capable of achieving at high levels. Draws on the concurrent field experience.

relationships.prereqs: TLPL252, TLPL413, and TLPL420.
relationships.restrictions: Minimum cumulative GPA of 2.
relationships.additional_info: 75; and must be in Middle School Education program.

TLPL477.name: Teaching Academically, Culturally, and Linguistically Diverse Students in Middle School and Secondary Education
TLPL477.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL477.description: Instruction on methods of teaching academically, culturally, and linguistically diverse students in middle school and secondary classrooms.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in the teacher education program; or permission of EDUC-Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership department.

TLPL478A.name: Professional Seminar in Education; Art Education
TLPL478A.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL478G.name: Professional Seminar in Education; Elementary Education
TLPL478G.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL479A.name: Field Experiences in Education; Art Education
TLPL479A.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL479B.name: Field Experiences in Education; Secondary Social Studies Education
TLPL479B.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL479C.name: Field Experiences in Education; English Education
TLPL479C.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL479C.description: Secondary English/speech/drama education majors only. Students must reserve one full day per week for observation.

TLPL479D.name: Field Experiences in Education; Secondary Mathematics Education
TLPL479D.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL479E.name: Field Experiences in Education; Middle School Education
TLPL479E.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL479F.name: Field Experiences in Education; Science Education
TLPL479F.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL479G.name: Field Experiences in Education; Tutoring
TLPL479G.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL479G.description: Purchase of LiveText ($139) is required for this course. A fee for fingerprinting may be required.

TLPL479J.name: Field Experiences in Education; Second Language Education
TLPL479J.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL479L.name: Field Experiences in Education; Agriculture Education
TLPL479L.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL481.name: Embracing Diversity in the Classroom Community
TLPL481.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL481.description: An exploration of the richness and complexity of student diversity that teacher candidates will encounter in K-12 classrooms. Students will engage in critical reflection around diversity and equity issues.

relationships.restrictions: Admission to teacher education program; or permission of EDUC-Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership department.

TLPL488B.name: Special Topics in Education; Teaching Academically, Culturally and Linguistically Divers e Students in Secondary Education
TLPL488B.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL488J.name: Special Topics in Education; STEM Participatory Action Research Project
TLPL488J.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL489.name: Internship in Education
TLPL489.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL489G.name: Internship in Education; TEACHING RESIDENCY
TLPL489G.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL489G.description: Students must pay a $375.00 lab fee.

TLPL489Z.name: Internship in Education; Elementary Education Residency
TLPL489Z.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL498.name: Special Problems in Education
TLPL498.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL610.name: Trends in Mathematics Education
TLPL610.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL610.description: Recent developments in educational thinking and practice which have affected the curriculum in mathematics.

TLPL632.name: Understanding and Teaching Aesthetics
TLPL632.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL632.description: Critical investigation of art, and curriculum implications.

TLPL637.name: Teaching for Equity in Bilingual/Dual Language Immersion Programs
TLPL637.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL637.description: Focuses on how educators apply and reflect on teaching, learning and school practices aimed to achieve educational equity in dual language programs, including bilingual, two way, and one-way immersion K-12. This course will include instruction, discussion, and materials in a LOTE (Language other than English) to model bilingual instruction.

TLPL644.name: Foundations of Reading
TLPL644.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL644.description: Broad and comprehensive overview of reading and literacy and factors that may influence effective reading practices such as instruction, classroom environment and individual differences. Focus on different knowledge domains and traditions of inquiry related to reading and reading instruction.

relationships.prereqs: EDCI362; or TLPL462; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

TLPL645.name: Content Area Reading
TLPL645.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL645.description: Research-based strategies for improving reading to learn in the content areas (K-12).

relationships.prereqs: EDCI362; or TLPL462; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

TLPL647.name: Diagnostic Reading Assessment and Instruction
TLPL647.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL647.description: Survey course in diagnostic reading assessment and instruction for graduate students not majoring in reading.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of EDUC-Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership department.

TLPL653.name: Clinical Assessment in Reading
TLPL653.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL653.description: Clinical diagnostic techniques and materials for assessing reading strengths and needs.

relationships.prereqs: TLPL645 and TLPL650; or permission of EDUC-Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership department.

TLPL656.name: Teaching Culturally and Linguistically Diverse Exceptional Learners
TLPL656.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL656.description: Explores cross-cultural and linguistic diversity as they relate to identification procedures for and education of English learners with exceptional needs beyond the second language acquisition process such as learning disabilities and gifted & talented.

TLPL657.name: Teaching for Cross Cultural Communication
TLPL657.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL657.description: Theories of intercultural communication and techniques for applying them in the teaching of English as a second language (ESL) and content classes. Research and evaluation of selected aspects of a culture as basis for creating, selecting and using culturally-responsive teaching materials and methods.

TLPL661.name: Multiliteracies: Theory and Practice
TLPL661.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL661.description: Explores the theoretical constructs and practical manifestations of multiliteracies in communities and schools by presenting an overview of the research on the constructs of New Literacy Studies, Critical Literacy, Digital Literacy, and Funds of Knowledge, as well as the practical implications of teaching reading and writing to culturally and linguistically diverse learners in content areas (i.e., language arts, math, science, social studies, etc.) in classrooms.

relationships.prereqs: TLPL665.

TLPL662.name: Second Language Acquisition
TLPL662.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL662.description: Major theoretical approaches to second language acquisition. For teaching English to speakers of other languages (TESOL).

relationships.restrictions: Permission of EDUC-Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership department.

TLPL664.name: Foundations of Second Language Education: Legal, Social and  Historical Trends and Issues
TLPL664.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL664.description: Knowledge of history, research, current practice and public policy issues in the field of second languague education from kindergarten to post-secondary settings. Required for TESOL certification program.

TLPL665.name: Methods of Teaching ESOL
TLPL665.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL665.description: This course presents a survey of the historical and current approaches, methods, and techniques of teaching English to speakers of other languages, from grammar to translation to audiolingual and communicative approaches. Additionally, successful classroom practices that address the needs of culturally diverse and language minority students will be analyzed.

TLPL666.name: English Grammar for Teachers of English to Speakers of Other Languages
TLPL666.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL666.description: English grammar and methods of teaching grammar for graduate, prospective and current teachers of English to speakers of other languages. Analysis of the major grammatical structures of American English. Discussion of the role of teaching grammar, and effective classroom methods and techniques for the English as a second/foreign language classroom.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of EDUC-Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership department.

TLPL671.name: Education Policy Analysis
TLPL671.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL671.description: Policy making in education from planning to evaluation with emphasis on the identification of policy problems and the resources available to analysts through multi-disciplinary approaches. An introductory experience with education policy analysis.

TLPL675.name: Embracing Diversity in Classroom Communities
TLPL675.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL675.description: The course aims to help students understand race, class, gender, and sexuality as systems of privilege, exclusion, marginalization, and the centrality of embracing diversity in the classroom communities to promote the success of all students.

TLPL683.name: Sociology of Education
TLPL683.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL683.description: This seminar examines major theoretical frameworks and perspectives of the sociology of education with an emphasis on k-12 education. The course also takes a pragmatic approach by applying theoretical knowledge to understand U.S. schooling and contemporary educational themes and debates where activists, researchers, and political actors aim to alter schools, students, or families.

TLPL687.name: Politics of Education
TLPL687.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL687.description: Educational institutions as political entities. Focuses on conceptual perspectives for examining political dynamics in governmental and organizational contexts. Provides opportunities to carry out original case studies of policy making processes at various levels of the education policy system.

TLPL689.name: Internship in Education
TLPL689.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL689.description: Student lab fee may apply. Contact program for details.

TLPL691.name: Research Methods
TLPL691.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL691.description: The interpretation and conduct of research relevant to curriculum, teaching and learning.

TLPL695.name: Methods I: K-12 World Language Methods and Technology
TLPL695.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL695.description: TLPL 695 requires on-going examination of theories relevant to language acquisition. Students will also investigate the instructional methods that reflect those theories.

relationships.additional_info: Lab and field experiences required.

TLPL696.name: Advanced K-12 World Language Methods and Technology
TLPL696.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL696.description: Teaches advanced best practices for effective World Language instruction. Topics include: lesson planning, using authentic assessment and materials, applying national and state standards infusing culture, interdisciplinary content and technology. Classroom management procedures and strategies to create a welcoming and engaging classroom environment. Motivating students and differentiated instruction.

relationships.coreqs: Must be concurrently enrolled in TLPL479J.
relationships.prereqs: TLPL695; and TLPL695.

TLPL698.name: Conducting Research on Teaching
TLPL698.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL699.name: Master's Seminar
TLPL699.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL704.name: Research Methodologies and Educational Practice
TLPL704.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL704.description: Introduction to methodological approaches commonly used in educational research with a focus on addressing issues in teaching and learning, schools and communities, and educational policy.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership Master of Arts program; or permission of instructor.

TLPL708A.name: Special Topics in Technology, Learning & Leadership; Seminar
TLPL708A.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL708C.name: Special Topics in Technology, Learning & Leadership; Research-Educational Responses to Digital Mis- and Disinformation
TLPL708C.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL708D.name: Special Topics in Technology, Learning & Leadership; Research-Practice Partnerships in Education
TLPL708D.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL710.name: Theory and Research on Mathematical and Scientific Thinking and Learning
TLPL710.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL710.description: Study of mathematical and scientific thinking by students at various levels of schooling considered from the perspective of those classic and contemporary theories of learning that are particularly relevant to the study of mathematics and science. Exploration of what it means to understand mathematics and science.

relationships.prereqs: Admitted to Doctoral Program in Mathematics Education or Science Education; or permission of EDUC-Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership department.

TLPL728.name: Research Seminar in Mathematics and Science Education
TLPL728.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL740.name: Language and Education
TLPL740.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL740.description: Dialect, language varieties in school settings; historical and current perspectives on the role of language in learning; theories of school achievement and consequences for language assessment.

TLPL762.name: Phenomenological Inquiry I
TLPL762.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL762.description: Philosophic grounding for phenomenological inquiry at a beginning level Guided writing practice in doing phenomenological inquiry is provided on a selected lived experience phenomenon.

TLPL764.name: Data Management and Coding in Stata
TLPL764.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL764.description: School districts and states are required to collect large swaths of data on students, teachers, and schools. These large administrative datasets have become the backbone of education policy research, and so students interested in engaging in this space increasingly need the skills to work with "big data." This course will help students learn a coding language from the program Stata in order to clean and analyze large datasets. Topics covered include: data cleaning, recoding and checking; merging data from multiple sources; reshaping data; documenting processes; writing programs and macros to reduce errors; and presenting descriptive data through tables and graphs.

relationships.additional_info: Recommended: Some prior experience with data management and statistical programming software (namely Stata) and with applied statistics.  Class will be held in the COE Computer Lab in Benjamin Building.

TLPL765.name: Quantitative Applicaltions for Education Policy Analysis
TLPL765.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL765.description: Students use quantitative applications and secondary datasets to investigate social problems and education policies. Emphasis on the use of quasi-experimental designs and regression techniques to frame education issues, analyze, and recommend policies.

relationships.prereqs: EDMS645; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.
relationships.additional_info: Recommended: EDMS646; or EDMS651. Or EDMS646; and EDMS651.

TLPL767.name: Law, Equity, and Diversity in Education
TLPL767.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL767.description: An examination of 'dilemmas of difference' on selected issues that arise at the intersection of law and education policy. Dilemmas and value conflicts imbedded in modern federal and state case law dealing with race, gender, sexual orientation, religion and disability.

TLPL771.name: Pedagogy of Teacher Education
TLPL771.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL771.description: Illuminates and challenges the somewhat implicit pedagogies of teacher education that have existed over time, and aims to develop a more overt knowledge of where the field is, and should be, as we engage in the opportunities and challenges of teaching and teacher education in our current era. To do so, we examine teacher education as racialized, linguicized, and gendered, and as situated in larger political and power-laden contexts.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of department.

TLPL774.name: Urban Education
TLPL774.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL774.description: This seminar provides students with a broad overview of urban education as a field of inquiry by examining the social context of urban schools, how transformative pedagogy is practiced and conceptualized as well as school reform.

TLPL788A.name: Special Topics in Education; Learning Equity: In and Out of Scholl
TLPL788A.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL788D.name: Special Topics in Education; Data Management for Social Science Research
TLPL788D.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL788D.description: Class will be held in the COE Computer Lab in Benjamin Building.

TLPL788E.name: Special Topics in Education; Professional Seminar in Urban Education
TLPL788E.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL788I.name: Special Topics in Education; Language Policy and Education
TLPL788I.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL788K.name: Special Topics in Education; Teacher Cognition
TLPL788K.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL788M.name: Special Topics in Education; Education Policy Research Workshop
TLPL788M.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL788Q.name: Special Topics in Education; Seminar in Teacher Education and Professional Development
TLPL788Q.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL788R.name: Special Topics in Education; Education Policy Research Workshop
TLPL788R.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL788U.name: Special Topics in Education; Race and Whiteness
TLPL788U.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL788W.name: Special Topics in Education
TLPL788W.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL789.name: Internship in Education
TLPL789.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL790.name: Seminar in Mixed Methods Research in Education
TLPL790.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL790.description: Examination of epistemological and methodological issues involved in conducting mixed methods studies in education. Students design and conduct analyses using existing datasets that include qualitative and quantitative data. They formulate appropriate research questions, consider alternative mixed methods designs, and address methodological complexities associated with working with qualitative and quantitative data in a single study.

relationships.prereqs: EDMS646; and (EDCI791 or EDHI700); and permission of EDUC-Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership department.
relationships.additional_info: Recommended: EDCI792.

TLPL791.name: Qualitative Research I: Design and Fieldwork
TLPL791.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL791.description: Examines the theoretical and epistemological moorings of different types of qualitative research.  Students apply selected field research methods to problems of professional practice in schools and communities while considering central issues and dilemmas that arise while engaging in fieldwork.

relationships.prereqs: EDCI790.

TLPL794.name: Foundations of Educational Research I
TLPL794.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL794.description: An introduction to the "contested terrain" of education research. It examines major conceptual, methodological and political issues embedded in efforts to carry out education research and focuses on the development of the analytic dispositions and communication skills required to carry out research that meets the variously defined quality, utility and significance standards of scholarship in the field.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership (Doctoral) program.

TLPL798.name: Special Problems in Education
TLPL798.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL799.name: Master's Thesis Research
TLPL799.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL860.name: Seminar on Case Study Methods
TLPL860.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership
TLPL860.description: Conceived as both an analysis of case study methods and a laboroatory for applying course content to research topics or projects of interest to students, it addresses a range of conceptual, methodological, ethical, political, and logistical issues embedded in efforts to conduct thoughtful, "disciplined" case study research. Since this focuses on case study research, it may be particularly helpful to students who are exploring various approaches to research or who are contemplating using case study methods in their theises and/or dissertations.

relationships.prereqs: TLPL690; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

TLPL888.name: Apprenticeship in Education
TLPL888.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL889.name: Internship in Education
TLPL889.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL898.name: Pre-Candidacy Research
TLPL898.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLPL899.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research
TLPL899.department: Teaching and Learning, Policy and Leadership

TLTC310.name: Leadership in Collaborative Learning Groups
TLTC310.description: Experiential learning opportunity that applies principles of leadership, peer mentoring, and learning theory to the planning and facilitation of peer-led collaborative learning sessions. Incorporates research, reasoning, evidence, and feedback to develop a reflective practice.

relationships.restrictions: Restricted to students selected to participate in the Guided Study Sessions through the Teaching and Learning Transformation Center.

TLTC333.name: Fundamentals of Academic Peer Mentoring
TLTC333.description: How should scientific research influence the way we study and advance the academic performance of others? Learn about the scholarship of teaching and learning and develop the applied skills to support active learning as an academic peer mentor. Whether or not you ultimately pursue a career as an educator, the more effectively you can coach and support the performance of other people, and the more successful you will be. Guided online and face-to-face participation will culminate in a portfolio of your teaching activities and professional development.

relationships.additional_info: Click here for more course information.

TLTC399.name: Independent Study in Academic Peer Mentoring
TLTC399.description: Repeatable to 6 credits. Earn academic credit for the time spent supporting a course in TLTC's Academic Peer Mentoring Program (AMP). Click here for more course information.

relationships.prereqs: Must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in TLTC333.
relationships.restrictions: Permission of TLTC required - enrollment restriction.

TLTC499A.name: Independent Study in Teaching and Learning
TLTC499A.description: Contact the department for information to register for this course.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of TLTC required.

UMEI003.name: English as a Foreign Language: Intermediate II
UMEI003.description: Intensive course for the non-native speaker of English who has mastered the essential structures of English grammar. Emphasis on improving communicative skills for a wide range of linguistic situations, on rapid expansion of vocabulary, and on improving reading comprehension and basic writing skills. Special fee required for this course. This course does not carry credit towards any degree at the University and does not count in the retention plan.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of EDUC-Dean-Maryland English Institute department.

UMEI004.name: English as a Foreign Language: Intermediate III
UMEI004.description: Intensive course for the non-native speaker of English who has a good command of the basic features of spoken and written English. Emphasis on refining speaking and listening skills, on improving reading speed and comprehension of academic texts, and on developing writing skills for academic courses. Special fee required for this course. This course does not carry credit towards any degree at the University and does not count in the retention plan.

relationships.restrictions: Permission of EDUC-Dean-Maryland English Institute department.

UMEI005.name: Advanced English as a Foreign Language
UMEI005.description: Semi-intensive course for the nearly proficient non-native speaker of English needing additional language instruction prior to undertaking full-time academic study. Speaking and listening skills; improvement of reading speed and comprehension; and development of writing skills. Special fee required for this course. This course does not carry credit towards any degree at the University and does not count in the retention plan.

UMEI006.name: English Pronunciation
UMEI006.description: Individualized class for the non-native speaker of English. Diagnosis of individual pronunciation problems. Practice in the correct pronunciation of English sounds and improvement of ability to speak English with proper stress and intonation patterns. Special fee required for this course. This course does not carry credit towards any degree at the University and does not count in the retention plan.

relationships.restrictions: Must have graduate standing.

UMEI007.name: Advanced Writing for International Students
UMEI007.description: A writing skills course for the non-native speaker of English with a good command of spoken English. This course does not carry credit towards any degree at the University and does not count in the retention plan.

relationships.restrictions: Must have graduate standing.

UNIV100.name: The Student in the University
UNIV100.description: Introduces students to University life. In a small classroom setting, students will explore how to successfully bridge the gap between high school and college. Study skills, career decision-making, and student development processes will be explored.

UNIV100V.name: The Student in the University
UNIV100V.description: Introduces students to University life. In a small classroom setting, students will explore how to successfully bridge the gap between high school and college. Study skills, career decision-making, and student development processes will be explored.

UNIV106.name: The Transfer Student in the University
UNIV106.description: This course is designed to assist students in making a successful transition to the University of Maryland (UMD) and to serve as an extended orientation to campus living and learning.

relationships.restrictions: Must be a first-semester transfer student.
